column2: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., April 14 (UPI)--Dennis Brodeur, a barkeeper, has to get rid of his winter store of 30,000 empty beer cans before the horses return to this resort island, where automobiles are banned.

Mr. and Mrs. E. Tillman Stirling of Chevy Chase, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Stirling, to Hans Jurgen Gruss, who teaches law at the University of Augsburg in West Germany.

WASHINGTON--Polls have been bad news for President Carter for months, revealing with a thudding persistence that the American public does not like the way he handles his job, thinks he lacks leadership qualities and believes he cannot cope with inflation. Last week, he even managed to get discouraging news from a poll that never once asked how he was doing.

As far as we can determine, the dowries that President Carter promised Egypt and Israel for their peacemaking would cost the United States an additional $500 million a year for the next three years. Most of that will be gifts. The rest will generate huge loans for military purchases, largely in the United States, but these will be repaid with normal commercial interest. If peace can truly be served at these amounts, it's a bargain.
Laurie Anderson has been doing performance art of one sort or another on the SoHo scene for several years, now, but this writer hadn't encountered her in some time.
ALLENHURST TRAFFIC on the New Jersey Turnpike has not diminished, despite the tightening gasoline situation that has led some service stations along the superhighway to restrict their sales.

HONG KONG, April 13--In a reversal of the relatively open policy of the last few months toward the outside world, China is taking a more xenophobic approach, warning people against fraternizing with foreigners, asking for Westernstyle democracy or becoming too dependent on foreign technology.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Hugh Farley of Garden City, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Marie Farley, to Bradley James Quin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Wyndham Quin of River Vale, N.J.

COLUMBINES and cornflowers are prime sources for blue color in the garden. Both come in other colors, too, but New Jersey gardeners who are looking for blue flowers that bloom prolifically with little care could not do better than to choose columbines (to bloom in late spring and early summer) and cornflowers (to bloom in the summer and fall).

Although the temporary commission to investigate casino gambling has not yet made even an interim report, prominent New Yorkers, including Governor Carey and Mayor Koch, are already squabbling over where the gambling goose will be invited to lay her golden eggs. They should instead be making sure the goose is capable of laying them anywhere.

Dr. and Mrs. Devereux Haigh Lippitt of New Bern, N.C., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Anita Walthour Lippitt, to Michael Rourke Rogers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Charles Rogers of Reading, Mass. A June 30 wedding is planned.

Art Hall and Tom Cuffe finished together in the seven-mile Riverdale Ramble yesterday, clocking 37 minutes 30 seconds. The race, over a hilly course in Riverdale, drew more than 350 entries. Marie Roach of the Long Island Golden Spikes led the women with a time of 45:27.
In the midst of the Washington Bul lets' run to the National Basketball Association championship last season, Coach Dick Motta sounded the lone sobering note.

Willie Mays of the New York Giants was batting against Sal Maglie of the Brooklyn Dodgers, whom they called The Barber because he shaved hitters so close. The first pitch brushed Willie back and the second low-bridged him.

BONN, April 14 (UPI)--The Nuerburgring race track, boycotted by the world's Formula One drivers since Niki Lauda crashed and was burned there in 1976, will lose 159 of the 174 curves that made it what many considered the toughest and most dangerous course in the world.
WHITE PLAINS ELLEN OCHS needed a paying job last summer but did not think that she could find one working with retarded persons, an avocation that may become her career.

JONATHAN MILLER, best known for his connection with "Beyond the Fringe," once qualified as a doctor of medicine. He also has special interests in the history and philosophy of science, and these talents are very much in evidence in "The Body in Question," a book version of a 13-part BBC television series.

WESTCHESTER County, the site of many a gingerbread Victorian mansion, will pay tribute to contem porary architecture Thursday night. A benefit for the Hudson River Museum is planned as a name-dropping occasion.
The Jerusalem International Book Fair, starting Thursday and continuing for a week, is the first fair in the Middle East since the signing of the peace treaty between Egypt and Israel.

WASHINGTON, April 14--The majority opinion in Washington at the Easter recess seems to be that President Carter is in deep political trouble and is likely to be defeated if he runs for re-election in 1980.

The 1978-79 season of the Metropolitan Opera ended yesterday, and it's statistic-flinging time again. The season saw five new productions. There were ten operas in Italian, seven in German, four in English, two in French and one in Russian: 24 in all, for a total of 214 performances.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI)--The Center for Auto Safety is sending several hundred letters to Ford owners who have complained to the Government, Ford of the center itself of defects in their cars. The public interest group wants to force the Government to act on allegations that certain Ford cars have defects that cause them to jump from park into reverse.

FOR 25 years or so, I had for my operating headquarters a shelter where I could walk naked without offending anyone and compose novels out loud. I ironed into a thousand shirts the dialogue of heroic persons I had created.
MOSCOW, April 14--Handel's "Messiah" was presented here this weekend in what may have been its first performance in the Soviet Union since the Communists came to power in 1917.

Some time next year, probably when the bright-colored warblers are migrating north, an event calculated to distract millions of bird watchers even from this annual springtime excitement will take place: the publication of a revised edition, the first in 30 years, of "A Field Guide to the Birds"!

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 14 (Reuters)--The Rhode Island Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a worker was entitled to compensation for an injury he suffered when he struck a coffee machine that did not dispense a cup of coffee after he put money into it. Michael Denardo, a former foundry worker, suffered a 10 percent loss in the use of his right hand because of the blow.

BARRY KRUPOWICZ is determined to be in shape when this year's motocross schedule opens Saturday at the Bridgehampton Race Circuit. Since early winter, the 35-year-old auto body repairman from Brentwood has been lifting weights, running several miles daily and doing special calisthenics. He has also quit drinking beer and smoking.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 14 (Reuters)--The Rhode Island Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a worker was entitled to compensation for an injury he suffered when he struck a coffee machine that did not dispense a cup of coffee after he put money into it. Michael Denardo, a former foundry worker, suffered a 10 percent loss in the use of his right hand because of the blow.

BARRY KRUPOWICZ is determined to be in shape when this year's motocross schedule opens Saturday at the Bridgehampton Race Circuit. Since early winter, the 35-year-old auto body repairman from Brentwood has been lifting weights, running several miles daily and doing special calisthenics. He has also quit drinking beer and smoking.

CHICAGO--When Jane M. Byrne is sworn in tomorrow night as Mayor of Chicago, she will take on not only the burden of running the nation's second largest city, but also the challenge of living up to the legend of Richard J. Daley.

GAYLORD, Mich., April 14--Six years after she married a former Detroit automobile dealer named Herman Isaac Smith, Jeannette Smith, 47 years old, has been acquitted of killing him with a kitchen knife.

MEXICO CITY, April 14--In a brief ceremony marking the 60th anniversary of the murder of Emiliano Zapata, President Jose Lopez Portillo this week raised a white flag outside the ruins of the Chinameca hacienda where the revolutionary hero was shot down.

Alice Pauline Guillemette of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Alice Margaret Guillemette, to M. Declan Bransfield 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Declan Bransfield Jr. of Norfolk, Va.

WHEN one speaks of a "basic American restaurant" serving "good, honest food," the emphasis is often on the basics rather than on the variety of American regional cooking. The Alps, opened in Bronxville in 1927 and maintained under the same watchful owner for the last 14 years, has always served fresh, impeccably cooked American basics in a warm, convivial atmosphere.

Eight robbers fired several shots inside a Queens bar Friday night and forced its more than 100 patrons to disrobe, according to the police. A woman was sexually assaulted before the robbers escaped with an undetermined amount of cash and personal jewelry, authorities reported.

JACKSON, Miss., April 15--The Pearl River, enlarged by last week's heavy rains, sent murky flood waters into this capital city today, leaving businesses abandoned and forcing an estimated 15,000 people from their homes.
AMES, Iowa, April 15 (AP)--Chuck Yagla of the Hawkeye Wrestling Club of Iowa City won his third straight title Saturday at the national Amateur Athletic Union freestyle wrestling championships.

When the Mets scored 19 runs in their first two games of the year, the offseason trading that had sacrificed pitching to gain offensive punch seemed successful. Yesterday at Shea Stadium, however, the Mets showed little of their early offensive authority as they dropped a doubleheader to the Philadelphia Phillies, 3-2 and 6-3.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI)-- Most taxpayers have until midnight tomorrow to file their Federal income tax returns, but holidays will give residents of North Carolina, the New England states and northern New York an extra day's grace.

BREWSTER, N.Y., April 15 (UPI)--A couple driving to a sunrise Easter church service and the 19-year-old driver of a second car, all of the Putnam County town of Patterson, were killed in a headon collision near here early today, the state police reported.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI)--The Justice Department said today it planned to set up offices in 27 cities in a major drive against "crime in the suites"-- white collar crimes such as corporate embezzlement, fraud or theft of securities.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 15-- An earthquake rolled across the southern Adriatic coast of Yugoslavia today, leveling villages and killing and injuring hundreds of people.

Idi Amin has been chased from his capital and the end of Uganda's eight-year nightmare seems at hand. The joy of a people liberated from murderous brutality is enough to overwhelm, for now, any misgivings about the role of Tanzanian soldiers in the final act and concern about the difficult task of reconstruction ahead.
TORONTO, April 15--Canada's business world is being deluged by a nationwide wave of takeovers that is prompting more and more calls for stronger antitrust legislation.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 15--The scene has been familiar in Rhodesia since white settlers arrived here in the 1890's: a white farmer standing in a grove of mango and eucalyptus trees addressing farmhands and their families in the Shona language, spoken by more than 80 percent of the country's 6.8 million blacks.

WASHINGTON, April 15--A highlevel Administration study group has virtually completed a set of recommendations that would result in substantial cuts in regulation for the nation's financial institutions.

The Carter Administration was right to cut off economic aid to Pakistan for surreptitiously starting to build a plant to produce nuclear explosives. But Pakistan was only doing what rival India did a decade ago, so trying to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons now requires effective measures against India as well.

As confident as ever of the alternating-goalie system that helped his New York Islanders post the best regularseason record in the National Hockey League, Coach Al Arbour has told Glenn (Chico) Resch and Billy Smith that they will take turns in the net during Stanley Cup play.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 15--Israeli armed forces have returned openly to southern Lebanon, right-wing Christian militia groups move about freely with heavy arms, Palestinian and leftist guerrillas have increased attempts at infiltration, and the United Nations peacekeeping troops can do nothing.

LANDOVER, Md., April 15--The Washington Bullets, featuring the inside scoring of Elvin Hayes and Bobby Dandridge, opened the defense of their National Basketball Association championship today with a 103-89 victory over the Atlanta Hawks at the Capital Centre.

American cosmetic companies have long enjoyed a singular success in the difficult Japanese consumer market. The Japanese recently expressed their admiration when the KAO Soap Company, Japan's leading manufacturer of synthetic detergents, made a deal to acquire Helena Rubinstein Inc.

TULSA, Okla., April 15 (UPI)--Topseeded Jimmy Connors, withstanding temperatures of almost 90 degrees, wore down Eddie Dibbs today to post a 6-7, 7-5, 6-1 victory and capture the $50,000 Tulsa Grand Prix tennis tournament.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 13--A Federal grand jury investigation into the police ambush of two young leftists is roiling the political waters in Puerto Rico as the commonwealth heads toward another round of debate on the statehood question.

At the age of 19, George Whitmore Jr., became the wrong man in the notorious Wylie-Hoffert "career girl" murders in New York City. Now, 15 years after he was arrested and six years after he was finally cleared of three murders and an attempted rape, Mr. Whitmore has apparently lost all hope of winning a penny from New York for false imprisonment.
KAMPALA, Uganda, April 15-- After eight years of silence and fear, the people of Uganda are beginning to feel free to talk again.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., April 15-- The Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions, seeking to cope with changing times and a tight budget, plans to abandon its no-longer-quiet hillside villa.

Women's liberation is probably the most successful pestilence since Prohibition, a movement that was likewise under feminine stewardship. It thrived, nourished as it was by the major philosophical current of modern America, namely self-interest, improperly understood.

The annual spring bird migration, just now getting under way with millions of birds heading north for their summer breeding grounds, has often ended in death for small birds, which tend to crash into lighted structures on cloudy nights.

LOS ANGELES, April 15--California, which has more unaccredited law schools than any other state, is considering a proposal by the California Bar Association that would eliminate the schools in five years unless they upgraded their faculties and curriculums to meet the accreditation standards of the state and the American Bar Association.

All 167 shops of the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation will reopen in time for today's thoroughbred racing program if the more than 1,000 striking clerks who have kept most of the shops closed since March 27 vote this morning to ratify a contract settlement.

The Chinese garden--contrasting with the contemplative, serene, orderly and more easily grasped Japanese garden--appears to be a restless, anarchic, crowded place, with jumbles of pockmarked, grotesque rocks, buildings, bedless plantings and no lawns at all.

HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., April 15--The malady that afflicts almost all tennis players--choking--gripped Tracy Austin for the first time today, but she still managed a 7-6, 7-6 victory over Kerry Reid in the final of a $150,000 women's tournament.
OAK GROVE, La., April 15 (AP)-- Five young men died and three others were injured when they were trapped inside a van that slammed into a bridge abutment, leaped a creek and crashed, ...

Leonard H. Meyers, a physicist and lecturer at the Center for Interdisciplinary and Innovative Science in the School of Natural Sciences at San Francisco State University, died Friday at his home in San Francisco after a long-illness. He was 47 years old.
TEHERAN, Iran, Monday, April 16-- Iran's Foreign Minister, Karim Sanjabi, resigned his post, it was annouunced this morning by Radio Iran.

CALHOUN, Ga., April 15 (AP)--The Rev. Dr. R.L. Maddox, who says he is "cut from the same cloth" as President Carter, said today that he will leave the First Baptist Church of Calhoun to become a White House speechwriter.

Hijinks have given way to violence on a few American campuses, keeping law enforcement officials busy, prompting neighbors to consider moving away and costing some fraternities their campus welcome and hundreds of dollars in damages.

LONG BEACH, Calif., April 15--Billy Carter has confirmed that the Libyan Government paid for his trip to Rome and Tripoli last fall, but he steadfastly denies the suggestion that he had any business dealings with the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

JERUSALEM, April 15--An Israeli Army force killed four Palestinian guerrillas who crossed the Jordan River into northern Israel this morning, according to a military spokesman. He said there were no Israeli casualties.
LONDON, April 15--In the end, the British general election on May 3 may turn on one simple but nebulous question: How long is a voter's memory?
THE one thing that no play centering on the Don Juan legend should do is to play the music from Mozart's opera. It is letting the sun rise on candlelight.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 (UPI)-- The financially troubled Bond Baking Company has closed its distribution centers in northern New Jersey, a company spokesman has confirmed. The centers in Edison, Asbury Park and Clifton were closed Tuesday when the entire company was threatened by a lack of cash. Bond got a $500,000 loan from the Philadelphia National Bank and reopened its Philadelphia baking operations and its distribution centers in southern New Jersey Thursday.

SERGIU COMISSIONA and the American Symphony Orchestra offered an Easter program yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall that ended with a really inspiring account of Mahler's Symphony No. 2 in C minor ("Resurrection").

WASHINGTON, April 15--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee said in a staff report today that President Carter's policy of cutting back on arms sales was "running out of time" and his efforts to get Moscow to agree to a formula for restraining weapons exports "may be on the brink of failure."

WASHINGTON--According to the Theory of Cognitive Dissonance propounded two decades ago by Prof. Leon Festinger, the human mind tries to block out information not consonant with previous beliefs or actions. For example, a recent purchaser of a Panasonic videotape recorder tries not to read ads for Sony Betamax.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 15--Iran announced today that it was raising oil prices by 13 percent over the basic level set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Geneva last month. The new prices will be $16.57 for a barrel of Iranian light crude and $16.04 for a barrel of heavy crude.

PARIS, April 15 (UPI)--Consumer prices in the 24 countries that are members of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development rose by eight-tenths of 1 percent in February, underlining continued strong inflationary trends since the beginning of the year, the O.E.C.D. reported.
CLEVELAND, April 15--Edward S. Reddig, retired board chairman of White Consolidated Industries Inc., died today in University Hospitals here. He was 74 years old.

DENVER, April 15 (AP)--Kareem Abdul-Jabbar sank a hook shot with 12 seconds remaining, lifting the Los Angeles Lakers to a 112-111 victory over the Denver Nuggets today in the deciding game of their two-of-three National Basketball Association playoff series.

ON THE MOVE Greenwich Village's Westbeth Theater tonight rings in the second season of "Mainly Mime," a potpourri of new material by professional mimes, clowns, mask specialists and dramatic acrobats.
LEIPZIG, East Germany--East Germany, celebrating its 30th year as a nation, is faced with an economic future that does not look bright.

WHAT is the "New Class" that is taking over? According to Alvin W. Gouldner, Max Weber Professor of Social Theory at Washington University in St. Louis, the New Class consists of scientists, educators, managers, communicators, publicity agents, maybe even literary critics and other "professionals," whose business it is to run the culture. Culture--knowledge and skills--is in fact the capital of the New Class.

In a typical countergambit, such as the Greco (1 P-K4, P-K4; 2 N-KB3, P-KB4) or the Albin (1 P-Q4, P-Q4; 2 P-QB4, P-K4), Black sacrifices a pawn to remove a white pawn from the center, thus clearing the way for the buildup of a superiority there. The ultimate objective, once Black has established a strong pawn center, is to constrict the white position and develop an attack, usually against the king.

Judge Bruce McM. Wright stepped up his attack on the New York police yesterday, referring to the head of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association as a "skunk" and to three white policemen found not guilty of killing blacks as "killers" and "enemies."

EDGEWATER, N.J., April 15--Size seemed to make a big difference today as Rodney Harmon of Richmond defeated Hugo Nunez of Rockaway, N.J., in the final of the boys' 18-year-old division of the Easter Bowl junior tennis tournament.

MOSCOW, April 15 (AP)--Joe Mullen, a New Yorker who plays for Boston College, scored early in the final period to give the United States a 1-1 tie with Finland in the world hockey championship today.

An economic setback, whether it be inflation or recession, is commonly described only in economic terms: rising prices, falling profits or increased unemployment. Rarely are, there graphs or charts to show the effect of these cold statistics on people's lives.

AUGUSTA, GA. WHEN he arrived at the Augusta National Golf Club Sunday, Fuzzy Zoeller was handed a blue Easter egg by a hometown friend. On it in white letters were the words "Fuzzy Zoeller Masters Champ." But not many people took it seriously. Fuzzy Zoeller was then six strokes behind Ed Sneed as the final round of the Masters was about to begin. But he enjoyed his present.

GROTON, Conn., April 15 (AP)-- Navy projections say that the work force of 18,000 at the General Dynamics Corporation's Electric Boat division in Groton, where the Trident nuclear submarines are being built, could be cut by one-third by the mid-1980's because of lack of work, Representative Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, said today. An Electric Boat spokesman. Joe Wornom, called Mr. Dodd's statement "alarmist."

SHANGHAI, April 15--Despite a nationwide crackdown on political dissidents, some wall posters demanding more human rights in China and assailing the Shanghai police are still being pasted up here in the country's largest city.

Today's self-styled neo-conservatives are convinced (and some would say convincing) that liberalism--defined for the most part as the demand for Government intervention in social and economic life--is intellectually exhausted. More likely, liberalism is politically exhausted and exiled to the political wilderness where there is a hunger after ideas that have too small a following and spark too little popular responsiveness to constitute a political alternative.

LIKE the studio it is celebrating, "The RKO Years" is a disarmingly unpretentious, somewhat ragged documentary. The pro gram, narrated by Joseph Cotten, who appears in a small studio with a few skimpy props, can be seen tonight at 10 on WOR/Channel 9, which happens to be an RKO Television station.

THE leaders of 10 of the country's largest ad agencies are unanimous in their personal belief that agencies should not pursue accounts that conflict with those they already have. That, however, does not mean it never happens.
CHICAGO, April 15--For the second day in a row, the Yankees spotted the White Sox a sizable early lead and then caught and passed them with some long-distance hitting.

KADUNA, Nigeria--The booklet is called "Bridging the Gap," and its popularity extends far beyond the readership for which it was intended: the 5,000 Nigerians who go each year to study in Britain, about a fourth the number of Nigerians attending school in the United States.

If ever a National Hockey League series was destined to go the full seven games, it is the quarterfinal matchup between the Rangers and the Philadelphia Flyers that starts at 8:05 tonight in the Spectrum. The winning score will probably come in the second overtime period, when a clearing pass caroms off a defenseman's skate, hits a goal post and trickles off the stick of an unlucky goalie and into the cage.

After a year at the United States headquarters of her agency, McCann-Erickson, Ann Burdus has returned to the McCann Group, Britain's largest agency, as one of its two leaders. She will be chairman, while Barry Day, a widely known creative man, will be president.

GRAND ISLE, La., April 15 (UPI)--A father and his son drowned and two men were missing today on an overnight camping trip on Timbalier Island off the coast of Louisiana.

Morris Davidson, an artist and teacher of art, died Friday of a heart attack at his home at Orchard Terrace, Piermont, N.Y. He was 80 years old.

The New York City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, reported yesterday that he had found "numerous instances of extravagance and abuse" in the way that travel expenses had been paid to the trustees of four municipal-employee welfare funds to attend out-of-town conventions.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Aug. 15--Fuzzy Zoeller, a cheerful 27-year-old extrovert who likes to exchange wisecracks with galleries, won the 43d Masters today on the second hole of a suddendeath playoff with Tom Watson and Ed Sneed.

MUNDAL, Norway, April 15--On a summer's day in 1856, a farmer named Fredrik Mundal, his wife and their sixyear-old son, Ole, set out on a long and perilous journey from this remote village of 400 people, nestled beneath the mighty Jostedalsbre glacier along the spectacular Fjaerlands Fjord.

Most were in Boston, where about 20, led by Richie Phillips, attorney for the Major League Umpires Association, marched outside Fenway Park in 42-degree weather before the game between the Red Sox and the Cleveland Indians.

SHAMKHAN, Pakistan, April 12--An effectively functioning network of selfexiled Afghans in refugees camps in the semidesert tribal areas of Pakistan's remote Baluchistan Province appears to be running the growing revolt against the year-old pro-Soviet Government in Afghanistan.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)--The United States Metric Board will hold public hearings here May 2 and 3 on whether gasoline pumps should be converted to metric measurements.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, April 15 (UPI)--Top-seeded Bjorn Borg of Sweden crushed Vitas Gerulaitas, 6-2, 6-1, 6-3, in the final of a $175,000 World Championship Tennis tournament today.

This week's volume of fixed-income financing will be down sharply from that of last week, when the Treasury sold a 15-year bond issue at a record yield and a fairly large total of corporate and tax-exempt bonds were marketed.

RABAT, Morocco, April 15 (Reuters) --King Hussein of Jordan arrived here today for a private visit to Morocco with his wife, the American-born Noor al-Hussein, after a skiing holiday in the Austrian Alps.

Colin Fowles, a defender for the Fort Lauderdale Strikers of the North American Soccer League, was once clocked in 9.9 seconds for the 100-yard dash when he was a student at Long Island University. Fowles thus believes that he is the fastest soccer player in the world. Whether he is or not, 9.9 ought to stand him in good stead. Unless he decides to become a race horse.
Louis L. Horch, a specialist in international exchange and the founder of the Master Institute of United Arts in New York City, died last week at his home in Hallandale, Fla. He was 90 years old.
AT Ivy League football games, in which it often seems that neither side is capable of winning, the cheerleading is apt to be correspondingly diffident and the crowds quietly contemplative.

ROME, April 15--Pope John Paul II, in an Easter message today, appealed for peace and human rights, and strongly re minded a great throng at St. Peter's of the plight of poor people and especially the sufferings of destitute children.
MONTEREY PARK, Calif., April 15 --George Haines smiled the smile of a poker player holding kings and queens but he wasn't claiming the pot yet.

BILBAO, Spain, April 15 (Reuters)-- About 200,000 Basque nationalists, calling for home rule and shouting slogans against the Spanish and French Governments, marched today through four northern Spain provincial capitals--Bilbao, San Sebastian, Pamplona and Vitoria.

The Administration has risked the further erosion of its anti-inflation program by cheering so loudly for the tentative new contract between the Teamsters and the truckers. The cheers are premature. The union's members will not vote on the settlement until later this month, and then they will look extra hard at any deal that has the Administration's guideline guardians dancing down Pennsylvania Avenue.

AMMAN, Jordan, April 15--Jordan was for years the closest Arab friend of the United States, a reliably "moderate" state in an area of shifting extremes. Since Camp David and the Egyptian-Israeli treaty, the relation ship has come on hard times. Jordanians and American diplomats both speak of "strain."

WILMINGTON, Del., April 15--The youthful crew of the Pride of Baltimore and their dour captain lounged on board the docked ship this morning and answered questions from sightseers at the Wilmington Marine Terminal. It was the first time in 10 harrowing days that they had had nothing more urgent to do.
MIDDLETOWN, Pa.--The people living near the 372-foot-tall cooling towers of the nuclear-powered electric plant on Three Mile Island had learned to coexist with the raucous sound of venting steam.

THE difference between Martin, Bogan and Armstrong, the old time black string band that was at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Saturday, and any white group playing a comparable repertory is an interesting difference indeed.

Signs are increasing that consumers, whose buying has fueled the economic recovery since the 1974 recession, have turned sharply pessimistic. Their changed outlook could signal an imminent economic slowdown, some economists warn.

Melissa F. Greene, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald A. Greene of Kettering, Ohio, was married yesterday to Donald F. Samuel, son of Howard D. Samuel, Deputy Under Secretary for International Affairs in the Labor Department, and Mrs. Samuel of Chevy Chase, Md.

President Carter's popularity, which had been declining in March, appears to have leveled off, but still more people disapprove than approve of his performance in office, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

ROBERT THOMPSON dug up some real novelties for his program of Baroque bassoon music Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, including sonatas for bassoon and continuo by G. Antonio Bertoli and Joseph Bodin de Boismortier;
Welcoming an elusive spring, with or without the day's touches of finery, 50,000 people turned out for the city's century-old Easter Parade on Fifth Avenue.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex. April 15 (AP) --George Gervin and Larry Kenon combined for 61 points today as the San Antonio Spurs routed the Philadelphia 76ers, 119-106, in the opening game of the National Basketball Association Eastern Conference four-of-sevensemifinal series.

BERKELEY, Calif., April 15--In an effort to promote its marijuana decriminalization initiative on the city's ballot Tuesday, a local political organization here is raffling "one kilogram of a wellknown leafy substance imported from Colombia."
BOSTON HE is at an age when many men who were once his athletic peers are dead or have long since retired from their sports. Still Johnny Kelley runs on.

KAMPALA, Uganda, April 15--The invasion of Uganda by the forces of President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania is a triumph for him personally and for Tanzania, and it has been greeted as welcome news over much of Africa and the world.

WHEN will the long climb in prices of basic raw materials taper off? According to the closely watched index of futures prices compiled by the Commodity Research Bureau, the rise in costs has been slowing for several weeks.

UST-NERA, U.S.S.R.--If you could figure out how much gold the Russians produced in this northeast Siberian mining town, you would probably be thrown into jail for spying. So secret are the figures that the posters outside the mine headquarters do not say how many tons were produced in January and February --they just say, "Plan fulfilled."

We are in favor of pooper-scoopers but we are also in favor of dogs. Manhattan was once the home of whistling swans and seals and mountain lions, and on spring days we remember this in our bones. Walking a dog, we feel occasionally that we are with a living ancestor, as ...

The French trimaran Kriter IV, which was trying to set a trans-Atlantic sailing record, sank yesterday but its five crewmen were rescued, a Coast Guard spokesman said today in New York City. The spokesman said the container ship Atlantic Song took the five Frenchmen off the stricken yacht this morning shortly before it were down in heavy seas in the North Atlantic
ESSEX JUNCTION, Vt., April 15 (AP)--One of the world's best known computer companies is tangled in a $1 million mixup in its credit union--because of a computer problem.
MADRID, April 15 (Reuters)--Tourists returning from Easter vacations in Spain faced long delays today as French air traffic controllers stepped up a job action, Spanish airport sources said.

New Jersey's largest state employees union plans to conduct walkouts of several hours' duration at 14 public institutions tomorrow to protest the state's offer of a 2.5 percent wage increase for this year.

FROM year to year, Ella Fitzgerald's performances remain much the same. One can count on a few ballads, some up tempo numbers and some scat pieces, including "Flying Home." The songs, when they are not the same from one year to the next, are interchangeable, and she sings with remarkable consistency.

Donald Kirk David, who had served as dean of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration and was one of the nation's leading business educators, died Friday at Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass. Mr. David, who lived in Osterville, Mass., was 83 years old.

To a former head of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, Bruce McM. Wright is "the best friend criminals ever had." To the City Bar Association, his performance as a Criminal Court judge has been "decidedly better than average." To civil-rights activists, he is, as one put it, "an exasperating ally."
INVESTORS is bank shares have been concerned for years that underlying values are not reflected in the market price of their holdings.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)--A Washington columnist says that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, sent an aide to China in 1971 in an effort to buy a nuclear bomb from the Peking Government.

JEKYLL ISLAND, Ga., April 15-- President Carter emerged this morning from the secluded villa where he has been vacationing and joined in a rousing, hand-clapping Easter service with some 200 black parishioners of the First African Baptist Church on nearby Sapelo Island.
KUWAIT--The banking community in this tiny sheikdom believes 1979 will be the year when the Kuwaiti dinar becomes the first oil-backed currency to play an international financial role.
Renewal of visas, not deportation, is the primary concern of many foreign players in the North American Soccer League after the strike by the players' association.

NEW confrontations loom between Congress and the White House over the legislative veto. That is a provision that allows Congress--at times both chambers and at times only one--to veto new regulations issued by various Federal agencies. Congress has contended that the provision is an important part of legislative oversight and has been adding it to new laws with increasing frequency.
DETROIT, April 15--Southeastern Michigan, long a leader in developing broad health-care services and benefits, is turning into a battleground over containing the resultant spiraling costs.

The New York City School Chancellor, Frank J. Macchiarola, and the union representing the striking school bus drivers may be nearing a settlement of the nineweek-old wildcat walkout, the participants say. But the issue of job security, although now viewed by the Board of Education as negotiable, remains a major sticking point.

CLEVELAND, Tenn., April 15 (AP)-- The state police said two persons were killed and at least 14 were injured today when 16 cars collided on a fog-shrouded section of interstate 75 about 30 miles northeast of Chattanooga.

PHOENIX, April 15 (AP)--The Phoenix Suns outscored the Portland Trail Blazers, 31-15, in the fourth quarter and went on to a 101-91 victory today. The Suns captured the firstround National Basketball Association playoff series, two games to one.

Every weekday morning, 19-year-old Glenice Pearson wakes up in his room on 110th Street near Lenox Avenue as dawn is breaking through the gray over Central Park. At just about the same time, Gloria Dudwick is waking up in her house on Sprain Valley Road in Scarsdale.

The credit markets, which have just come through a week-long slump that raised long-term Treasury bond yields to their highest levels in history, hope to get some definite information this week about whether the Federal Reserve is going to make money more difficult and expensive to borrow.
Margo Semas Henderson, a blues singer, died Friday of cancer at the Royal Marsden Hospital in London. She was 33 years old and lived in Manhattan.
Some bacteria have an internal "compass" that apparently aids navigation, scientists in New England have discovered.

IN "Homeland," a Modern Times Theater production at the New York Theater Ensemble, an innocent black maidservant visits America with her white South African employers and meets a suburban family's worldly black housekeeper, or as she prefers to call herself, a "household technician."
Maurice J. Cohn, a lawyer and real estate developer, died April 13 at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco after a long illness. He was 63 years old.
DETROIT, April 16 (AP)--Sales by auto makers in the United States fell slightly in the first 10 days of April, with only the General Motors Corporation reporting a gain.

Mayor Koch's criticism of a bail decision by Criminal Court Judge Bruce McM. Wright was called "highly inappropriate" yesterday by an official of the 25,000-member metropolitan council of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

CAHUITA, Costa Rica JUST ahead, stretching from the uplands to the shores of the Caribbean like a huge green tent, looms the rain forest. From the distance, it seems quiet and benign, but within its woody boundaries thousands of species of plants, mammals, birds and insects live precariously, fighting a constant struggle for food and light in one of the world's most complex ecosystems.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 16--An armed force of 100,000 men will be stationed around the country tomorrow as black and white Rhodesians start five days of voting to give this nation its first black-led Government.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16--Mayor Frank L. Rizzo and top police administrators keep this city's Police Department shielded from public scrutiny, according to witnesses who testified today before the United States Civil Rights Commission.
Dr. S. Zalman Yovely, a consultant on Jewish folk art, antique Hebrew books and manuscripts, died Saturday in Metropolitan Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, April 16--The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether transcripts of Henry A. Kissinger's telephone conversations, compiled by his secretaries while he was national security adviser and Secretary of State, are subject to disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act.

A NEW "guided missile" method of administering drugs shows promise in delivering powerful doses of anti cancer chemicals to specific targets in the body while leaving normal tissues largely untouched.

BOSTON NEW ENGLAND will finally have its own school of veterinary medicine this fall when the first class of 35 students, now being selected from among 500 applicants, are admitted to a new branch of Tufts University.

Money, everyone knows by now, is the mother's milk of politics. What is not so well known is how much of it is now required to run for Congress--and the extent to which politicians are now suckled by special interests. Hence the most important bill before Congress this year may be one labeled, with apt ceremony, ...

THE McGraw-Hill Publications Company, its eye on the golden al mond cookie in the sky, has exercised its option to acquire 49 percent of the American Industrial Report, a controlled-circulation trade publication that is distributed in China.

An Off Broadway play about a sorry homecoming, Sam Shepard's "Buried Child," won the Pulitzer Prize for drama yesterday. The prize came the day after the drama closed at the Theatre de Lys. where it had played 152 regular performances and five previews.
Most of the 156 offtrack betting parlors in New York City reopened yesterday after striking clerks ratified a new twoyear contract and returned to the betting windows.

TEL AVIV, April 16--Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel was criticized today for having suggested that, just as Sinai had to be given up to make peace with Egypt, the Golan Heights might have to be ceded some day in an effort to reach a peace accord with Syria.
MINEOLA, L.I., April 16--An agreement on a new lease that will keep the New York Islanders in the Nassau Coliseum for the next 30 years was announced today by county and Islander officials.

MONTREAL, April 16 (UPI)--Bill Lee allowed only one hit--a trapped fly that was ruled a single by one of the substitute umpires--over 8 2/3 innings and wound up with a two-hitter for his first National League victory today as the Montreal Expos defeated the Chicago Cubs, 2-0.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI)-- The State Department announced today that the United States would reopen its embassy in Uganda, ending a six-year freeze in relations between the two countries.

A decade-long study by Dr. William H. Masters and Virginia E. Johnson, the pioneering sex researchers, has found that the sexual problems of homosexuals, including the unfulfilled desire by some to function as heterosexuals, can in many cases be effectively treated in two weeks of intensive therapy.

The Occidental Petroleum Corporation yesterday reported first quarter net income of $87.9 million, or $1.11 a share, almost triple the restated $32.1 million, or 36 cents a share, it reported for the year-earlier period. It was the first major oil company to issue results for the quarter.

ESTELI, Nicaragua, April 16 (AP)-- Broken glass and spent cartridge cases littered the streets and blood-stained sidewalks of Esteli, and residents accused President Anastasio Somoza's army of atrocities during the weeklong fight to take the city from leftist guerrillas.

JACKSON, Miss., April 16 (AP)--The worst Pearl River flood in history continued to inundate Jackson today, sending water to the eaves of some homes in the suburbs and forcing officials to seal off the downtown area.

A leading archeology journal has charged that Syrian authorities are trying to suppress the findings of scholars who are deciphering the huge cache of inscribed clay tablets discovered amid the ruins of the 4,500-year-old Kingdom of Ebla.

ARABA EL MADFUNA, Egypt-- Om Seti may or may not have lived 3,200 years ago as a temple waif in the 19th Dynasty under Seti I and Ramses II. It is certain, however, that the elderly Englishwoman feels at home only among the renowned pharaonic ruins that she began seeking as a child.

For Edward F. Gibbons, the chairman and chief executive officer of the F.W. Woolworth Company, 1979 was supposed to be a year of celebration. The big chain-store corporation, the country's fourth-largest retailer and long a household name, reported a 52 percent rise in profits last year, celebrated its hundredth anniversary in February and was looking forward to further progress in the forthcoming months.

It sounds like the long-rumored city apocalypse, but the case of the Tree of Life versus the Urban Development Corporation is actually a struggle for a lively corner in Harlem, where "the vibrations are very heavy," to quote the identical enthusiasms of Brother Ernest and Dr. Moore.
Beneath a spray of pale pink blossoms, a Japanese industrialist yesterday gave the city 150 flowering cherry trees and a promise of continuing friendship between his country and the United States.
RIDGEWOOD, N.J., April 16 (UPI)-- Joe King, a New York sportswriter for nearly 40 years, died here Monday. He was 70 years old.

Two Long Island men were arrested the other day, taken to a courtroom in handcuffs and released pending a trial that could lead to 15 days in jail or a $250 fine. The charge: selling Tide, Fab and Cheer in their grocery stores.

CHICAGO, April 16--Jane M. Byrne, in being sworn in tonight as the 42d Mayor of Chicago, paid ample homage to her mentor, the late Mayor Richard J. Daley, then made an acknowledgment that might well have been considered heresy during his 22-year reign at the helm of the city's powerful Democratic machine.
SAPELO ISLAND, Ga., April 16 (UPI)--The President and Mrs. Carter have filed for an automatic 60-day extension on their income tax returns for 1978, a White House spokesman said today.

KAMPALA, Uganda, April 16--This morning a woman strolled down Parliament Avenue, where the stores are gutted, carrying a bright red parasol in one hand and a baby swaddled in lace in the other. She passed a group of Tanzanian soldiers lounging on a street ...
COSTA MESA, Calif., April 16 (AP)-- Herbert Stanley Dunn, who played the original Cisco Kid in silent pictures from 1913 to 1915, died of a stroke Saturday. He was 87 years old.
A rapid shrinkage in the number of companies in the food industry may account at least in part for the steady upward march of food prices, according to the authors of a report released today.

BERT LUCARELLI'S oboe recital Sunday night at the 92d Street Young Men's-Young Women's Hebrew Association seemed decidedly more attractive after the intermission than before it, and this was both because of the music and how he played it.

Having heard that Toronto was becoming one of the continent's noblest cities, we flew from New York to investigate. New Yorkers jealous of their city's reputation and concerned about challenges to its stature have little to worry about.
WASHINGTON, April 16--The United State Supreme Court let stand today without comment disbarment orders against two former Brooklyn Congressmen.

A top editor of The New York Post, testifying on pictures The Post published of David Berkowitz asleep in a hospital prison ward, said yesterday that he did not know at the time that a freelance writer to whom The Post paid a total of $13,000 was in turn allegedly paying a source inside the ward.

If one could arrange a tournament for teams from commuter railroads throughout North America, the New Haven representatives would probably be strong favorites. The standard is very high, as witness the diagramed deal, despite the high speed of play and the confusion generated by "ghoulie" dealing, in which the cards are distributed in bunches without shuffling.
"A simpie dinner for two in a Greenwich Village restaurant costs me $35," said a New York bachelor. "That's more than 30 percent over a year or so ago. Unfortunately, my salary hasn't kept pace."
WASHINGTON, April 16--Marcus B. Finnegan, an internationally recognized expert in patent law and licensing, died of cancer Friday in Houston. He was 51 years old.

Is bigness badness? If asked of businessmen about business, the answer is reflexively "no." Yet when asked of the same businessmen about government, the answer, without any trace of irony, is "of course." Big government is wasteful, unresponsive, mired in red tape.

BOSTON, April 16--There are steeper hills, but only one has been named Heartbreak. Someday it might be renamed after William H. Rodgers. Widening his lead on Heartbreak's back slope, Rodgers won his second consecutive Boston Marathon today, and his third in the last five years.

WASHINGTON, April 16--The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether certain types of damage awards to injured workers, intended to compensate for lost income, ought to be scaled down to reflect the portion that Federal and state income taxes would have taken out of the workers' earnings.

ROME, April 16--Officials in the Italian judiciary said today that substantial new evidence had been found that implicated 12 people in the kidnapping and murder of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro last year.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 16--The resignation of Foreign Minister Karim Sanjabi yesterday and the temporary departure from Teheran of a popular religious leader appear to be a last-ditch effort to salvage the provisional Government of Iran and lay the groundwork for a crackdown on the Islamic councils of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

MIME theater speaks a universal language, but sometimes, to a laggard onlooker who is not willing to work at it, it is easy to lose the thread of the conversation. This problem has been remedied in the latest production of the Richard Morse Mime Theater, a piece called "What the Devil!" that incorporates beautiful mime with some dialogue, a narration and dance.
WASHINGTON, April 16--In the last year or so, the states have vastly increased their help to the distressed communities, urban and rural, that they once were accused of neglecting.
Merrill Lynch Ready Assets, a money market fund, has become the largest American mutual fund ever, reflecting the shift of investors away from stocks toward more conservative types of investments.

THE word "cure" is one that doctors seldom use. Although as students they may have great hopes of learning to apply medicine's newest advances to cure diseases they later find in their practices that they can actually eradicate just a tiny fraction of the thousands of human ailments.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y. April 16--The Hooker Chemical and Plastics Corporation plant here regularly released mercury, chlorine, phosphorous-based gases and persistent carcinogenic pesticides ...

These are not easy times for Phil Chenier, who once was one of the National Basketball Association's premier guards. Chenier has had to swallow his pride as he sits on the Washington Bullets' bench, waiting for Coach Dick Motta to find an opportunity to send him into a game.

A 25-year-old man was in serious condition yesterday in Beekman Downtown Hospital after sliding down a building drainpipe to escape two gunmen in a holdup of the Sung Que Athletic Club, at 177 Canal Street, on Sunday. The injured man, James Tong, lost his grip on the drainpipe and slipped down four stories.

EVEN though the Energy Department is entangled in President Carter's controversial proposal to tax any "windfall" profits on oil, it has been scathingly accused of failing to play an active role in determining what effects national tax policy has on energy matters.

THE Canby Singers, conducted by Edward Tatnall Canby, celebrated Easter Day on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall with an a capella program titled "The Sons of David"--for the most part, music about King Saul and his son Jonathan, King David and his son Absalom, and Christ, the new Testament's "Son of David."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass.--In 1959, C. P. Snow published "The Two Cultures and the Scientific Revolution." As he saw it, the scientists did their thing, complicated and inhumane, getting better at it all the time, while the humanists went their blissful, harmless, peaceful way, knowing little of science. Both cultures sought truth, but in their own terms.

The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation reported yesterday that its net operating income had risen more than 18 percent in the first quarter of this year compared with the corresponding period a year earlier.

WHEN a man has a heart attack in a drama called "Transplant," there can hardly be any doubt about where the script is heading. One problem with tonight's presentation on CBSTV, at 9 o'clock, is that the time spent getting there seems interminable.

John Biggs Jr., Senior Judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia, died Sunday at the Wilmington Medical Center in Wilmington, Del., after a heart attack. He was 83 years old and lived at Wooddale, an estate near Wilmington.

A. Einstein showed that any material substance moving at the speed of light, be it atom, man or star would have an infinite mass. Even a speeds much less than that of light rapidly moving atomic particles increase enormously in mass.

Who said the Yankees don't take the Mayor's Trophy game seriously? That idea emerged recently when Sparky Lyle suggested in his book that Graig Netties purposely threw away a ball in last year's exhibition with the Mets in an attempt to end the game.

Richie Phillips, the Philadelphia lawyer who is ringmaster of the major league umpires in their strike for more money, looks like an umpire, dresses like an umpire and talks like a Philadelphia lawyer. If umpires were as punctual as he, they wouldn't have jobs to be unhappy about.

FROM the first song on her program at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, which closed with a leap to a breathtaking high pia nissimo, Montserrat Caballe made it clear that this was to be a night to send the vocalism enthusiasts straight to heaven.

The Federal Department of Energy announced a campaign yesterday to investigate and prosecute gasoline price-gouging nationwide, beginning with a steppedup effort to audit the books of suspicious service stations in the New York City area, where prices are among the highest in the nation.
AMERICAN Ballet Theater opened its spring season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House with a good mix of favorites and two works new to New York.

WASHINGTON, April 16--Adm. Stansfield Turner, the Director of Central Intelligence, has told the Senate that it will take until 1984 for the United States to restore fully the intelligence capability for monitoring Soviet missile tests and development that was lost with the shutdown of two electronic listening posts in Iran, according to Congressional sources.
Archbishop Molloy won the team title, in the Athletic Association of Private Schools track and field championships yesterday at Randalls Island.

Howard Davis Jr., a 23-year-old millionaire bachelor from Hempstead, L.I., will again practice the trade he says he hates Friday night when he carries his unblemished professional lightweight record into the ring at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum against Giancarlo Usai, the lightweight champion of Italy.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI)-- President Carter today asked that more than 36 million acres of untrampled countryside owned by the Government be opened for logging and oil,gas and mineral exploration.

GREENSBURG, Ind., April 14--"It was like being locked in a closet for 14 years--locked in and forgotten," Pfc. Robert Russell Garwood said, crushing the Marlboro he had just smoked down to the filter and lighting the next of a chain.

ALBANY, April 16--Criticizing what he called the "immorality and arrogance" of the Legislature, a lawyer for 40 "property poor" school districts asked a State Supreme Court justice today to enjoin the state from implementing its new budget. The lawyer, Robert E. Sapir, said the budget did not comply with a court decision that education spending be equalized throughout the state.

UNIONDALE, L.I., April 16--The New York Islanders, with Mike Bossy scoring three goals, routed the Chicago Black Hawks, 6-2, in the opener tonight of their four-of-seven-game Stanley Cup quarterfinal series in the Nassau Coliseum.

BOSTON, April 16--McAvoy Layne wanted to accomplish two things in today's marathon: to finish in less than three hours and to "go out in style." This was his sixth and final marathon performance, said Layne, who dressed for the occasion of his retirement in a tuxedo, complete with pleated shirt and satin bow-tie.

Robert Hinkley is the comptroller for Capitol Service Stations, whose Texaco station is on the corner of 37th Street and First Avenue in Manhattan. In the last few weeks, the posted price for premium gasoline in that station--99.9 cents a gallon--has been the highest, and probably the most highly publicized, price in Manhattan.

PRETORIA, South Africa, April 15-- When Solomon Mahlangu, a 22-year-old black convicted of complicity in a murder, went to the gallows here this month, South Africa was enveloped anew in controversy over its policies toward blacks, in particular its record as one of the most frequent practitioners of legal execution.

WATERBURY, Conn., April 16-- Thieves shot three security guards to death before dawn today by firing rifles through the windows of an armored-car depot, and then fled with an estimated $1.8 million in currency, coins, checks, jewelry and food stamps.
Arthur Peck has been working in the office-products field during his entire business career--at the McGraw-Edison Company, at the Dictaphone Corporation and, for the last seven years, at a ...

WASHINGTON, April 16--The senior nuclear safety expert of the Tennessee Valley Authority said today that almost 11 months before the March 28 accident at the Three Mile Island power plant, he warned the manufacturer of the reactor that there was a possibility that a similar accident could occur.

CINCINNATI, April 16 (AP)--Five persons were killed and a sixth was critically injured today when a car went out of control and smashed into a guard rail and a tunnel abutment, the police said. "The car apparently lost control due to the high speed," estimated by the police at 100 miles an hour, said Bill Ries, an officer. Names of the victims were not immediately released.

THERE is one stretch of strong and effective writing in "G.R. Point," a play about American soldiers in the Vietnam War. It comes at the end of the first act and it portrays the pathology of battle fatigue in two men who have come out of a fire fight.

Shearson Hayden Stone, a leading investment firm servicing United States and foreign securities and commodities markets, yesterday reported a net income of $3.6 million, or 75 cents a share, for the third fiscal quarter ended March 31, more than triple the $1.1 million, or 25 cents a share, reported in the comparable three months last year.

TOKYO, April 16--The Bank of Japan, the country's central bank, decided today to raise its official discount rate for the first time in nearly five and a half years in an attempt to thwart a renewed inflationary surge that could cripple the Japanese economy.

TRENTON, April 16--New Jersey's two United State Senators announced today they had agreed on four candidates for Federal judgeships and had submitted the names to the White House. Included on the list is Anne Elise Thompson, the Mercer County Prosecutor, who, if appointed, would be the first woman and the first black to sit on the Federal bench in New Jersey.

Consumer resistance to mortgage rates that are approaching 11 percent appears to be weakening, Sharon Stieber, Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation economist, said yesterday after analyzing the Government agency's latest purchase of home mortgages.

Alfred Brittain 3d, the chairman of the Bankers Trust Company, recently invited the treasurer of a multinational corporation to lunch, hoping to snare at least a small piece of the company's banking business. He was surprised to learn his bank already had a substantial piece.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, April 16 (Reuters)--Gunmen believed to be Basque guerrillas today shot and seriously wounded a provincial secretary of the right-wing Popular Alliance Party, police sources said. The secretary, Gerardo Gomez Chaus, was shot five times-- twice in the head--as he was leaving home for work. The Basque separatist guerrilla group E.T.A. has claimed responsibility for killing 28 persons in Spain this year.

The difficulty of getting SALT II ratified in the Senate is becoming clearer every day. Unfortunately, the issues involved are not. The most important debate of the Carter Administration is in danger of bogging down, before it officially opens, in technicalities, exaggerated fears and irrelevancies.

VENICE--As a genteel girl from a rich and prominent New York family, Peggy Guggenheim set out for Europe to have an interesting life. Now, frail at 80 years old, she lives alone in a halffinished Venetian palazzo on the Grand...

Zoltan Merszei, who resigned in February as chairman of the Dow Chemical Company, has been hired for a top position at another major multinational corporation. The Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced yesteday that Mr. Merszei had been appointed its vice chairman.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 16--An explosive charge went off early today in front of the John F. Kennedy American Center, causing structual damage but no casualties. A second charge failed to go off. The explosion was believed to be another protest against the American-sponsored Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty.

EVERY 90 minutes a large Soviet spaceship completes a circuit of earth, as it has since September 1977, and as it probably will for months to come. It is a home away from earth for two astronauts, and a place to work. It represents the most ambitious effort to date to understand what it is like to live and work in space for long periods of time.
TEL AVIV, Tuesday, April 17--Six Arab guerrillas and an Israeli soldier were killed last night in a clash on the Lebanese border, the military command here announced this morning.

The strident and exaggerated criticism of Judge Brace Wright's recent bail decision has now been matched by his responses--and by heated comments from almost everyone else. There can yet be a constructive result; the flare-up could teach the public something about the principles of bail. To understand them is to recognize that the judge's original ruling in New York City's Criminal Court might have been defensible. But understanding can't begin until everyone cools down.

Complaints of corruption and serious misconduct against New York City police officers increased 17 percent during the first three months of this year compared to the same period in 1978, according to a Police Department report submitted yesterday to Commissioner Robert J. McGuire.

NO tenor has ever thanked Rimsky-Korsakov for the role of the Astrologer in "Le Coq d'Or." It is short but it lies almost exclusively in the uppermost part of the voice, eventually ascending to E above high C. The composer suggested that it be sung by a "tenor-altino," whatever he may have meant by that.

WASHINGTON, April 16--The Carter Administration, fearing a nuclear arms race on the Indian subcontinent, has offered to sell Pakistan fighter planes and to give help on nuclear power if it agrees to restrictions against the production of nuclear weapons, Government officials said today.

WILSON COLLEGE in Chambersburg, Pa., a high-quality liberal arts college for women on a rustic 300-acre campus, will cease operations on June 30. Over spirited protests by some students, alumnae and friends who have launched a "Save Wilson" drive, the trustees say that even though the college is not bankrupt its prospects for survival are dim at a time of rising inflation and declining enrollment.

Led by an armed passer-by, a group of outraged Queens citizens chased and captured a holdup suspect yesterday afternoon, moments after he allegedly shot and critically wounded a young woman on her way to make a bank deposit at a busy Woodside intersection.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16--Under pressure from the Carter Administration, the Scott Paper Company announced today that it would roll back prices on certain items and defer or modify some planned price increases.

PITTSBURGH, April 16--The Westinghouse Electric Corporation agreed in principle today to settle a uraniumsupply lawsuit brought by the Virginia Electric and Power Company. Westinghouse estimated that the settlement would cost it $200 million. But the utility said it would receive $361 million in cash and uranium.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Company reported yesterday a 47.8 percent gain in first-quarter earnings.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16--The Rangers did everything right tonight in the first game of the quarterfinal series against the Philadelphia Flyers--until the last 5 minutes. In that time, Bill Barber scored for Philadelphia to send ...

ATLANTA, April 16--A Justice Department review of the investigation of Bert Lance is complete, and prosecutors have been given permission to seek indictments, but it may be more than a month before a Federal grand jury here takes action, sources familiar with the case said today.

AMHERST, Mass., April 16 (AP)-- Dr. Julian H. Gibbs, a Brown University chemistry professor, has been named president of Amherst College effective July 1. He succeeds John William Ward, who announced last November he would resign this July.

WASHINGTON, April 16--Farmers intend, as of today, to increase their soybean plantings by 7 percent and to reduce the amount of corn they will soon plant by only 1 percent, according to the Agiculture Department.

WASHINGTON, April 16--A Civil Aeronautics Board judge today urged the approval of a proposed merger between Continental Air Lines and Western Airlines providing they keep their promise to cut fares after the consolidation.

LA JOLLA, Calif., April 17 (AP) S. William Halperin, author and retired University of Chicago professor, has died at his home in La Jolla, Calif. He was 74 years old.

CHOREOGRAPHERS often base ballets on famous literary works, and one can understand why. Literary plots provide choreographers with ready-made narratives, and the familiarity of those plots makes it easy for audiences to follow the choreographic action.
MONTREAL, April 18 The script that has provided the major theme for the dramas staged by the Mets and the Expos this season continued unchanged today as Montreal beat New York again by one run.

HARTFORD, April 18 The predawn attack on the Purolator Security Inc. branch in Waterbury on Monday used a new tactic that the armored-car industry, which transports hundreds of billions of dollars a year in cash, is not prepared to meet, industry sources said today.
MOSCOW, April 18 For a time this afternoon exactly 39 seconds it seemed as if the United States team was on its way to its first victory at the world hockey championship here.

BERKELEY, Calif., April 18 Ballot initiatives that call for the withdrawal of an estimated $10 million in city funds from banks that make loans to South Africa and require the Berkeley Police Department to make enforcement of state marijuana laws its "lowest priority" passed by substantial margins in the municipal election here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (Reuters) United States officials are looking for Eschel M. Rhoodie, the central figure in the South African bribery scandal, to ask him about alleged payments to American politicians, the Justice Department said today.

WASHINGTON, April 18 King and Spalding, the Atlanta law firm headed by Charles Kirbo, the President's closest adviser and trustee (and the firm soon to be rejoined by Attorney General Griffin Bell) has announced plans to open a Washington, D.C., office.

WASHINGTON, April 18 Following are excerpts from opinions by the Supreme Court in the case of Anthony Herbert v. Barry Lando and the Columbia Broadcasting System Inc. Associate Justice Byron R. White wrote the majority opinion.

WITH the arrival of spring stirring wanderlust and other seasonal urges, it's time to cock an ear at car stereo once again. Shaking their heads at their own findings, market researchers report that, for the last two years, car stereo has been the fastest-growing segment of the audio industry.
The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it was withdrawing the surcharge on silicon steel products that it imposed in March and April.

TORONTO, April 18 Edper Equities Ltd., an investment arm of the Bronfman family, today reopened its bid to take over Brascan Ltd., which itself is embroiled in a proposed takeover of the F.W. Woolworth Company.

A major reorganization of public mental-health services in the Bronx was announced yesterday. The state's Bronx Psychiatric Center received a new director and deputy director and is to undergo a $13.4 million renovation, while 60 new acute-care psychiatric beds will be added at three other hospitals.
Yields on medium-grade utility bonds climbed yesterday to 11 percent, their highest level in three and a half years.

Governor Carey told a television audience last night that the state needed "games of chance" to attract conventions that would otherwise go to New Jersey.

SEATTLE, April 18 The Liu Lin Hai, the first Chinese merchant ship to sail into a United States port in 30 years, docked here today while a Navy band played "Jesus Christ Superstar" from the rock opera and political figures huddled in a chilly wind waiting to label the occasion as historic.

The recently repositioned Diners Club International is moving its account to Wells, Rich, Greene, according to James M. Stetler, executive vice president, marketing. The advertiser says the total marketing budget is $12 million.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 18 (AP) Fourteen persons were treated for injuries suffered when two buses collided at the morning rush hour today on the Missouri River bridge linking the downtown area with North Kansas City.
LONDON, April 18 After a bloodless beginning, the British election campaign has begun to generate some passion in the last 48 hours.

WHEN trying to provide a private garden retreat, whether in a suburban yard or on a city terrace, the first plant that comes to mind for a snug screen is privet. As ordinary and unimaginative as privet may be, it does the job well.

THE Composers' Forum opened a six-concert Spring Festival Tuesday night at the Paula Cooper Gallery in SoHo. The series is divided into three concerts of combined video-art and music and three of new chamber music.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) First-quarter passenger traffic on United States scheduled airlines increased 18.6 percent over the same period last year, the Air Transport Association reported today. Traffic in March was up 20 percent over March 1978, the association said.

Abraham Albert Desser, a labor organizer in the Depression who later became a Federal mediator seeking peace in major industrial disputes, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. Mr. Desser, who lived at 150 West End Avenue, would have been 77 years old May 31.

Mayor Koch and his fiscal advisers have discovered that there is more money for next year's budget than they had expected, raising the possibility that they can save 4,000 jobs. The jobs are now being paid for by Federal funds that will be cut off in the fall.

The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York yesterday issued an eightpage booklet strongly criticizing some of the nation's most popular television programs and movies as well as some best-selling music as morally objectionable.

IF any group has swept a fresh breeze--make that a gust of exhilaration--into the dance season it is the Paul Taylor Dance Company, which will be appearing at the City Center 55th Street Dance Theater through April 29.

IT was pure man-bites-dog on the economic news front this week when the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, G. William Miller, parried the pressure from the Secretary of the Treasury, W. Michael Blumenthal, to raise interest rates and tighten monetary policy to slow down inflation.
Lou Rossini was dismissed as head basketball coach at St. Francis College yesterday after four years at the Brooklyn school. No successor has been named, but the school is accepting applications.

CAIRO, April 19--Egyptians voted on the peace treaty with Israel today in a referendum called by President Anwar el-Sadat to demonstrate to Arab critics that the treaty has solid support in his country.

HAVING stubbed his toe with two expensive films in a row, "At Long Last Love" and "Nickelodeon," Peter Bogdanovich took a year off and then decided that his next pro duction would be more modest financially. It turned out to be "Saint Jack," which opens in New York next Friday.

HIGHLAND, Ind., April 18--A controversy has developed in this conservative and normally placid city of 26,000 people just outside Chicago as a result of a surprise raid in which 50 police officers, using German shepherds and Doberman pinschers, conducted a room-by-room search for drugs at the city's junior and senior high schools.

Nassau County sold $20 million of general Purpose bids yesterday, but it rejected bids for $16.6 million of sewer bonds because the low bid was submitted incorrectly. The issue was rescheduled for sale Monday.

PITTSBURGH, April 19--The Aluminum Company of America reported at its annual meeting today a 136.9 percent rise in first-quarter profits to $127.7 million, or $3.62 a share, from $53.9 million, or $1.53 a share, in the first quarter of 1978. WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP)-- China has canceled another order for United States wheat, stirring conjecture that it may be running into storage or payment problems, an Agriculture Department report indicated today. This cancellation involved 106,626 metric tons of wheat. Earlier this week China had canceled an order for 118,374 metric tons, and last month it canceled an order for 300,000 metric tons (of 2,205 pounds each).
Two of the nation's largest railroads reported yesterday sharply higher profits for the first quarter, despite increased weather-related expenses in the period.

Howard K. Smith yesterday posted notice of his resignation on the bulletin board of the ABC News office in Washington because, he said, he felt that his role as commentator on the nightly news show was being eliminated and that he would be left without a real function.

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 3.3 million shares in the month ended April 12 to a new high of 43.2 million shares. The previous high was 42.9 million shares on May 15, 1978. Tne short interest for the year-earlier level totaled 40.1 million shares.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP)--The State Department criticized the Polish Government today for imposing a $350 fee on foreign journalists assigned to cover the visit of Pope John Paul II in June. A spokesman, Hodding Carter 3d, called the fee "excesssive".

HARRISBURG, Pa., April 19 (AP)-- Levels of radioactive iodine leaking from the disabled Three Mile Island nuclear power plant have dropped, and a new filtering system is being employed to stop further releases, Federal officials said today.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., April 19-- Sapped of revenue by offtrack betting and hurt at the gate by dwindling tourism, Monticello Raceway began its 22d season tonight with hopes of coming up with a "saver," the way many racetrack bettors get "saver" tickets as backups in case their first choice fails.

ELMSFORD, N.Y.--It now takes three times longer, on the average, to get governmental approval of proposals for new housing than it takes to build the housing itself, says Robert F. Weinberg, chairman of the Robert Martin Company. And for every three projects proposed, two ultimately fail to win approval at all.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 19 (AP)-- Gov. Robert Graham and his Cabinet will hear arguments tomorrow on whether John Spenkelink, a convicted murderer, should be executed in the electric chair. Mr. Spenkelink, one of 130 persons sentenced to death in Florida, could become the first person executed in the state since 1964 and the first in the nation to be unwillingly executed since 1967.

WHITE PLAINS, April 19--The eightweek strike by dairy workers has been prolonged, in part, because out-of-state milk deliveries keep dairy counters filled, a State Senate committee was told yesterday. As a result, one dairy industry official said, public pressure for a settlemeet is at a minimum.
ROME, April 19 (Reuters)--Construction on Rome's first mosque has been halted by authorities pending an inquiry into complaints that the $35 million project violates environment protection laws.

RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 19 --Calm, cool and relaxing. These were the words used by several golfers to describe the Tournament of Champions held here one week after Fuzzy Zoeller won a three-way, two-hole playoff to capture the Masters championship.

CHICAGO, April 19--Mayor Jane M. Byrne has named Patrick V. Murphy, former New York City Police Commissioner, as her top choice for chief of this city's 13,000-member police force.

If Elmville could just get more people, more homes and shops, more industry, the conviction was, everyone would be that much happier.

THE General Motors Building can boast of at least two well-known ad agencies, Wells, Rich, Greene, and Leber Katz Partners. It also has Parkson Advertising and that's what this item is all about. Here we have a little-known $75 million agency that is about to go public, not in the sense of selling shares, but rather opening its doors to other clients than the J.B. Williams Company and Nabisco.

Frank Taveras, the 28-years-old shortstop of the Pittsburgh Pirates who stole 118 bases in the last two seasons, was acquired by the New York Mets yesterday in a trade for Tim Foli, another 28-year-old infielder, and Greg Field, a minor league pitcher.

Eastern Orthodox Christians, observing a liturgical calendar that differs from the one followed by Western churches, prepare to celebrate Easter this weekend with rites and festivities designed to awaken the spirit and the senses.
