Credit demand continued to show considerable strength in the week ended April 18, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
MANILA, April 19--The question seemed innocuous enough: Which Filipino do you admire most? Panorama The Manila Bulletin's Sunday magazine asked its college readers to reply, and 72 did so.

SALT LAKE CITY, April 19--President Eisenhower reportedly told the Atomic Energy Commission in 1953 to keep the public "confused" with its explanations of the kind of explosions that were causing radioactive fallout, according to recently declassified commission records, released today.

LOS ANGELES, April 19--Johnny Carson, host of "The Tonight Show," one of television's most successful and profitable programs, has told the National Broadcasting Company that he plans to leave the show on Sept. 30, after 17 years.

WASHINGTON, April 19--A sharp rift seems to have developed between G. William Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and the senior economic policy makers of the Carter Administration over the conduct of economic policy.

"THAT CHAMPIONSHIP SEASON," Jason Miller's play about four basketball players and their old coach, will be revived on Broadway next season. Moreover, it will be done with black actors, although not a line in the script will be changed.

PARIS, April 19--The campaign for the June elections for the European Parliament has opened formally in France with a declaration by President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, made in terms that added fuel to the raging French political feud, that it has nothing to do with domestic politics.

WASHINGTON, April 19--Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin of the Soviet Union met today on the nearly completed treaty limiting strategic arms and there were signs that plans would be announced next week for a meeting between President Carter and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader.
The Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday that its amateur color film will be available to tourists visiting China beginning this June.
Copper futures led other metals lower yesterday after the Government reported an unexpectedly slow economic growth rate for the first quarter of the year.
JEKYLL ISLAND, Ga., April 19-- President Carter intends to visit South Korea immediately after the economic summit meeting in Tokyo in June, the White House Press Office announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 19--The courts and the press in this country are fussing with one another again about the conflict in the Constitution between the right to a fair trial and the freedom of the press. WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP)-- Thirty-five students were injured, two critically, today when a predawn fire routed hundreds of residents from a highrise dormitory at George Washington University.

Johnny Carson is believed to be a profit center unto himself at the broadcasting subsidiary of the RCA Corporation. According to industry analysts "The Tonight Show" is estimated to account for 17 percent, or $23 million, of the pretax profits of the National Broadcasting Company. Last year NBC earned $122.1 million.

Standard Poor's lowered its ratings on the senior debt of the Chrysler Corporation yesterday to BB from BBB- and also reduced its rating of the auto maker's preferred stock to B from BB-.

Two workmen from Italy are installing a series of colorful mosaics in St. Paul's Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Hempstead, L.I., that are designed to become the most authentic examples of the Byzantine art style in any church in the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 19--The United States is forming contingency plans to establish a force of 100,000 troops, including 40,000 combat soldiers, for use in defense of American interests in sensitive areas, according to qualified Pentagon sources.
Elderly people who are frail will live in apartments with financial help from the state and with care by private sponsors under a pilot program that was presented yesterday in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, April 19--The National Transportation Safety Board tentatively decided today that the main cause of the midair collision in San Diego last fall was the failure of the airliner crew to keep the small plane in view and to inform controllers when they had lost visual contact.

KINONI, Uganda, April 20 A Tanzanian soldier sat in the sun sewing buttons on a uniform. Another danced to rock music broadcast from Kenya over a Panasonic radio he said he had brought all the way from Dar es Salaam. Others chewed sugar cane, drank tea and posed for photographs in front of rifles and machine guns in a shaded camp that looked more like a picnic ground than a frontline.

The Dow Chemical Company was charged in a $12 million civil antitrust suit yesterday with monopolizing the market for polyethylene foam plank and using "predatory pricing-cutting" and other tactics to squelch competition.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20. With the Mets liberally helping their rival's cause with poor control pitching and errant fielding, the Phillies coasted to an 8-0 victory tonight in the opener of a three-game series. It was the Mets' fifth straight loss.

WASHINGTON, April 20 The European Common Market has warned the United States that a new international trade agreement may be jeopardized by Congressional interpretation of a key concession made by American trade negotiators in Geneva.
SEOUL, South Korea, April 20 (AP) -- The national police say they have arrested seven South Koreans suspected of spying for North Korea and trying to reactivate an underground Communist Party.
WASHINGTON, April 20 The Council on Wage and Price Stability said today that proposed pollution controls on diesel engines were too stringent and too expensive.

COTTONWOOD POINT, Mo., April 20 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency said today that an estimated 63,000 gallons of the chemical styrene leaked into the Mississippi River here after several barges hit a bridge.

LAGOS, Nigeria The oil business is booming here once again, so much so that the Government's decision to add surcharges of nearly $4 over the OPEC cartel price has met with widespread approval from Nigerians here. "Better late than never," wrote Dr. Olu Akinmoladun, chief energy correspondent for the respected Business Times newspaper here.

AIUN, Western Sahara, April 15 Three and a half years after King Hassan's spectacular unarmed march forced colonial Spain out of the Western Sahara, a steadily growing Moroccan expeditionary force finds itself bogged down in a costly and seemingly unwinnable war against guerrillas who have struck even into southern Morocco.

BANGKOK, Thailand, April 20 Refugee officials and diplomats here say they fear that about 1,800 Cambodian refugees may have been forcibly returned to Cambodia by Thai authorities. The officials believe that refugees who are returned face almost certain execution.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, April 20 (AP) Authorities rescued a disabled fishing launch off the south coast near the Haitian border this week, found two pistols, three rifles and 600 rounds of ammunition, and arrested the five men aboard, the military said.

The Federal Aviation Administration ordered yesterday that stringent visual and ultrasonic inspections be made of the tail rotors on American commercial helicopters of the type involved in the New York Airways craft that crashed here Wednesday evening.

Smith today hailed as "manna from heaven" a South African proposal for a new grouping of nations in southern Africa that has been interpreted by some officials here as opening the way for much broader South African support of the Salisbury Government.

BOSTON, April 20 (AP) Several hundred frustrated gate crashers broke store windows and assaulted policemen on horseback last night after they were denied admittance to a rock concert at a downtown theater, the police said.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) Federal financial agencies are taking steps to make it easier for families to borrow money to rehabilitate their homes or to buy cooperative apartments.

TEL AVIV, April 20 In recent weeks the Israeli pound has been experiencing its steepest fall since it was floated in October 1977 to find its own level. This month the barrier of 22 pounds to the dollar was broken, and today it closed at 22.20 to the dollar.

HARRISBURG, Pa., April 20 (AP) Temperatures in the Three Mite Island reactor dropped below the boiling point for the first time since the nation's worst nuclear accident occurred on March 28, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 20 Secretary General Kurt Waldheim warned today that continued obstruction of United Nations peacekeeping activities in southern Lebanon could have disastrous consequences for Lebanon and for the Middle East in general.

A private group of monitors reported this week that it was "favorably impressed" with the first 15 months of President Carter's year-round job program for disadvantaged young people in New York City. ALBANY, April 20 Representatives of the New York State correction officers' union continued their talks tonight with state officials and mediators in effort to settle a statewide strike as additional National Guardsmen were moved in to help staff most of the state's prisons.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 20 (AP) A week-long standoff ended today when the United States Auto Club notified six of the rival Championship Auto Racing Teams that their entries for the May 27 Indianapolis 500 had been rejected because they were "not in good standing with USAC."

ROME, April 20 A terrorist bomb seriously damaged the Palace of the Senators on the Capitoline Hill today. The building, which serves as Rome's city hall, was designed by Michelangelo and is a monument to the nation's cultural heritage.

Members of the Newspaper Guild unit at The New York Times voted overwhelmingly yesterday to begin a series of actions on May 3 to achieve a contract. "such action to culminate, if necessary, in a strike." The resolution was approved by a vote of 530 to 90.

ROME, April 20 Amid political unrest, strikes, inflation and the relentless onslaught of terrorism, Italians these days have found a welcome diversion in the predicament of a Government member whom a former woman aide is publicly accusing of "sexual blackmail."

CAIRO, April 20 The Government announced today that Egypt's voters had overwhelming approved President Anwar el-Sadat's peace treaty with Israel.
BOSTON, April 20 (AP) Carl Yastrzemski drove in three runs with his 386th career homer, a single and a double to power the Boston Red Sox to a 9-2 victory today over the Kansas City Royals.
RICHMOND, April 20 An unmarried woman is not morally unfit to practice law merely because she lives with a man who is not her husband, the Virginia Supreme Court ruled unanimously today.

The Koch administration said yesterday that it would propose a $13 billion budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1. An established sportswear producer has developed a plan to allow retailers to get into the growing field of petite sportswear by providing an instant department at a price that will probably not affect the bottom line.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 Darryl Dawkins, in an awesome display of scoring and rebounding in the final quarter tonight, paved the way for the Philadelphia 76ers' 123-115 playoff victory over the San Antonio Spurs at the Spectrum.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) United Airlines and striking mechanics will resume contract talks Monday in Denver in an attempt to end a three-week strike that has grounded the nation's largest air carrier, officials said today.

An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday said incorrectly that Governor Carey had appointed Judge Herbert B. Evans as statewide court administrator. Judge Evans was appointed by Lawrence H. Cooke, Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals.
MOSCOW, April 20 The United States fell into a tie for last place in the relegation pool of the world hockey championships tonight when it lost to West Germany, 6-3. The American team has yet to win.

The Polaroid Corporation yesterday reported first-quarter earnings of $17.1 million, or 52 cents a share, an increase of 18 percent above the earnings of $14.5 million, or 49 cents a share, in the corresponding period of last year.

WASHINGTON, April 20 The United States and the Soviet Union held highlevel talks again today on completing a strategic arms-limitation treaty and scheduled one more round. Administration officials indicated that an announcement of a summit meeting for the second half of May could come next week.

WASHINGTON, April 20 The rubber workers union agreed late this afternoon to postpone a strike threatened for 12:01 A.M. tomorrow and to extend its contract with the Big Four rubber companies on a day-to-day basis pending further negotiations.

Auction records for American artists from Winslow Homer to Norman Rockwell were toppled over and over yesterday at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street. WASHINGTON, April 20 Deeply divided over whether recession or inflation was the greater danger, the top policy-making body of the Federal Reserve System defeated by a vote of 6 to 4 an attempt at its March meeting to raise interest rates, the Fed reported today.

BANGKOK, Thailand, April 20 Two candidates and 13 political workers have been murdered so far in the campaigning for the election Sunday for the House of Representatives, and more violence is expected before the polls close.

By reviving Antony Tudor's "Shadowplay" Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, the American Ballet Theater has restored a provocative work to its repertory. NOW YOU SEE IT It's that time again for magic-minded New Yorkers, as the Society of American Magicians presents its annual salute to legerdemain tonight at 8 o'clock at the Hunter College Assembly Hall, 69th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues.

A city park at the southeast corner of First Avenue and 42d Street has been offered as an alternative site for construction of a controversial skyscraper that Harry Helmsley, the developer, wants to build in the center of the Tudor City development.

RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., April 20 The big-name champions dominated the second round of the Tournament of Champions today, while the lesser known of golf's elite slipped a bit off the pace. Tom Watson, the first-round leader by one stroke over Ron Streck, shot a six-under-par 66 today for a 36hole total of nine-under 135.

The Yankee turmoil that had been missing for the first two weeks of the season erupted on a new front last night with the announcement that Rich Gossage, the team's $2.75 million free agent, suffered a sprained right thumb Thursday in a clubhouse fight with Cliff Johnson. Gossage will be out for at least a week.

WASHINGTON, April 20 The National Capital branch of the Y.M.C.A. is almost a year old now, but it still smells new. And it is remarkably quiet. No raucous cries echo through the building from the gym. The place seems nearly empty much of the time.

In its continuing struggle to force the press to shape up, the Supreme Court now states that journalists can be required to tell lawyers what opinions they held while preparing material that public men subsequently believe has libeled them.

A threatened strike of 20,000 service employees in 3,000 apartment buildings was temporarily averted late last night when they and the Realty Advisory Board agreed to suspend a midnight deadline and continue negotiating over the weekend.

Charles Reeves Shackford, professor of music at Connecticut College, died yesterday following injuries suffered in an automobile accident in New London, Conn. He was 61 years old, and had taught at Connecticut since 1955.

Everyone, the Supreme Court now rightly answers: Whites and blacks alike are hurt by sales practices that rob a residential area "of its racial balance and stability."

The National Transportation Safety Board, by a 3-to-1 vote yesterday, formally affirmed its finding that primary blame for the fatal midair collision in San Diego last September must be borne by the crew of the Pacific Southwest Airlines jet.

CINCINNATI, April 20 At a negotiating session here tonight, representatives of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's largest, reaffirmed their position that they would not agree to a wage package that exceeded the 7 percent guidelines called for by the 7 president.

The Kansas Electric Power Cooperative announced yesterday that it would acquire a 17 percent share, valued at about $187 million, of the Wolf Creek nuclear generating unit, now owned jointly by the Kansas Gas and Electric Company and the Kansas City Power and Light Company.
Most cattle futures rose sharply yesterday on strong demand for beef, despite an announced cut in beef purchases by the Government because of soaring prices.

The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust said it had pared its losses for the quarter ended Feb. 28 to $l.7 million, from $6.7 million in net losses it reported for the similar quarter a year earlier. Easter weekend attendance at the nation's major amusement parks, usually a harbinger of the spring and summer tourist season, was generally strong, a spot check by The New York Times has shown.

The dollar gained strength on the world's foreign exchange markets yesterday as news of a sharp increase in wholesale prices in West Germany raised inflation fears and put downward pressure on the West German mark.

CHICAGO, April 20 (Reuters) The First Chicago Corporation, parent company of the First National Bank of Chicago, today reported a modest increase in its first-quarter operating profit over the comparable yearearlier period.
CLARKSDALE, Miss., April 20 (AP) Former Lieut. Gov. Charles Sullivan was found dead yesterday in the wreckage of his twin-engine plane. He was 54 years old.

PAMPLONA, Spain, April 20 (Reuters) Four persons were injured, one seriously, in clashes between several hundred left-wing Basque-nationalist supporters and riot policemen last night, hospital sources said today.

Selected glamour and specialty issues scored gains yesterday as the popular stock averages displayed a mixed pattern. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 1.73 points to 856.98, while the transportation and utility averages moved down slightly.

MANILA, April 20 (Reuters) The death toll from a typhoon that lashed the central Philippines earlier this week rose to 29 today, and more than 100 people were reported missing, officials said.

READING, Pa., April 22 (AP)--The president of the company that operates the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant says the concern was neither prepared for the March 28 accident nor aware of its scope for two or three days.

When some communities in Illinois discovered that the price of bricks sold to private government contractors had been illegally fixed by the brick manufacturers, they sued for damages. But in 1977 the Supreme Court ruled that as "indirect" purchasers they had no right to sue. Only the middlemen--the contractors who actually bought the bricks--had any claim against the brick companies.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 22 (Reuters)--Two seamen were killed and five were reported missing when the 1,491-ton Turkish cargo ship Kemal Kefeli sank last night after a collision with a Rumanian vessel passing through the Bosporus, the Turkish radio said today. The 16,604-ton Rumanian ship, the Carpati, was on its way to the Black Sea. No casualties were reported among its crew.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI)-- Negotiators for the United Rubber Workers union and Uniroyal Inc. plan to meet for "intense" talks with a Federal mediator tomorrow in an effort to avert a strike.
BADMINTON, England, April 22-- More than 100,000 British horse fanciers converged on a muddy meadow here this weekend for an annual upperclass rite of spring known as the Badminton Horse Trials.

Jane Dryfoos Bijur, widow of Justin H. Bijur, was married yesterday at her home in Elberon, N.J., to Robert Sturm Rau, a widower. Rabbi Joseph Goldman of Temple Beth-Miriam in Elberon performed the ceremony.
In a recent article on the virtues of raw garlic, it was mentioned that a friend and cookbook author eats a goodly quantity of the seasoning each year to ward off attacks of hay fever.

A group of about 25 striking New York State correction officers with drawn guns surrounded an unarmed force of 60 National Guardsmen returning to their armory on Staten Island last night, according to the police, who managed to separate the two groups without violence. No arrests were made.

Five days a week during the academic year, Mike Liscovitz dons a suit, white shirt and tie and heads for Middletown (N.J.) High School, where he teaches English. But the weekends. ... ah, that's another matter. The dress and demeanor associated with English instructors is left behind as he heads for a rugby field.

Deborah Post and David Cort Radovsky were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Seymour C. Post in New York. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Morton Goldberg of Toledo, Ohio, the bridegroom's uncle.
There has been another flap in Washington about whether the loss of two American monitoring stations in Iran will let the Russians cheat on the pending arms control agreement.

A truck leaded with dynamite caught fire and exploded at a quarry east of Buffalo yesterday, injuring about eight workers and blowing out windows of homes and businesses over an area of several square miles. Two of the injured were hospitalized but their conditions were described as not serious.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 23--More than a third of Princeton University undergraduates have cheated on an examination at least once during their college careers, according to a controversial copyrighted poll conducted by The Daily Princetonian, a campus newspaper. The survey's methodology was immediately attacked by administrators and the student body president when it was released yesterday.

ALBANY, April 23--Attorney General Robert Abrams said today that "legal grounds exist" for New York State to bring damage suits against companies whose dumping of toxic waste has created health hazards to the public. He asked Governor Carey for almost $1 million and subpoena power to pursue the legal action.

A ONE-HOUR closed-circuit television program will be broadcast by satellite today to some 60 public television stations as a preview of a series in which 3 million fifth-grade and sixth-grade students in the United States and Canada will be taught how to think, reason and apply their classroom knowledge to the outside world.
DETROIT, April 23 (AP)--Mark (The Bird) Fidrych gave up four hits and two runs in six innings for Detroit as the Tigers routed the Cincinnati Reds, 14-3, tonight in an exhibition game.

WASHINGTON, April 23--The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether local government can constitutionally forbid a charity to solicit funds unless the organisation can prove that most of the money goes for charitable purposes.

An article on tipping that appeared in these pages recently raised hackles and some serious issues as well. The story dealt with the problems of tipping in full service, deluxe restaurants, the kind that employ headwaiters, captains and wine stewards as well as waiters. Most people visit such places once a year or, as one reader put it, "once in a lifetime."

He is a New York physician caring part time for city prisoners on Rikers Island. But he also has a promising private practice in Manhattan, and he did not want his name mentioned. He did not want to be stigmatized, he said. He was not going to risk losing any of his private patients or losing face with colleagues.

Eddie Donovan, Red Holzman and Fuzzy Levane were in Philadelphia last Friday to watch the National Basketball Association playoff series between the 76ers and the San Antonio Spurs. Donovan, the Knick general manager, said he was there with the coach and the scout "just to watch the game."

The cosmic heartbeat, the music of the spheres, Johannes Kepler himself reduced to computer-derived intervals after his own formulas, can now be experienced on an LP disk. Two professors from Yale, helped by a computer, have set it all to music, sort of. They have brought out a record on, appropriately, the Kepler label, on which the music of the planets in their orbits can be heard.

KAREN SHAW, who heads the piano department at Indiana University, has established her credentials as an ad mirabie recitalist with several appearances here in the past. On Sunday afternoon she returned to Carnegie Hall, where she confirmed the reputation she has earned as a fully equipped technician and a persuasive interpreter of Romantic music.

WASHINGTON, April 23--The Soviet Union has begun to deploy a new nucleararmed missile in East Germany, a step that Carter Administration officials described today as raising the risk of a stepped-up arms race in Europe.
TEHERAN, Iran, April 23--Three unidentified gunmen today killed the Iranian general who was appointed the first army Chief of Staff after the revolution last February.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) --A House Banking subcommittee announced today it would hold hearings to draft legislation providing "clear authority" for consumers to receive interest on a variety of checking accounts. Such interest-bearing checking accounts were ruled illegal on Friday by the United States Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, April 23--In danger of losing a first major test of strength as chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Senator Edward M. Kennedy postponed today until May 8 a vote on an antitrust bill that shapes up as a major battleground between business and consumers.
DISCOUNT bonds, perennial stepchildren of the tax-exempt municipal bond market, are find ing new support in the wake of the Tax Reform Act of 1978.

ALBANY, April 23--Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink said today that he had "second thoughts" about whether casino gambling should be legalized in New York State, following a special study panel's report that gambling would provide the state government with relatively little new income.

FOR the last eight years, the Apple Hill Chamber Players have traveled to New York from their home base in southern New Hampshire for a series of concerts. The final one of the season took place Sunday night in Carnegie Recital Hall and it was notable for a number of reasons, not the least being the superior quality of the performances and the group's usual care in planning an interestingly diverse program.
LONG BEACH, Calif., April 23--Fifteen-year-Old Cynthia Woodhead set one American record in winning two individual events Sunday as the United States dominated West Germany in a dual swim meet.
PEKING, April 23 (Reuter)--A gang of embezzlers who bribed scores of officials has been arrested in one of the biggest Chinese corruption scandals under Communist rule, the People's Daily said today.
"The days are gone when a woman--any woman-- will buy clothes that will just last a season. If they buy a fur, it should last five years, maybe longer."

A memorial service for Dr. Richard Ettinghausen, a leading authority on Islamic art who was consultative chairman of the Metropolitan Museum of Art's department of Islamic art, will be held Saturday at 3 P.M. at the chapel of Princeton University, in Princeton, N.J. Dr. Ettinghausen died on April 2.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)-- The Department of Housing and Urban Development has raised the maximum interest rate that will be allowed on Government-insured home mortgages to a record 10 percent, effective today.
A raw potato fell out of the sky and shattered on the sidewalk. The sound of its impact and the tiny fragments into which it exploded suggested it came from considerable height.

Energy stocks posted some of the market's best gains yesterday, while the general list moved slightly higher on modest volume. Caesars World tumbled 6 points to 70 after selling as low as 66, placing a damper on other gambling stocks.

Those who have raised questions in the past about the risks of nuclear power plants will not be surprised that the industry and its apologists have opened a counterattack following the near-catastrophe at Three Mile Island. Theirs may be the most defensive special interest this side of the gun lobby.

MORRIS TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 23 --John T. Connor, chairman and chief executive of the Allied Chemical Corporation, called "Preposterous" Federal charges that Robert E. Mulcahy, the company's president, had conspired to defraud the Government with respect to income taxes owed for 1972 and 1973 by Chester Zabik, former purchasing manager of the General Tire and Rubber Company.

For years, American industry has dominated the world market for everything from passenger jets and computers to oil-drilling equipment. But Government officials and industrial executives have been growing worried about technological development. Now, President Carter has ordered a comprehensive study of how official policies affect industrial innovation, and is pleading with Congress not to cut his budgetary request for basic science research funds.
Rates on United States Treasury bills dropped unusually sharply yesterday in response to the Federal Reserve's apparent decision last week not to tighten monetary policy.

THE 1970's search for alternative energy sources had a coun terpart some 2,500 years ago in Greece and Rome, according to three California researchers, who say the impetus for the search then was a shortage of wood, not oil.
VIENNA, April 23 (Reuters)--An explosion at a Vienna Jewish center last night, originally thought to be an attack by neo-Nazis, may have been caused by a Palestinian group, police sources said today.

WASHINGTON, April 23--The United States bad no official comment today on the decision by Kuwait and Saudi Arabia to break diplomatic relations with Egypt, and officials speaking in private expressed uncertainty about the implications of the moves.

The Exxon Corporation and the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), two of the nation's largest oil companies, reported sizable profit increases yesterday, stemming in part from the higher oil prices that resulted from the revolution in Iran.

BANGKOK, Thailand, April 23-Cambodian soldiers and civilians are flowing toward the Thai border and often across it in increasing numbers and for a variety of reasons. The Thai response is equally varied.

QUEBEC, April 23 (AP)--Bob Guindon scored twice in Winnipeg's fivegoal second period tonight, as the Jets posted a 6-3 victory over the Quebec Nordique's in the opener of their World Hockey Association semifinal playoff series.

WASHINGTON, April 23--Many members of Congress voiced strong subport today for a tax on oil company profits that would flow in once prices are allowed to rise on June 1. But sharp divisions remained over how the tax should be applied.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)-- New orders for durable goods received by the nation's factories fell 2.5 percent in March, the largest decline since a near-record drop of 5.3 percent last July, the Commerce Department said today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 23--Eleventhousand public school teachers in Brasilia walked off the job today, joining hundreds of thousands of Brazilians already idled in a series of strikes that are sorely testing the military Government's resolve to return the country to civilian rule and democratic institutions.
The city's medical schools are planning for the fall term, gleaning applications and counting bodies, and the anatomy professors figure they are about 300 cadavers Short for the coming year.
TROUVILLE, France, April 22-- Princesse Ghislaine de Polignac, who makes a business of getting people to parties, what she calls "Custom PR," said that "it was never so easy."

Herbert H. Pensig, a labor lawyer who was chairman of the Garment Trucking Industry, a bargaining and administrative association for employers and employees in the Garment District, died of pneumonia Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 63 years old.

WASHINGTON, April 23--A member of the United Mine Workers' international executive board was shot and wounded this morning while driving here from Ohio to resist his ouster by the union's president. Arnold R. Miller.

General Mills Inc. announced yesterday it would discontinue its Kimberly division, a maker of women's apparel. General Mills said that a review of Kimberly's operations indicated that while an improvement in its current unprofitable performance was projected, "overall prospects are inadequate to warrant continuing the business."

The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court yesterday upheld a lowercourt finding that the northern Westchester town of New Castle had unconstitutionally excluded multifamily housing. But the court overturned a broad judicial order that the town allow the construction of 3,500 apartment units over the next 10 years.

MOSCOW, April 23 (AP)--Orange rain fell on the Crimean city of Yalta recently. Soviet scientists speculated that the clouds contained dust picked up in Turkey and carried across the Black Sea, the newspaper Trud said. It said about half an inch of rain left a thick layer of rustcolored dust.

CAIRO, April 23--Saudi Arabia, which has been Egypt's principal Arab financial backer, announced today that it had broken diplomatic and political relations with Cairo, but it said nothing about economic ties.
PYONGYANG, North Korea, April 23--The 42-member delegation of the United States table tennis team arrived in this spotless capital today, the first Americans to visit North Korea in nine years.
The United States must provide "a new Kind of leadership" to "challenge Soviet intervention in the third world," General Alexander M. Haig Jr. said yesterday.

Representatives of apartment-house owners and their service employees continued their contract talks early this morning in an intensified effort to avert a walkout at 3,000 apartment houses and cooperatives.

WILLIE RUFF, an associate professor of music at Yale University, sat a guest at the desk chair in his wood-panelled office and placed two small loudspeakers on her shoulders. He explained that with the speakers...

CLEVELAND, April 23 (UPI)--The police have arrested a Waukegan, Ill., man who was wanted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Illinois and Wisconsin authorities for questioning about three murders.

IN a recent Jules Feiffer cartoon strip, an assistant professor of Karl Marx is telling his class about Southeast Asia--the Viet namese invasion of Cambodia, the Chinese invasion of Vietnam and so on. In the last panel of the cartoon, the assistant professor explains: "History will prove that none of this happened."

CHICAGO KARY HARRISON leaned over his desk in the back row of a seventh-grade class at the May Elementary School here and dug into a series of short, mimeographed read ing passages, including one about trained dogs and cats.

Martin's, the 70-year-old apparel specialty store chain, will close its main store on Fulton Street in Brooklyn later this year as a result of long-term unprofitability, its parent company announced here yesterday.

VIKTOR TRETYAKOV, that most elegant of violinists, found a novelty to open his Carnegie Hall recital last night. With the exuberant Mikhail Erokhin at the piano, he played the Brahms Violin Sonata "No.2 in E flat." Thus it was described on the program, and it was a bit of a shocker. An E flat Violin Sonata by Brahms? A newly discovered work?

Any notion that the 30th National Book Awards would represent establishment thinking because of their sponsorship by the publishers' and booksellers' associations was shattered yesterday by the surprise winners-- and losers--in the major categories.

More than 500 stockholders of the American Express Company attended the company's annual meeting yesterday, but few asked questions in the twohour session and fireworks expected over an unsuccessful bid for McGrawHill Inc. failed to materialize. McGraw-Hill will hold its own annual meeting today.

NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., April 23 (AP)--John Wayne, the actor, was hospitalized last week for treatment of bronchitis, a spokesman for Hoag Memorial Hospital said today. The spokesman said Mr. Wayne, still recuperating from recent cancer surgery, was expected to be released in a few days.
Paul A. Johnston, a geologist at the University of Alberta in Canada, has concluded from a study of the rings in dinosaur teeth that those enigmatic old reptiles were, in fact, cold-blooded.

WASHINGTON, April 23--The United Rubber Workers and Uniroyal Inc., the tire maker, agreed today to resume contract negotiations tomorrow at the offices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service here.

The Energy Department is "leaning toward" a fixed price ceiling on gasoline to eliminate overcharging at the pump, but the move could cost motorists 5 cents more a gallon, a petroleum newsletter said yesterday. The Lundberg Letter said that any uniform calling price would tend to become the minimum price as well.

Chicagoans had a miserable winter this year with record snowfalls. And last night at Madison Square Garden, the city's amateur boxing team was also buried--in a barrage of punches --as the New York team won the 37th Intercity Golden Gloves competition, 9 bouts to 2.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 23 (Reuter)--The last group of 76 Vietnamese refugees from a stranded freighter left today for Bangkok on their way to the United States for resettlement.
Moscow, April 23--Two streaks continued at the world hockey championship today as Canada lost again and the Soviet Union cruised to another overwhelming victory.

At the crest of its most popular season ever, ABC-TV yesterday gained a jump on the other networks next season by being the first to announce its fall program schedule, one that will field at least seven new weekly series.
Phil Ford of the Kansas City Kings was the only unanimous choice for the National Basketball Association's all-rookie team selected by the the League's coaches.

DENVER, April 23 (UPI)--Negotiations between United Airlines and the striking International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers resumed today for We first time in nearly three weeks. The strike by 18,000 mechanics and other ground crew workers began March 31 and has grounded the airline, which transports about 160,000 passengers daily. All flights have been canceled through May 5.

Twenty-four striking school-bus drivers and matrons were arrested on charges of disorderly conduct outside the Staten Island Bus Company, a nonunion shop, yesterday morning. They had tried to block 75 vans from leaving the garage.

Sol A. Pearl, who wrote under the name S. Almazov for The Morning Freiheit, a Yiddish-language newspaper, died Friday at Cabrini Health Care Center in New York after a long illness. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Newspaper advertising revenues rose by 14 percent last year to almost $13 billion, daily newspaper circulation increased for the third year in a row and 200 weekly newspapers have started up since last year, members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association were told yesterday.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 23--Latin America's developing countries strongly condemned today what they perceived as the "growing protectionist barriers" to their exports raised by the United States, Europe and Japan.

Pyotr Nikolayevich Pospelov, a principal theoretician of the Soviet Communist Party who led many of the cold war's verbal assaults on the West, has died at the age of 80, according to an official announcement in Moscow.
Pan American world Airways reported yesterday a net loss f $8.9 million for the first quarter of this year, its lowest first quarter loss since 1968.
NEW HAVEN, April 23--Doug Latrenta and Bob Kovalsky had two runs batted in apiece to lead St. John's University to a 7-5 victory over the Univer sity or New Haven today.

WASHINGTON, April 23--Two senior technicians of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission recommended today that the commission reverse an earlier decision and shut down nuclear power reactors made by the Babcock Wilcox Company, which designed the reactor involved in last month's accident in Pennsylvania.
THERE ought to be an incometax rebate for watching a pro gram like "The Grand Jury: An Institution Under Fire," which is being presented from 10:30 to midnight tonight on Channel 13.
LOS ANGELES, April 23 (AP)-- Johnny Carson, his representatives and his employers met through the weekend trying to resolve Mr. Carson's differences with NBC-TV.

Weary volunteers worked in incessant rains yesterday to fight back the waters of the Red River, which rose to its highest point this century at East Grand Forks, Minn. Its waters breached dikes and spilled through city streets and affluent neighborhoods.

John Boldt, who has led a rent strike of tenants at the 79th Street Boat Basin for the past six months, returned from a trip to a Broadway self-service laundry late yesterday afternoon to find that his abode --a 35-foot, $25,000 fully equipped houseboat--had disappeared, along with his two Siberian huskies and all the rest of his worldly possessions.

As if they didn't have enough trouble, the Mets came off the road yesterday and braced for the season's first wave of western power that arrives tonight with undefeated Vida Blue and the San Francisco Giants.
A number of Irish-American politicians in recent weeks have intensified their criticism of British policy in Northern Ireland.
PHILADELPHIA, April 23 (UPI)-- Sid Gillman, a professional football coach for 18 years, has joined the Philadelphia Eagles as an assistant, the team said today.

WASHINGTON--In the days before Vietnam and Watergate, Americans took on the world's problems with a self-assurance born of good intention. We were the world's innocents, idealistic in our viewpoint and charitable in our intent. We may not always have been right but we seldom faltered for lack of conviction.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 23--Joe Harrington, an assistant to Lefty Driesell at the University of Maryland for the last 10 years, was named basketball coach at Hofstra University today.

TEL AVIV, April 23 (AP)--An earthquake shook Israel today but caused no injuries or major damage, the Israeli radio reported The tremor extended from Tiberias in the north to Beersheba in the south and from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, according to the Seismological Institute of Hebrew University.

Armco Inc., the nation's fifth-largest steel company, yesterday reported earnings for the first quarter of $58.4 million, or $l.27 a share, a 93.4 percent increase over last year's first-quarter earnings of $30.2 million, of 64 cents a share.

A commission created Lo find solutions to the growing problems surrounding the 500,000 children in foster homes or childcare institutions said, in a report to be released today, that it was possible for the majority of these children to be returned to their natural parents or placed in adoptive homes.

PASSAIC, N.J., April 23--In a move that could set a precedent for hundreds of municipalities throughout the state, a City Councilman here is running for a new four-year term--even though he still has two years to serve on his current term.
More than anyone, the Rangers--if they have a sense of their history at all --should know that strange things happen in the playoffs.

ON Sunday afternoon the Criterion Concerts series at the Guggenheim Museum presented a program of music composed in the last five years that was extremely, implacably tedious. Four of the five pieces consisted of sequences of short movements strung together; the fifth, Doris Hays's "Breathless" for bass flute (l977), was one short movement in itself.

The dollar eased against most major European currencies abroad and in New York yesterday while gold prices rose.
WESTBURY, L.I., Apri1 23--There aren't too many of them left, the oldtime hardboot trainers who have kept from being swept up in the flood of dollars that has engulfed harness racing for two decades.

NEWPORT, Del., April 23 (AP)--An explosion at the Du Pont Company plant last night injured four persons, none seriously, and sent a red ball of smoke into the sky, company officials said. The explosion occurred in a piece of filtering equipment used to filter red pigment, the plant manager, Ralph Fortney, said. He said there was no extensive damage to the plant.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)--A Korean-born American businessman pleaded not guilty today to a charge of contempt of Congress stemming from his refusal to answer a question from the House ethics committee, which was investigating the South Korean influencebuying scandal.

QIRYAT TIVON, Israel, April 23--As the victims of the latest Palestinian terrorist attack were buried today, Israeli leaders hinted that more reprisals would be made against Palestinian guerrillas. [United Press International reported...

JOHANNESBURG, April 23 (UPI)-- Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina put on a controlled display of baseline power play today to defeat Deon Joubert of South Africa, 6-2, 6-1, in the final of the South African open tennis tournament.

AMHERST, Mass., April 23 (AP)-- The president of Amherst College suspended 72 students today after members of the Black Student Union and sympathizers chained themselves inside the main administration building.

Two tobacco industry leaders reported higher profits yesterday. R.J. Reynolds Industries had a 38.3 percent rise, while American Brands Inc. had a 24.6 percent gain. Both said they had been helped by diversification outside the tobacco industry.

JOHANNESBURG, April 23 (Reuters) --Explosives were found planted across four tracks of a main rail line near the black township of Soweto today, railway policemen said. They said a detonator was dismantled.

LOS ANGELES, April 23--West Coast newspapers, many of which have already been forced to cut their size and circulation because of a newsprint shortage, are bracing for a potential strike in Canadian mills that could restrict supplies even further.

LEST WE FORGET The Friends' Meeting House at 15 Rutherford Place is one of the most handsome and tranquil-looking landmark structures in lower Manhattan, dating from 1860. It is a restful sight indeed on a spring day, observed at leisure from a bench in the adjacent park at 15th Street and Second Avenue, an area where many older residents recall the horrors of World War II on European soil.
WASHINGTON, April 23--peter Charles Bommarito is not easily scared. The White House is learning that.
A STUDY involving 9,000 women who gave birth at a hospital in Copenhagen has concluded that, when given proper prenatal care, teen-age women are better at giving birth than women of any other age.

WASHINGTON, April 23--The House Ways and Means Committee announced today that it had voted to require domestic industry to show "material" injury before getting import relief. The action sets up a conflict with the Senate Finance Committee and raises prospects of a House-Senate struggle over a key American trade concession.

WUXI, China, April 18--A large pink chart on the wall of the clinic of the Xihung production brigade near this industrial city advertises how each local official is complying with what may be China's most important campaign, birth control.

WASHINGTON, April 23--Ted Turn er, Atlanta's flamboyant sportsman and broadcaster, announced today that he would present prime-time adult programs on his satellite network for cable television systems and offer news and daily children's shows for the first time.

LARCHMONT, N.Y.--While living in Australia, I discovered that banks do not return canceled checks. Having tossed away receipts on the assumetion that our checks would come back, I asked the teller what evidence we would have for the tax department.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation formally introduced its domestic long-distance tele phone service yesterday at rates that it the American Telephone and Telegraph Company but comparable to those of two other competitors.

WASHINGTON, April 23--President Carter said today that public support of his energy plan had led Congressional opponents "to try to hoodwink the American people by passing a windfall profits tax that is in fact a charade."
SWANTON, Vt., April 23 (AP)-- Abenaki Indians and wardens of the state Fish and Game Department have traded citations on the banks of the Missisquoi River in Swanton.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 23 (AP)-- Three members of Parliament resigned from Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit's Republican People's Party today, seriously undermining the Government's slim majority in the 450-seat National Assembly.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 23--The Rhodesian election received a major setback tonight when the Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole, one of the two men vying to be the country's first black prime minister, denounced the voting as fraudulent and said his party would refuse to accept the result.

MOSCOW, April 23 (Reuters)-- Irina Rodnina, the Soviet figure skater, plans to return to competition with her husband and partner, Aleksandr Zaitsev, to defend their Olympic title at the 1980 Winter Games in Lake Placid, N.Y., it was reported today in Izvestia, the Soviet newspaper.

For the last 10 years, quality quartermilers have been synonomous with Adelphi University. This week at the Penn Relays, it will be a woman, June Griffith, who is likely to be the center of attention.
TRENTON, April, 23--The New Jersey Assembly voted today to allow mortgage rates charged by state banks to rise to 10 percent in an effort to start home loans flowing again.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 23--Dan White, 32 years old, former policeman, fireman, paratrooper and San Francisco supervisor, went on trial today, accused of murdering Mayor George Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk.
NAIROBI, Kenya, April 23 (Reuters) --Idi Amin spent two days in Baghdad last week but has disappeared since then, Arab diplomatic sources said tonight.

CHARLESTON, W.Va., April 23 (AP)--Terry Bradshaw, the Pittsburgh Steeler quarterback, will receive an nonorary doctor of laws degree from Alderson-Broaddus College on May 20. An official of the Philippi, W.Va., college said that Bradshaw is being recognized for his "humanitarian efforts and his interest in people."

Sanitation Commissioner Normal Steisel said yesterday that the union of the striking tugboat crewmen had agreed to let its members comply with a court order that they resume taking New York City's garbage to a Staten Island landfill. But last night it remained uncertain whether the tugboat union had agreed to anything.

A transportation program that would close two midtown streets in New York City to all traffic but buses and taxis from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. and that would encourage group cab riding to and from city airports was announced yesterday by Mayor Koch.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)--A coalition of education, research, labor and civil rights activists announced today the formation of a committee to oppose the creation of a separate education department.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI)--A Roman Catholic official has expressed "grave concern" about proposed Federal actions that could drastically cut church participation in a major Government jobtraining program.

ST. LOUIS, April 23 (AP)--The St. Louis Cardinals third baseman, Ken Reitz, said today that his temper had cost him $1,250, The penalty stemmed from as incident that occured April 11 during a 10-hour rain delay at Lambert Airport here while the team was waiting to fly to Pittsburgh.
Striking milk-truck drivers and plant workers yesterday rejected a judge's proposal to work and submit outstanding issues to binding arbitration.

Four tapestries from the 16th and 17th centuries, valued at more than $100,000, were stolen last week from the walls of St. Thomas Episcopal Church on Fifth Avenue at 53d Street. Thieves entered the church during the night after prying open a stainedglass window, the police said.

LOS ANGELES, April 23--Law enforcement officials here said today that they had solved 10 of the "hillside strangler" murders and named a 27-year-Old man who professes to have a "multiple personality" as one of possibly two or more men allegedly involved in the deaths.

Four tapestries from the 16th and 17th centuries, valued at more than $100,000, were stolen last week from the walls of St. Thomas Episcopal Church on Fifth Avenue at 53d Street. Thieves entered the church during the night after prying open a stainedglass window, the police said.

STEARNS, Ky., April 23 (AP)--Ten mines in Kentucky and Tennessee were closed today by pickets protesting a tentative settlement of a three-year-old strike against the Stearns Mining Company, according to the Bituminous Coal Operators Association.
Hobart College's lacrosse team came of age last Saturday. The Statesmen, characterized as young and inexperienced when the season began, crushed the most powerful Syracuse squad in years, 16-4.

The bond market, concerned that the Federal Reserve is not moving more forcefully against inflation and apprehensive about the impact of a possible 40-year Treasury bond issue, lurched uncertainly yesterday toward higher yields and lower prices.
Three striking state correction officers were arrested on Staten Island last night and accused of brandishing their pistols during a confrontation with National Guardsmen there Sunday evening.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 23 (AP)--A woman whose ranch was in the path of fallout from nuclear tests in the 1950's stood before a joint Congressional committee today and declared that she and her family "were forgotten guinea pigs."

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 (UPI)-- The Consolidated Rail Corporation reported today that it had narrowed its losses to $127.7 million in 1979's first quarter from $216 million in the yearearlier period. The Congressionally created rail company said the results showed a continued upward trend in the four years Conrail has operated.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 23--Dr. Archibald S. Dean, retirtd head of the Department of Public Health of Western New York State and former professor at the State University of New York at Buffalo, died Saturday following a short illness. He was 84 years old and had lived here since 1978, when he moved from Buffalo.

MOSCOW, April 23 (Reuters)--The United States Embassy delivered a strong protest to the Soviet Foreign Ministry today over the alleged drugging of a correspondent of an American news magazine in the Central Asian city of Tashkent last week. The protest was rejected.

A Federal bankruptcy judge in New York yesterday approved an order setting Friday as the start of the five-week going-out-of-business sale for the 79 J. M. Fields Department Stores, a unit of Food Fair Inc. The start of the sale had been delayed because of a disagreement over the value of the inventory in the stores. Food Fair has been operating under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act since October 1978.
