The statement from the Seagram Company had only one line about Frank S. Berger, saying he had resigned as president of the House of Seagram. It offered no explanation.
WASHINGTON, April 25--Despite a last-minute public plea from President Carter, the House Commerce Committee handed the White House another ...

Robbers who apparently hid in the Gimbels department store after closing time on Tuesday night smashed open a safe and escaped with diamond jewelry that one estimate said was worth as much as $1 million.
ANTONY TUDOR and Glen Tetley are not choreographers who would normally be put into the same category.
The Procter Gamble Company, the nation's largest manufacturer of detergents and household packaged goods, reported earnings of $169 million, or $2.04 a share, for its third quarter ...
A weekend of French-Canadian folk dances and Jewish music will be offered by the Balkan Arts Center at Casa Galicia, 119 East 11th Street.
"Harry James has the only established name band that can pull in ballroom dancers," the owner of Roseland Ballroom, Nancy Brecker Leeds, was saying.

NEW DELHI, April 26 (AP)--An explosion aboard an Indian Airlines Boeing 737 forced the pilot to make a crash landing at Madras airport today, airline officials said. Ten of 67 persons aboard were hospitalized. Witnesses said that the plane had overshot the runway and plowed through nearby fields before coming to a halt about a mile from the terminal.

WASHINGTON, April 26--A Federal grand jury has been quietly investigating Seaboard Coast Line Industries in connection with possible improper and lavish entertainment of government officials at the company's resorts, it has been learned.

OAKLAND, Calif., April 26--Rich Gossage and his agent, Jerry Kapstein, will meet with Al Rosen, the Yankee president, late next week as their first step in fighting the $18,603 fine imposed on Gossage for his clubhouse fight with Cliff Johnson last Thursday.

THERE is probably no government agency more important to the interests of the legal and cor porate community than the Securities and Exchange Commission. This week, Harold M. Williams, chairman of the commission, had the opportunity to offer some of his thinking to a uniquely blue-chip audience of 800.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 26-- The Security Council commended Lebanon today for taking steps to reassert its authority over the strife-torn southern region and implicitly warned the Israelisupported Christian militia forces there against further interference.

ISMAILIA, Egypt, April 26--Defense Minister Ezer Weizman of Israel spent an hour with President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt today and said they had reviewed plans for normalizing relations and for withdrawal of Israeli forces from Sinai.

OBERLIN, Ohio, April 26--Almost exactly a decade ago, a handful of black students marched out of Willard Straight Hall on the Cornell campus with bandoleers slung across their chests and rifles in their hands. The scene was a harsh symbol of a volatile decade in which black student anger, polarization and radicalism seemed to increase with each turning of the calendar page.

The Board of Estimate decided yesterday to conduct an auction at 2 P.M. today among six competing companies for an interim contract to operate 500 bus shelters until a long-term franchise can be awarded.

The world's largest Gothic cathedral, St. John the Divine, has cause to celebrate. Work is to resume next June to complete the structure, which has stood unfinished, at Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street, for 37 years.

"IT'S been real nice weather since we got to Nashville," Sissy Spacek reported the other day. "The trees are a-buddin' out all over. We're shooting at the Grand Ole Opry. It's exciting because I'm working with all of Loretta's musicians."

Richard S. Salant, who will begin a new job Tuesday as vice chairman of the National Broadcasting Company, says one of his major goals is to increase the daily national news program from a half-hour to an hour and to broadcast it in prime time, from 8 to 9 P.M.

James (Sonny Ford) Thomas, a blues singer from the Mississippi Delta who will be giving his first New York concert tomorrow evening at the Center for International Arts, has thought long and hard about death. "You may be beautiful," he sings, "but you know you got to die some day," and though the line is as old as the blues, for Mr. Thomas it has a special meaning.

WASHINGTON, April 26--The Envi ronmental Protection Agency today fined Texaco Inc., a Texaco distributor in California and 11 Texaco filling stations in Alameda County there a total of $159,000 for illegaly selling leaded gasoline as more expensive unleaded fuel.

Apartment Houses: There was no move by either side to resume negotiations in the three-day old strike by apartment-house maintenance workers. Meanwhile, tenants at 2,000 affected buildings in Manhattan continued their efforts to maintain their own services.

IT takes a visitor no more than two minutes conversation with Peter Straub, whose "Ghost Story," a supernatural caper, has just been published by Coward, McCann Geoghegan and received favorable reviews, to learn that this author has more on his mind in his fiction than providing book-length entertainment.

HOLLYWOOD, April 26 (UPI) -- John Carroll, a star in Hollywood's swashbuckling era, who played the title role in several Zorro movies, died of complications from leukemia Tuesday. He was 72 years old.

ATLANTA, April 26--What once appeared to be a short, if difficult playoff series with the Atlanta Hawks is now becoming a nightmare for the Washington Bullets. Even after his team lost earlier, Dick Motta, the Washington coach, pointed out that he never saw his team lose its composure. That happened tonight, in a 104-86 loss that tied the series at three games each.

JACKSON, Miss., April 26--The Easter weekend flood that caused an estimated $500 million damage to some of Mississippi's richest neighborhoods has left behind a whirlpool of recriminations, lawsuits and threatened grand jury investigations as this city looks for someone to blame.

IN the penultimate weekend of the New York Philharmonic season. Zubin Mahta last night took his men through a program of Schu bert, Saint-Saens and Stravinsky. The Schubert was a continuation of Mr. Mahta's series honoring the 150th anniversary of the composer's death, and the work on this program was the Sixth Symphony in C, one of the least-played.

THE combination of high taxes, inflation and eroding respect for government is splitting every advanced industrial nation into two economies--an above-ground economy that, as Prof. Peter M. Gutmann of Baruch College in New York says, is legal and taxed, and a subterranean economy that is illegal and untaxed.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 26 (UPI)--A 17-year-old gorilla named Toni gave birth to a female gorilla yesterday, giving the Columbus Zoo its fourth generation of the animal and a world record. Toni's mother, Colo, made headlines in 1956 as the first gorilla born in captivity.

Antal Dorati, the Hungarian-born conductor, began his career in a typically European fashion, by serving as rehearsal pianist and coach at various opera houses. He made his conducting debut in his native Budapest in 1926, when he was 20, and was around two years later when Richard Strauss's opera "Die Aegyptische Helena" ("The Egyptian Helen") had its premiere and made the rounds of the many Central European theaters.

An amateur inventor carrying a device he called "The Eternal Light"-- six flashing red bulbs wired to two batteries and covered with epoxy-- caused the evacuation of a jetliner at LaGuardia Airport shortly before its scheduled departure for Pittsburgh last night when the authorities decided it might be a bomb.

UNIONDALE, L.I., April 26--Coach Al Arbour of the Islanders and Coach Fred Shero of the Rangers stood behind their teams' benches tonight and pushed the buttons that sent players on and off the ice, but the computers were high upstairs in the last row of Nassau Coliseum.

As spring unfurls outdoors, fall fashions are being paraded this week in the showrooms of Seventh Avenue, where American designers, unlike their fantasy-prone European counterparts, are keeping a clear eye on the dividing line between believable and imaginative clothes.

BOSTON, April 26 (AP)--Doctors say that for the first time they are able to tell before birth whether a baby will have hemophilia, the inherited bleeding disorder that once plagued the royalty of Europe.

Rosalynn Carter told a group of women communicators here yesterday that she thought her personal interests as First Lady--the mentally ill, the elderly, the handicapped and the poor --were being discriminated against because they are not "sexy" issues for a First Lady.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)--The average Social Security beneficiary will find $25 extra in his Government check this July and some will get up to $50 more as a result of an automatic 9.9 percent benefits increase announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 26--The Federal Communications Commission indicated today that it would approve the construction of facilities by Satellite Business Systems that would allow the new company to launch its satellites on schedule. The commission did not vote, however.
Cattle and copper prices, which surged ahead in active futures dealings, captured the interest of commodity traders yesterday.

PARIS, April 26--The European Court of Human Rights ruled today that the British Government had illegally infringed on the freedom of the press when it prevented the publication in 1972 of a newspaper article on the drug thalidomide.
The third day of the strike by 20,000 building-service employees found both tenants and strikers showing signs of increasing distress yesterday.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 26--Rebounding from the legislative defeat of his "taxpayers' bill of rights" two weeks ago, John V.N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, today proposed cutting county taxes by 10 percent a year for each of the next three years.

The Japanese Government has approved a $1 million cash contribution to help construct a new building for the Asia Society at the northeast corner of Park Avenue and 70th Street on a site that was cleared earlier this year.

SINCE January, 3,000 copies of the prestigious and peach-hued Financial Times of London have been arriving at 6 A.M., six days a week at Kennedy International Airport aboard a Lufthansa freighter from Frankfurt. Of that number, 889 are hand-delivered to Manhattan subscribers before noon--usually well before noon--on the day of publication. It's all part of the shrinking world of international publishing.

WASHINGTON, April 26--The talk of Washington these days is a serious analysis in the current issue of The Atlantic by James Fallows, a 29-year-old former speech writer in the White House, on the character of President Carter and the personnel and procedures of his Administration.

DETROIT, April 26--Record profits for the first quarter of 1979 were reported today by the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, the nation's largest and secondlargest automobile manufacturers, respectively. The results were considerably above what investment analysts had anticipated for both companies.

SOLO projects in rock are often ill-prepared ego trips. Musicians grow restless within the confines of a group, get together a more or less starry passel of friends, and out comes the solo album. The result, often as not, is sloppily considered, inferior work in which the artist indulges in some facet of music for which he's neither talented nor trained --guitarists sing, singers compose, etc.

CHICAGO--In the years since their independence, the developing countries have noted what they consider to be excessive coverage by Western news agencies of violence and crises (such as the Nigerian civil war), and poor coverage of positive developments (such as the universal, free, compulsory educational system that Nigeria is now building).
WASHINGTON, April 26--The Carter Administration suffered a setback on its bill to carry out the Panama Canal treaty today when the House Rules Committee adopted a substitute measure.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 26--His trainer had wanted a tough, useful workout for him, but Spectacular Bid did not get it today in the $121,550 Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland. Instead, the favorite for the 105th Kentucky Derby hardly had to work at all.
WASHINGTON, April 26--Few lobbies have more political power in Washington than the nation's 30 million veterans.

LOS ANGELES, April 26 (AP)-- Major California savings and loan associations, which have often led the nation in mortgage rate increases, are raising mortgage loan rates to 11 percent or more, the highest rate in four and a half years.

ELMIRA HEIGHTS, N.Y., April 25 --The men slouched in the lawn chairs could be a company softball team partying after a game, except for the patches on their blue-and-gold baseball caps. The words an the patches read: "New York State Correctional Services." The men scorn what they have become.
WASHINGTON, April 26--The Securities and Exchange proposed rules today that would prevent the nation's stock exchanges from applying restrictions on "off-board" trading to newly listed stocks.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Apri 26 (AP)--The official Libyan news agency reported today that Mauritania would turn over its part of the disputed western Sahara to the Polisario Front, a guerrilla group fighting for independence for the former Spanish colony, which wash divided between Mauritania and Mo rocco, but Mauritania had a somewhat different view.

CHICAGO, April 26 (AP)--American and National League officials are meeting with major league umpires at an undisclosed location to work out a settlement to the umpires' strike, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn said.

Pepsico Inc. reported yesterday a 22.2 percent rise in net income to $45.2 million, or 48 cents a share, during the 12 weeks to March 24, from $37 million, or 40 cents a share; in the 1978 quarter. Donald M. Kendall, chairman, noted that the company had hit the billiondollar mark for the first time in the quarter.

OTTAWA, April 26--For Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, who is off in British Columbia continuing a pugnacious election campaign to keep his Liberal Party in power, this week started out on a sour note.

Gould Inc., one of the nation's leading producers of electrical parts and auto batteries, offered yesterday to pay nearly $300 million in cash and stock for the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation.

NEW HAVEN FOR "Hillbilly Women," the stage at the Long Wharf Theater has been converted into a textile factory, a women's cooperative in a narrow-minded town in Georgia. Seven women are assembled to celebrate the factory's second anniversary.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 (AP)-- Smoking among teen-agers has declined by 25 percent since 1974, but for the first time more girls in that age group are smoking than boys, Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today.

WASHINGTON, April 26, (Reuters) --Senator Robert Byrd of West Virginia, the Senate majority leader, and Senator Robert Dole of Kansas, a prominent Republican, warned Japan today of possible retaliation if it did not make concessions in trade talks with the United States.

NEW DELHI, April 26--Opponents of the slaughter of cows, animals sacred to most Hindus, gained a significant political victory today as Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai announced in Parliament that the Government would introduce a constitutional amendment in this session prohibiting the slaughter of cows anywhere in India.

In 1966, the Supreme Court set aside the murder conviction of Dr. Sam H. Sheppard. The Court described his trial as a carnival of publicity that denied him the right to be tried by an impartial jury and only on evidence presented in court.

TENNECO INC., the largest natural-gas pipeline company in the United States, has been lagging in the stock market relative to its industry since the beginning of the year, even though it participates broadly in the energy business.

Except for one factor--the failure of black nationalist guerrillas to disrupt the voting--the election in Rhodesia went entirely as expected. Some of the principal players in the former Smith Government have swapped seats, and it will now be called the Muzorewa Government. Little else has changed.
Commissioner Norman S. Marshall, national commander of the Salvation Army from 1957 to 1963, died yesterday at his home in Asbury Park, N.J. He was 85 years old.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 26-- Against prohibitive odds, Rhodesia's transitional Government has completed the country's first universal-franchise election and cleared the way for a blackled...
ALBANY, April 26--Traces of chemical contamination turned up in ground water near the Niagara Falls watertreatment plant, state officials announced today.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 26--Kurds and Turks in the western Azerbaijan area of Iran exchanged hostages today as calm apparently returned to the embattled area, where five days of fighting left as many as 1,000 dead, the Iranian radio reported today.

UAL Inc., parent of strike-beset United Airlines, announced yesterday that its first-quarter earnings plunged 82.5 percent to $3 million, or 10 cents a share, from $17.1 million, or 68 cents a share, in the corresponding period last year.

Beatrice R. Solomon, an administrative staff member of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies until her retirement 24 years ago, died of a heart attack Wednesday at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in New York City. She was 84 years old and until she became ill two years ago she lived in Brooklyn.

A substantial decline in the cleanliness of city streets, a potential loss of experienced park workers and a drop in absenteeism among fire and correction workers were among the findings in the Mayor's Management Report on city services.
LONDON--Once again Britain is in the grip of election fever. I can feel it creeping up my leg even as I write, and by the time polling day arrives it will have reached my brain, numbing it totally.

THIS year marks the 10th anniversary of "New York Painting and Sculpture" at the Metropolitan Museum. Hard things were said of that exhibition at the time, but as the definitive statement of one man's point of view it had then, and still has now, a historical fascination.
PHILADELPHIA, April 26--A 15year-Old high school sophomore from Willingboro, N.J., leaped farther than the winner of the college long jump at the Penn Relays today, but no one was shocked.

The history of a neighborhood evolves in small steps. Take the case of Columbus Avenue in the West 80's, which is on the move largely under the impetus of the current conversion of the former Endicott Hotel into cooperative apartments.

The General Public Utilities Corporation voted yesterday to halve its dividend and to cut its spending for new construction, the salaries of executives and directors and stock-option plans to help cope with the costs incurred in its Three Mile Island plant's nuclear accident.
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 26--Franz Beckenbauer, the Cosmos midfielder, will be out for at least two games with an injured right knee, the North American Soccer League team announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 26--Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that it was "premature" to judge the fairness of last week's voting in Rhodesia and warned Congress that any action now to end economic sanctions against Rhodesia would be constitutionally improper.

In recent years, bridge has become highly popular in India. The standard of play has risen, and the national team won the Far East title in l977. However, visitors from the West sometimes find that the organization of the game has a surrealistic quality.

Walt Disney Productions announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with Shimberg, Kennedy Frost Inc., a Tampa-based real estate investment concern, under which Shimberg will build a $30 million hotel at the Lake Buena Vista Hotel Plaza across from Walt Disney World Village in Orlando, Fla. Disney said it would receive ground lease revenues and a percentage of gross revenues from the hotel, which will be owned by Shimberg.
A 33-year-old Virginia tax official has been selected to be the deputy commissioner for administration of the New York City Police Department.

IN the seventh generatian of the deities who lived on the plain of high heaven, so Japanese legend goes, the divine brother and sister Izanagi and Izanami were called upon to create a new land. When Izanagi thrust his sword into the sea below, the salt dripping from its tip formed Japan's principal island of Honshu, and then the two gods stepped down from the sky to form the other islands of Japan.

ALTHOUGH Simone Forti has been a choreographer for almost 20 years, she has not choreographed many dances. And those dances have sometimes been presented in out-of-the-way places before small audiences. Nevertheless, she has been extraordinarily influential, partly because in the early 60's she was one of the first choreographers to make dances out of so-called "natural" gestures.

I GATHER from one of the essays in "The Medusa and the Snail: More Notes of a Biology Watcher" that when Dr. Lewis Thomas is writing--and not presiding over Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City--he sits at his desk in an upper-floor room facing north on East 69th Street. It must be an exciting place to sit.

UNIONDALE, L.I., April 26--With the nerve of a city slicker fleecing a smalltown rube, the Rangers stunned the Islanders tonight by winning the opening game of their Stanley Cup semifinal series, 4-1.

MALIBU, Calif., April 26 (AP)--A groaning, rumbling Malibu hillside could tumble into the sea at any time, destroying six $500,000 homes, an apartment building and a section of the Pacific Coast highway, geologists said today.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 28--Anthony Russo, reputed underworld boss of Monmouth County, was found shot to death today in his fourth-floor apartment at the oceanfront Harbor Island Spa.

THE painters are not exactly household names. Their por traits, scenics, genre subjects, marine paintings and classical themes are certainly far from familiar. Nevertheless, the art works in three 19th-century European paintings sales next week are causing quite a stir internationally in this segment of the art market.

MONTREAL, April 26--Pierre Larouche, teaming on an extra line with Doug Risebrough and Guy Lafleur, scored the winning goal tonight as the Montreal Canadiens gained a 4-2 Stanley Cup semifinal victory over the Boston Bruins.

FREDERICKTOWN, Mo., April 26 (UPI)--A McDonnell Douglas test pilot was killed yesterday in the crash of a $15 million F-15B Eagle jet fighter that was making a second test run from the company's St. Louis facilities. He was identi- fied by the aerospace company as Gary L. Kincaid, 34 years old, of Chesterfield.
Utility issues moved lower yesterday as the general market retreated after posting small gains in the four previous sessions.

PARIS, April 26--Abortion and population are becoming major political issues in France once again, injected into the election campaign for the Assembly of the European Community despite their irrelevance to the choice of its representatives.

The final game of the three-game series between the New York Mets and San Francisco Giants was rained out last night. The Mets, having pulled out of a six-game losing spin, now will face the Los Angeles Dodgers at Shea Stadium this weekend with a three-game winning streak that includes two victories over the Giants.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 26--The heavy artillery bombardments and air attacks that shook southern Lebanon for the last four days ended today after an informal cease-fire between Israel and the Palestinian guerrillas.
Odetta, the blues and folk singer, will appear tonight at 7:30 P.M. in Theater 1199 of the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employees, 310 West 43d Street.

THERE'S a different sort of disco in Manhattan these days, and its proliferation shows every sign of becoming a genuine trend. These "new wave" discotheques are still mostly large, dark places with flashing lights and eager crowds dancing to pulsating, heavily amplified music. But the music they are dancing to isn't disco; it's rock-and-roll.
HANOI, Vietnam, April 26--Secretary General Kurt Waldheim arrived here today to begin a United Nations initiative to end hostilities between Vietnam and China.

TRENTON, April 26--New Jersey Corrections Commissioner William H. Fauver, moving to tighten control over a controversial juvenile-counseling program that purports to deter crime, directed officials at Rahway State Prison today to allow only certified juvenile delinquents to undergo sessions with inmates at the maximum-security prison.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., April 25-- "It's good to be back in New Hampshire," said the shirt-sleeved man on stage. "One of the advantages of being an unknown candidate when I came to New Hampshire for the first time to campaign in 1975 was that my family and I could talk to you individually, or...

Four years after New York City's fiscal difficulties caused an almost complete halt to construction projects, including even essential repair and maintenance, Mayor Koch proposed yesterday a $1 billion capital budget that would be devoted mostly to improving the city's roadways, bridges, sewers and water-supply system and to upgrading its mass-transit equipment.

WASHINGTON, April 26--Opponents of a proposed new department of education lost a number of crucial rounds today as the Senate continued debate on the Administration-backed legislation. A final vote on the measure is expected on Monday.
Otto Cohen, one of the founders of Charles of the Ritz, the cosmetics division of Charles of the Ritz Group, died Wednesday at his home in Miami Beach after a long illness. He was 96 years old.

Pssst! Wanna mortgage, cheap? That seductive whisper is about to be amplified to a shout, as one community after another discovers the latest back-door Federal subsidy: tax-exempt housing bonds. By using their right to issue tax-exempt bonds, localities can make mortgages available for singlefamily housing at 7 or 8 percent rather than the 9 or 10 now demanded by banks.

The swollen Red River flooded parts of Minnesota, North Dakota and Canada with new misery yesterday prompting an order that thousands of people evacuate their homes in the province of Manitoba as the besieged area near Grand Forks, N.D., neared exhaustion behind sandbagged dikes.

MILWAUKEE, April 26 (UPI)-- Robin Yount knocked in four runs in the second game and Gorman Thomas homered in each game today, helping the Milwaukee Brewers sweep a doubleheader from the Detroit Tigers, 5-1 and 7-5.

GENEVA, April 26--Fritz Leutwiler, president of the Swiss National Bank, expressed satisfaction today at the strength of the dollar and disclosed that between the outset of 1979 to mid-April the bank had sold off the equivalent of about $6.6 billion of its dollar holdings.
WASHINGTON, April 26--Former Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz, never a captive of delicate phrasing, could describe in one sentence the meat industry's plight in the marketplace.

WASHINGTON, April 26--President Carter formally sent to Congress today his proposal for a so-called windfall profits tax on oil that is soon to be freed of price controls. The chairman of a key House committee predicted quick approval.

The F.W. Woolworth Company yesterday again assailed a takeover bid by Brascan Ltd. and said that the Canadian holding company, if successful, might be compelled to strip Woolworth's worldwide assets to meet the financial obligations of the acquisition.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 26 (AP)-- Championship Auto Racing Teams asked a Federal judge today to force the United States Auto Club to accept entries of six dissident racing teams for the Indianapolis 500-mile race.
A report on construction of a $95 million international trade complex on 125th Street in Harlem was presented to Vice President Mondale yesterday by the Harlem Urban Development Corporation.
"A new breed of buyer, typically a businessman, who concentrates on assets and balance sheets rather than earnings progression, has flocked to the Amex," says Michael Metz of Oppenheimer Company.
WASHINGTON, April 26--Although the atmosphere beneath the cloud deck of Venus is clear, it appesis to be in a ferment of exotic chemical reactions in which sulfur predominates.

WASHINGTON, April 26--The Nuclear Regulatory Commission, apparently weighing fundamental questions about the safety of nuclear power and the cost of losing it, postponed once more today a decision on whether to order the immediate shutdown of power plants with reactors like the one at Three Mile Island in Pennsylvania.

Cowles Communications, Inc., a closed-end investment company, reported yesterday first-quarter net income of $1.1 million, or 28 cents a share, up 19 percent. Operating revenues gained 9 percent. Investment income climbed 28 percent to $711,000 and net asset value of $68.7 million rose 21 percent.

IN this age of so many good dance performances, the truly great one is not that common. Yet greatness radiated from every moment that Gelsey Kirkland and John Meehan were on stage Wednesday night with the American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House. They left an audience stunned and delighted. In other words, they tore down the house.

The nation's money supply surged dramatically in mid-April, leading a number of money market analysts to believe that excessive easing of the Federal Reserve System's monetary policy is directly responsible for the worsening rate of inflation.

CRAWDADDY, the New Orleansstyled restaurant at Vanderbilt Avenue and 45th Street, which has thrived on jazz that, if not strictly New Orleans in its orientation, is sufficiently traditional to seem atmospherically appropriate, is expanding its musical horizons with a trio led by Red Rodney.

Are the subways safe? Most riders fear the daily encounter with their fellow New Yorkers. And those fears have certainly been reinforced by news of the firebombing of a change booth and other crimes this winter. But these violent incidents tell no more about actual danger in the subway than a single airline crash tells about the perils of flying.

DOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Del., April 26--Bodies of the dead from Jonestown, Guyana, triple-sealed in green plastic, hermetically sealed in 18-gauge gunmetal gray coffins, further encased in cardboard, were loaded on trucks bound for California here today long after the horrifying thing that happened in a faraway forest last autumn.

The dollar was mixed in late New York trading after slipping against most major currencies abroad yesterday. Gold prices drifted lower, fading in Zurich to $242.375 a troy ounce from Wednesday's late price $242.625 and to $242.50 in London, down from $242.75.
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 26--The New Jersey State Racing Commission granted permission today to Meadowlands Race Track to hold advance betting on its two biggest races this summer.

Consumer prices in New York City and northeastern New Jersey rose seventenths of 1 percent last month, largely because of higher costs of food, emergy and clothing, according to figures released yesterday by Herbert Bienstock, the Federal commissioner of Labor Statistics for the region.

ST. GEORGE, Utah, April 25--It is doubtful that even the United States Government knows exactly how much radiation was blown over the pretty, pleasant streets of St. George in the 12 years of open-air testing of atomic weapons just across the state line in Nevada.

The Mobil Corporation, the last of the giant oil companies to report firstquarter earnings, said yesterday that its overall profits jumped 81.3 percent to $437 million, or $4.12 a share, from $241 million, or $2.27 a share, in the first three months of 1978. It was the biggest percentage increase reported by any of the five leading international oil companies.

In a three-page letter to employees, The Daily News said yesterday that "any unlawful activity, such as a slowdown or strike," would subject the Newspaper Guild of New York and the union's leadership to "severe financial penalties" and participating employees to "disciplinary action up to and including discharge."

The names are Bill Lawson, Phil Lospitalier, Merrill Hadry and Jerry Loeber. With any luck, they will some day. take a place in the history of the labor movement right up there with Samuel Gompers, John L. Lewis and Eugene V. Debs. Wearing the plain blue serge of strikebreakers, the Messrs. Lawson, Lospitalier, Hadry and Loeber struck a mighty blow for the unemployed umpires of the major leagues the other night. A 28-minute blow.
Hit with discouraging inflation figures in the morning and with a huge increase in the money supply in the afternoon, the credit markets dropped sharply yesterday, pushing interest rates higher.

ALBANY, April 26--The union representing the state's 7,000 striking prison guards was found in criminal contempt tonight and fined $450,000. In addition, beginning at 8 A.M. tomorrow, a fine of $100,000 will be levied for each shift until the men return to work.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)-- The Labor Department's director of affirmative-action enforcement accused Sears, Roebuck Company today of mounting a campaign of resistance to equal job opportunity programs comparable to the South's massive resistance to desegregation in the 1960's.

HONG KONG, April 26--China indirectly rejected Vietnam's proposal for creating a demilitarized zone between their two countries today at a second round of peace talks in Hanoi, calling instead for the Vietnamese to withdraw their troops from Laos and Cambodia.

WASHINGTON, April 26--Consumer prices rose 1 percent last month, producing so far in 1979 the highest inflation in four and a half years and calling into question the effectiveness of the Carter Administration's economic policies.

A $12.8 billion New York City expense budget that would cut the number of teachers in the classroom and sanitation workers collecting garbage and temporarily reduce the number of police officers on patrol was proposed yesterday by Mayor Koch.
Morris A. Noss, former Mayor of Cortland, N.Y., in the Finger Lakes region, died Monday of cancer at the Memorial Hospital in Cortland, where he lived. He was 62 years old.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 26 (AP) --Whatsyourpleasure, ridden by Don Pierce, took the lead out of the gate and went on to score a half-length victory today in the $25,000 feature race at Hollywood Park.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)--The merger of North Central Airlines and Southern Airways into a new carrier named Republic Airlines was approved today by the Civil Aeronautics Board.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI)-- President Carter will hold his 48th formal news conference at 4 P.M. Monday, the White House announced today.
RAWTENSTALL, England, April 26--As a campaigner, Prime Minister James Callaghan doesn't rush; he doesn't shout; he doesn't panic; he doesn't even pander much to the television cameras.
GLENVIEW, Ill., April 26 (AP)--The Zenith Radio Corporation has announced that 67,000 color television sets produced since Jan. 1 could give off dangerous shocks.

WASHINGTON, April 30--Amtrak, the national rail passenger system, which has a low rating from the Carter Administration, is beginning to fight back as a deadline nears in Congress for action on an Administration plan to slash its service.

WASHINGTON, April 30--The Senate ethics committee opened public hearings today into Senator Herman E. Talmadge's tangled financial affairs and immediately ran head on into the powerful Georgia Democrat's indignation.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 30-- The Security Council approved a resolution today condemning the recent Rhodesian elections as illegal and calling on governments to maintain United Nations sanctions against Rhodesia.

WASHINGTON, April 30--A team of physicians who in 1967 found widespread hunger in America's backward rural areas and in urban slums said today that Federal food programs created in the last decade had eliminated most of the gross malnutrition in those areas.

MOSCOW, April 30 (Reuters)--Andrei D. Sakharov said today that he had appealed to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, to free the last three men still jailed for their role in an abortive hijacking in 1970.

Kennedy of Massachusetts.

TOKYO, Tuesday, May 1 (AP)--The dollar climbed more than three yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange market today in active early trading. It opened at 222.40 yen, compared with Friday's close of 219.15--its highest finish of the year--and edged up to around 222.60 to 222.80.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 30 (AP) --Indonesia will increase the export price of its crude oil tomorrow, the rise ranging from 50 cents to $1 a barrel, it was announced today. The Central Soya Company, a leading soybean processor and grain merchandiser, announced yesterday that it had purchased 986,000 shares of its stock for $135.3 million from the estate of Alvin B. Filbert, representing 6.4 percent of the shares outstanding.

In a club duplicate game, a player who takes a long time to play a particular deal will quickly find himself in trouble with the tournament director, since his extended thought inevitable delays several other players. More latitude is permitted in knockout team play, and within reasonable limits any player is entitled to take his time thinking about a difficult situation.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI)--A Federal judge today dissolved a temporary restraining order that blocked the PostalService from beginning an experiment in guaranteed same-day, intracity mail delivery. The Government agency said it hoped to begin the service in three cities this week.
Dow Jones Company said it had bought the Bunker Ramo Corporation's half of a computerized news retrieval service formed as a joint venture by the two concerns in 1971. The price was not disclosed.

BRASILIA, May 1 (AP)--The Brazilian House of Representatives has approved the creation of a parliamentary committee to investigate the Government purchase Dec. 28 of a Brazilian subsidiary of Brascan Ltd.

Two exiled Soviet dissidents watched from the steps of City Hall yesterday while thousands of chanting, shouting New York City union members marched in opposition to the dissidents' luncheon host, Mayor Koch.
"ON a crowded Fifth Avenue bus last week," writes Jack Hochhauser, "the driver was fiercely trying to make up some of his running time by moving at a more than usual brisk pace.

CAPE TOWN, May 1--A Governmentappointed commission today recommended cautious changes in South African labor laws that would grant union bargaining rights to blacks but maintain some other aspects of a union system that has been a pillar of apartheid.
ALTHOUGH to most victims they are a pedestrian, embarrassing ailment, hemorrhoids have the unusual distinction of having helped to change the course of history.

WASHINGTON, May 2--Members of an expert committee of the National Academy of Sciences that has assessed the health effects of low-level radiation agreed today that the risks from manmade radiation were small, but they disagreed sharply over how small.

WASHINGTON, May 2--A coalition of insurance companies, banks, major corporations and labor unions is lobbying intensively to limit the Government's ability to regulate pension fund transactions that are felt to pose conflicts of interest between funds and the insiders that handle or insure the funds.

BESSEMER, Ala., May 2 (AP)--A package bomb exploded in the Bessemer Police Commissioner's office today, killing the police lieutenant who was opening it, critically wounding the commissioner and injuring two other persons.

ALTHOUGH anyone who has ever used a hammer or a saw is familiar with plywood, there are still many do-ityourselfers who do not know the difference between the various types and grades available, and many who are not familiar with some basic working techniques that can simplify the cutting, assembling and finishing of this versatile material.

Time was when conventional wisdom perceived the Darwin theory of natural selection as an article of faith. Chilled into stone was the truth that life ascended from lichens through reptiles to mammals and finally Homo sapiens.

Negotiators for Texaco and the union representing drivers who deliver gasoline to metropolitan-area service stations reached a tentative agreement last night on a two-year contract covering 80 drivers.

NORFOLK, Va., May 2--Judge Joseph A. Jordan Jr., once a leading civil rights lawyer, must appear before the Virginia Supreme Court on June 5 to answer charges of violating the rights of defendants in his court.

LOS ANGELES, May 2 (AP)--John Wayne, the 72-year-old veteran actor, has undergone surgery for the second time in five months, this time to relieve an intestinal obstruction found during a routine check of his cancer surgery in January, the U.C.L.A. Medical Center said today.

WASHINGTON, May 2--John B. Connally, the former Texas Governor now seeking the Republican Presidential nomination, plans to file a personal financial statement this month under the new Ethics in Government Act despite his own reservations about such disclosures.

COGNAC PLATFORM, Gulf of Mexico--More than 1,000 feet above the floor of the Gulf, farther than the Empire State Building's observation deck is from 34th Street, Frank White's crew was drilling the seventh of 62 oil wells that are to be sunk into the sea bottom from this newest wonder of offshore oil technology, the biggest drilling platform in the world.

THE American Ballet Theater offered its first "Sleeping Beauty" of the season Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. One of the triumphs of Russian Classicism, it is a splendid work that deserves splendid performances.

Johnny Carson said last night that he would remain as host of "The Tonight Show" on NBC beyond Oct. 1 and possibly into next year, but the 54-year-old comedian left it unclear whether he would stay for the two years specified by his contract.

WASHINGTON, May 2--Seeking to preserve what it called its "excellent relations" with both Egypt and Saudi Arabia, the United States disassociated itself today from President Anwar elSadat's attack on the Saudi leadership.
WASHINGTON, May 2--Pietro Lazzari, a widely known painter, sculptor and researcher in art, died yesterday at a nursing home in Bethesda, Md. He was 80 years old.
WIESBADEN, West Germany, May 2 (AP)--West Germany's March trade surplus was greater than the February surplus, but less than in March 1978, the Federal Statistics Offices said today.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 2--A fastidious botanist from Missouri, the sort of public speaker who gives the lay name and the Latin name for a plant, then tracks the name on back to a time older than dirt while his listeners shift and scratch, was showing slides of his trip to the ginseng fields of China when he allowed that mice were a terrible problem there.

RICHARD GOODE gave a curious piano recital Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y. Or maybe it was this reviewer's reaction that was curious, or that reaction in conjunction with that of the small but highly partisan audience.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan has introduced a bill that would eliminate the age limitation of 70 for chief judges of Federal trial and appeals courts.

Stavros S. Niarchos, the Greek shipping magnate, has given $5 million to the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.
By deducting, among other things, $116 for "rental of formal attire for attendance at Pope's funeral in Rome, Italy " Mayor Koch qualified for a refund on his 1978 income taxes.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 2 (AP)-- George Gervin and Larry Kenon combined for 60 points and Mike Green had 9 in the fourth period tonight as the San Antonio Spurs snapped a playoff jinx with a 111-108 victory over Philadelphia in the decisive seventh game of a National Basketball Association Eastern Conference semifinal series.

THE five-week-long Black Theater Festival U.S.A. at Lincoln Center could not have begun more auspiciously than it did Tuesday evening with Vinnette Carroll's "When Hell Freezes Over, I'll Skate," which Miss Carroll brought from her Urban Arts Corps downtown.
Crimes at the bridge-table, like those in real life, do not always receive their just punishment. If you overbid in a team match against expert opponents, ...
The Newhall Land and Farming Company said it had reached an agreement in principle to sell its Magic Mountain amusement park in Valencia, Calif., for $53.2 million to the GSCSix Flags Corporation.
THE Film Forum's Japanese animation program is a catch all collection, which means it has the advantage of wide variety and the disadvantage of unevenness.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (UPI)--The Senate today approved President Carter's plan to order public and commercial building thermostats set no lower than 80 degrees in summer or higher than 65 in winter, but refused to restrict outdoor advertising lights.

THERE'S nothing like the electronics industry to let us know what kind of consumers we are. The introduction of video cassette recorders, which allow us to record television programs we can't be home to watch, and videodisk systems, which will allow us to build a library of readymade programs, type us as busy, working, afraid-to-miss-anything people.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)--At least 15 nuclear power stations have problems with coolant water pipes that leak small amounts of radioactive water, government regulators said today.

As water cascaded into the pink granite bowl and a band played "Hey, Big Spender," George T. Delacorte yesterday gave a fountain in City Hall Park to the city and announced that he would build yet another one in Times Square.

WASHINGTON, May 2--The first three annual awards by the General Motors Cancer Research Foundation were presented today to three doctors in recognition of their excellence and innovation in the field of cancer research.

Aristodimos Kaldis, an artist who painted color-filled landscapes of Greek mountains and New England scenes and whose robust personality and intellectual activities made him a well-known figure in the New York art community, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Ossining, N.Y.

At last, at 37 years old, Phil Esposito is a Ranger after more than three years of wishing he were not. Some athletes adjust to a trade quickly. They pack up and move and fit in with their new team without ever looking back.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)--The Interstate Commerce Commission approved a 4.2 percent rate increase for the household-goods moving industry today, despite an Administration request that it be denied as out of compliance with President Carter's price guidelines.

CHICAGO, May 2 (UPI)--The trial of Attorney General William J. Scott of Illinois on income tax charges has been tentatively scheduled for Oct. 1. Federal District Judge John Powers Crowley set the date today. Mr. Scott was indicted April 9 by a Federal grand jury on charges of filing false income tax returns for 1972 through 1975 and a false amended 1974 return. He pleaded not guilty.

Energy Conversion Devices Inc., which has been working in the solar energy field, announced yesterday a product development and licensing agreement with the Atlantic Richfield Company, a major oil producer.

At 9 o'clock last night, seven New York State correction officers in windbreakers and jeans leaned dejectedly against a parked car and a sawhorse at the entrance to the Arthur Kill correctional facility on Staten Island.

IN England, where rockabilly music from the 50's has become something of a mania, dozens of new albums collecting vintage material are available. Almost none of the companies that recorded rockabilly in its prime has seen fit to release such collections in the United States, the notable exception being the Gusto label, owner of the catalogues of KingFederal and Starday-Dixie, two important independent record companies of the 50's.
The Federal Communications Com mission said it had approved the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation's plan to buy the Telenet Corporation, but only under certain conditions.
WASHINGTON, May 2--China said today that its army suffered 20,000 killed and wounded in the four-week war with Vietnam in February and March.

WASHINGTON, May 2--Some of the $37,000 in excessive expense reimbursements that Senator Herman E. Talmadge collected could have been transferred to his personal bank account, one of his top aides told the Senate Select Committee on Ethics today.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)--The Justice Department asked today for a relaxation of speedy trial requirements but was accused of failing to try hard enough to comply with the existing law.

BOSTON, May 2 (AP)--Cimetidine, an ulcer medicine that is one of the nation's most widely prescribed drugs, can be expected to temporarily reduce the sperm count of most men and to cause temporary sterility in men who already have low sperm counts, according to doctors whose study involved seven men.

HOUSTON, May 2 (AP)--Paula Mayo scored 36 points Tuesday night as the Houston Angels downed the Iowa Cornets, 111-104, to win the first Women's Professional Basketball League championship in the final contest of a three-of-five-game series.

ANAHEIM, Calif., May 2--The matchup was what everyone expected. The featured performers, Ron Guidry and Nolan Ryan, did not disappoint anyone, but Guidry and the Yankees were disappointed tonight because Ryan and the California Angels won, 1-0.

Canadian Pacific Ltd., the diversified Canadian transport company, reported yesterday a 42.8 percent profit increase to $96.8 million, or $1.34 a share, in the first three months of this year, from a restated $67.8 million, or 94 cents a share, for the corresponding 1978 quarter.
Charlotte Mallory Mixsell, who was active in philanthropic work and the widow of Dr. Harold Ruckman Mixsell, a pediatrician, died yesterday at her home in Locust Valley, L.I. She was 92 years old.
A 42-year-old Poughkeepsie, N.Y., woman won an $854,000 judgment in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday against a plastic surgeon accused of accidentally moving her belly button off center.

The American Lawyer magazine and The Soho Weekly News, both of which are largely owned by Associated Newspapers Ltd., said yesterday that the British conglomerate's sale of Esquire magazine this week would have no effect on them.

John Henry Willenbrok, a retired real estate lawyer and former partner in the Wall Street firm of Curtis, Mattet, Prevost, Colt Mosle, died Tuesday at the Candlewood Valley Care Center in New Milford, Conn, after a brief illness. He was 81 years old and lived in Warren, Conn.

Subscribers to New Times magazine, the pro-consumer magazine that ceased publication in January, were never offered the option of a cash refund, even though the publisher had reportedly offered assurances that such a choice would be available, according to an assistant state attorney general who is conducting an inquiry.

STEARNS, Ky., May 2 (AP)--Miners will vote tomorrow on whether the United Mine Workers will represent employees of the Steams Mining Company's Justus Mine, where the union has been on strike nearly three years.
LONDON, May 2 (AP)--Britain's foreign currency reserves declined by $480 million in April after repayment of more than $1 billion to the International Monetary Fund, the Government announced today.

SOUTH HAVEN, Mich., May 2 (UPI) --A review of plans for replacing defective generators at the Consumer Power Company's Palisades nuclear plant disclosed a problem with two of the reactor's emergency cooling systems, a utility official said today.

FOR anyone who might remember Dwight David Eisenhower as an inarticulate, waffling, golf-obsessed President of the United States, a six-hour television biography of the man would not appear to be the most promising of prospects.
WASHINGTON, May 2--A bill to create a new department of education squeezed through a House committee today by a one-vote margin, but faced an uncertain fate on the House floor.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 2 (AP)-- The Aga Khan, spiritual leader of 20 million Ismaili Moslems, has given $11.5 million to Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for the study of Islamic architecture.
HOUSTON, May 2 (UPI)--K. Rupert Murdoch, owner of The New York Post and The San Antonio ExpressNews, plans to buy a chain of weekly newspapers in Texas, an official said today.

CLEVELAND, May 2 (AP)--The city of Cleveland, already under severe financial strain, lost its largest annual convention today when the Pittsburgh Conference said it would go to Atlantic City for its 1980 session.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 2 (AP)--Efforts to resolve a dispute between the United States Auto Club and Championship Auto Racing Teams before tomorrow morning's Federal court hearing broke off tonight, said Dick King, president of USAC.

One of the most troublesome questions facing the American Society of Newspaper Editors as it winds up its annual convention in New York City is whether to support The Progressive magazine in its fight against a Federal court order prohibiting it from publishing an article describing how to build a hydrogen bomb.

A juror on the panel that ended in a hung jury in the murder trial of Cleveland McKinley Davis in Brooklyn was questioned last week by the judge hearing the case concerning an assertion, which the juror denied, that the juror had judged the defendant not guilty before the jury began deliberations.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 2--The reputed chairman of the secret, ruling Revolutionary Council, Ayatollah Morteza Motahari, was leaving a private meeting with Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan and other Cabinet members last night when an assassin cut him down with a single bullet, according to those in the building at the time.

WASHINGTON, May 2--In a break with other major oil companies, the Mobil Oil Corporation plans to propose continued price controls on oil currently in production in return for freeing future oil discoveries from controls or special taxation, industry sources said today.

WASHINGTON, May 2--President Carter and Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira of Japan, terming their countries' ties the "cornerstone of peace and stability in Asia," today instructed their negotiators to settle outstanding trade issues as soon as possible to prevent damaging political spillover.

WHEN Beker Industries, the once-troubled fertilizer company, released earnings on Monday, there was such a positive Wall Street response that trading on the New York Stock Exchange was halted for a time.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 2 (AP)--A landslide Monday on the 9,500-foot Merapi volcano in western Sumatra killed 82 people, and 19 are still missing, a spokesman for the provincial office said today.
PARIS, May 2 (Reuters)--Snow fell in France, the Netherlands and Britain today in the coldest start of May in Western Europe for years.

DALLAS, May 2--Not hampered by a sore pinkie, Jimmy Connors took one set to decipher the style of Gene Mayer, then eliminated the New Yorker from the World Championship Tennis quarterfinals tonight, 6-7, 6-1, 6-4, 6-1.

WASHINGTON, May 2--Gerald M. Rafshoon, President Carter's media adviser, has compiled a master list of prominent opinion makers inside and outside the Government who can be used to rebut editorial and public criticism of the President's policies on subjects from the strategic arms treaty to the 1980 budget.
All takeovers of banks in New York State will be subject to approval by the State Banking Board it Governor Carey signs a bill passed earlier this week by the Legislature.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)--A White House panel today called for active Federal involvement on several fronts to improve health care for the nation's 30 million handicapped citizens.

ALBANY, May 2--The Senate Republican Conference agreed today on a seven-part tax-reduction program that incorporates several elements included in Governor Carey's budget but rejected by the Legislature last month.

Tom Cousineau, the 230-pound linebacker from Ohio State, plans to be present at draft headquarters at the Waldorf-Astoria today, and he expects to hear Pete Rozelle, the National Football League's commissioner, call out his name as the first player selected in the league's annual draft of college seniors.

SEATTLE, May 2--It was very easy for Dennis and John Johnson to get all the credit for Seattle's 108-93 victory over Phoenix in the first game of the National Basketball Association Western Conference championship series last night.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 2 (AP)--The United States grabbed a 2-0 lead in the first period and went on to beat the Soviet Union, 6-3, today in the World Water Polo Cup tournament.

CAPE TOWN, May 2--The South African Government announced today that it would grant full union rights to some of the country's seven million black workers. It will also permit companies to eliminate racial segregation in cafeterias, changing rooms and toilets, which has been mandated by law since the country was founded in 1910.

THE New York City Ballet opened its spring season Tues day night at the New York State Theater with four of George Balanchine's ballets to music by Igor Stravinsky, including the most famous of them all, the 1928 "Apollo."
WASHINGTON, May 2--Unusual secrecy has been imposed on the Department of Justice's investigation of President Carter's peanut warehouse, sources familiar with the case said today.

TOKYO, May 2 (AP)--The United States aircraft carrier Ranger, which collided with a Liberian-registered tanker near Singapore April 5, sailed today from the American Navy base at Yokosuka, where it was repaired, for an undiclosed destination, the Japanese Maritime Safety Agency reported. The Ranger had reportedly been en route to replace the carrier Constellation in the Indian Ocean at the time of the collision.
WASHINGTON, May 2--In an abrupt about-face, the House resurrected today the program of additional Federal aid for cities with high unemployment and agreed to spend $200 million on it this year.

The battle for control of National Airlines has been raging for the last nine months, but none of the three main suitors, Eastern Air Lines, Pan American World Airways and Texas International Airlines, has established a clear advantage.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (Reuters)-- The coal industry, a major factor in future American energy policy, will probably have a surplus of capacity for at least the next decade, a Congressional study said today.

The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange. The reports of changes follow:

Iraq raised the price of all grades of its oil yesterday, according to industry sources in New York. The move increases the pressure for another general price increase by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries on July 1, they said.

ALL right, this is the year we don't grow summer squash or zucchini. It's not that we don't like them. Quite to the con trary, everyone in our family eats them with pleasure--for the first couple of months. But we inevitably end up with enough to feed a hundred. And if there's one thing you can't give away to the neighbor, it's extra zucchini or summer squash. He's busy trying to give his away.
The Treasury yesterday sold an issue of bonds that will mature in 2009 at an average yield of 9.23 percent, the highest rate of return in history for longterm Government securities.
LOUISVILLE, KY., May 2--General Assembly had just stunned the clockers today with a five-furlong workout of 57 2/5 seconds, but the trainer of Screen King was not impressed.

Surrounded by posters that recalled the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island and the ravages of the atomic attack on Hiroshima, an interfaith coalition of religious leaders yesterday called for a suspension of nuclear-generated power and an end to the arms race.

Service workers in apartment buildings throughout Manhattan were back on the job yesterday after a weeklong strike --opening doors, hailing cabs, hauling trash, accepting deliveries and running elevators.
If enough New York fans want to see telecasts of Los Angeles Dodger games, or the San Francisco Opera, or conveniently timed reruns of "Saturday Night Live," there is no technical obstacle.

CBS Radio will resume weekly broadcasts of "College Bowl," the quiz show that tests the erudition of undergraduate students, on June 30. The program, which originated on radio in 1953, also enjoyed an 11-year run on television.

THERE is no public environment in the United States as squalid as the New York City subway. It is dirty, cramped, smelly, noisy and altogether lacking in amenities as basic as a place to sit down. It is efficient--that much can be said for it. But as an object of design, the subway is a lesson in what not to do.
KANEVILLE, Ill.--If hogs are Eldon Gould's line of business, why does the 37-year-old farmer seem so pleased by the high prices cattlemen are getting?
Changes to "turn the foster-care system on its head" were urged yesterday by City Council President Carol Bellamy and Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin.
MEXICO CITY, May 2--At the age of 65, with his prestige as a poet never more secure, Mexico's most prominent writer, Octavio Paz, has opted for the lonely life of a political dissident.
NEW DELHI, May 2--A Soviet offer to build a large atomic power plant for India has been rejected by the New Delhi Government.
CLEVELAND, May 2 (AP)--The 300th homer of Bobby Bonds's career provided the only Cleveland run tonight as the Indians were beaten by the Milwaukee Brewers, 6-1.
The dollar continued mostly firmer in foreign exchange trading yesterday and hit a second consecutive high for the year against the Japanese yen in Tokyo.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 2--Foreign Minister Ibrahim Yazdi outlined a foreign policy for Iran today that stressed militant support of the Palestinian cause, an apparently conciliatory approach to the United States and a noncommittal attitude toward the Soviet Union.

Canadian newsprint shipments in March topped production, the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association announced yesterday. Newsprint production last month totaled 747,000 metric tons, up 10 percent from February but off three-tenths of 1 percent from March 1978.

GDV Inc., a subsidiary of the City Investing Company, disclosed yesterday that it had acquired 168,400 shares, or 5.1 percent, of Stokely-Van Camp Inc., the Indianapolis-based marketer of canned and frozen fruits and vegetables, and that it intended to buy more.

National Airlines announced yesterday that Pan American World Airways had increased its offer for National to $50 a share from $41 a share, matching the high bid by Eastern Air Lines. The value of the new bid for National was estimated at $427 million.

TORONTO, May 2--J.H. Moore, chairman of Brascan Ltd., charged today that a successful takeover of control of Brascan by Edper Equities Ltd. would effectively disenfranchise Brascan's remaining tens of thousands of shareholders.

Two prominent drug issues, SmithKline Corporation and Squibb Corporation, were the biggest losers on the active list of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday in response to adverse news developments. Meanwhile, the number of declining stocks narrowly outnumbered advancing issues, as the general market closed virtually unchanged.
Caesars World Inc. announced yesterday that its board of directors had declared a 3-for-1 stock split, payable June 5 to holders of record May 14.

JACKSON, Miss., May 2 (AP)--The Mississippi Supreme Court today set May 28 as the date for two convicted murderers to die in the gas chamber, but lawyers expected the courts to block the executions. The court reset the executions of Johnny Lewis Washington and John Buford Irving 3d after the United States Supreme Court refused to review their cases.

Amerace Corporation, a manufacturer of consumer products and components for the industrial, automotive and aerospace markets, has appointed C. Donald Caughey to the newly created position of vice president-planning and development.

Prices of grain and soybean futures shot forward yesterday, ending a long period of relatively minor movements in these basic foodstuffs. At the final bell on the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat futures rose a stunning 9 to 17 cents a bushel; corn soared 4 to 2 cents, and soybeans advanced 8 to 12 cents on the day.

ATHENS, May 2--When Archbishop Makarios of Cyprus died nearly two years ago, the political and religious powers that he and his predecessors had held for centuries were divided for the first time between two men.
The show-of-hands vote that ended a three-week strike of clerks for the New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation on April 16 has been confirmed by a secret mail ballot vote.

WASHINGTON, May 2--Negotiators for Uniroyal and the United Rubber Workers are expected to return to the bargaining table tomorrow to resume master contract talks and attempt to avert a strike scheduled against the company at 12:01 A.M. Saturday.

Telco Marketing Services Inc. said yesterday that it had terminated its cash offer of $11 a share to acquire up to 140,000 common shares of Outdoor Sports Industries Inc. Telco said the Securities and Exchange Commission had raised questions about the offer. Under terms of the bid, Telco is required to return all tendered shares.

PEKING, May 2 (AP)--With love back as an approved subject in the Chinese press, a Shanghai newspaper has warned against love based on a pretty face, riches or property. "With fame, wealth, position or beauty as the bonds for love, that kind of love is like straw," the newspaper, The Takong Daily, said yesterday. "It burns fiercely, burns out quickly and in the end can bring suffering and remorse."
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 2 --When the national soccer teams of the United States and France met at Giants Stadium tonight, both coaches agreed that prestige was at stake more than anything else.

CHICAGO, May 2 (AP)--The Santa Fe Railway said today it would lose an estimated $56.7 million in gross revenue if the Interstate Commerce Commission approved the proposed acquisition of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific ...

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)--A judge today acquitted two persons who had been charged with disorderly conduct when they shouted at President Carter and Deng Xiaoping during White House welcoming ceremonies for the Chinese Deputy Prime Minister.

ALBANY, Thursday, May 3--Negotiators for New York State and its 7,000 correction officers appeared to have reached agreement last night on the economic elements of a new labor contract that would end a two-week-old strike at the state's prisons. But they continued to negotiate into the morning over the last remaining snag, the issue of possible retaliation by the state against strikers after they returned to work.

JERUSALEM, May 2 (AP)--Israel today celebrated the 31st anniversary of its independence, the first at peace with Egypt, and Prime Minister Menachem Begin said his Government would consider no further major withdrawal from occupied lands in exchange for an overall Middle East settlement.

This is the message of "New Handmade Furniture: American Furniture Makers Working in Hardwood," a provocative exhibition of 36 designs opening today at the American Craft Museum, 44 West 53d Street.

Victor Posner, president and chairman of the Pennsylvania Engineering Corporation, said that the company had bought 824,900 shares of the National Gypsum Company, or 5 percent of its outstanding common, for $12.8 million.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)--The Senate today confirmed President Carter's nomination of Gen. Robert H. Barrow to become the next commandant of the Marine Corps.
ACCRA, Ghana, May 2 (Reuters)-- I.K. Acheampong, Ghana's deposed head of state, has been released from preventive custody but stripped of all military rank, the Ghana news agency reported today.
Robert H. McKinney, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board since June 1977, resigned yesterday, effective June 1. He said that he was quitting for "strictly personal reasons."

"PEOPLE in Show Business Make Long Good Goodbyes" is a mildewed tale about two innocent, eager young dancers who desperately want to break into show business.

The New York City Department of Health yesterday released the names of 40 food establishments that it said had violated the Health Code. The department also named one restaurant that had corrected earlier violations. It also cited three restaurants that had reopened after correcting earlier violations.

Fuqua Industries disclosed in its annual report that its auditors, Ernst Ernst, had lifted their qualification of the company's 1977 statements after Fuqua set up a reserve to cover possible damages resulting from an antitrust suit alleging a theater monopoly in Texas.
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP)--Two women, one of them black, were among three new Federal appellate judges designated today by President Carter.

HARTFORD, May 2--The two lawyers who succeeded in compelling the state to devise a new system of financing education unexpectedly announced today that they would not challenge the new school financingformula.

ENGLAND is said to be a nation of shopkeepers but it is actu ally a nation of gardeners. QUITO, Ecuador, May 6 (UPI)-- Ecuador's state petroleum company yesterday raised oil prices 6 percent to $20.36 a barrel, retroactive to May 1. Ecuador exports 150,000 barrels of oil a day, mostly to the United States, Trinidad, Jamaica, Chile and Colombia. Some 62.5 percent of the oil is sold by the state company and the rest by Texaco Inc.

"No surprises here: The spirit of 'TGIF,' Monday hangovers, and the resulting absenteeism on both days result in factory failures and endangered motorists."

SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, May 6 (AP) --Michael G. Levine was returned to Ohio yesterday to face charges in the slaying of Julius Kravitz, the supermarket executive, and the abduction of Mr. Kravitz's wife, Georgene. File, 26, who surrendered Wednesday, are charged with aggravated murder, attempted aggravated murder and kidnapping in last Tuesday's abduction and slaying.

CINCINNATI, May 6 (UPI)--A policeman was shot and killed yesterday by a suspect he chased into an alley. The officer, Melvin Henze, 28 years old, is the fourth Cincinnati policeman shot and killed while on duty in the last year.

Henry E. Schultz, a retired national chairman of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith and a former member of the New York City Board of Higher Education, died Saturday at the Miami Heart institute in Miami. He was 72 years told and lived in Miami Beach.

CLAUDE FRANK, one of the most distinguished Beethoven pianists around, was presented by the Beethoven Society on Sunday at Hunter College in the second installment of a Beethoven sonata cycle. Contract talks between the United Rubber Workers union and Uniroyal Inc. ended here yesterday with union leaders setting a "firm" deadline of noon tomorrow for a strike against the nation's No. 3 tire maker unless the company signs an agreement by then.

The General Motors Corporation raised its regular quarterly dividend on common stock yesterday to $1.15 a share from the previous payment of $1. Directors also declared a special dividend of 50 cents, the same amount as the special dividend paid in the 1978 second quarter.

The Metropolitan Opera's 13th season of free concert performances in the city parks will run from June 12 to 23. Four performances each of Verdi's "Aida" and "La Traviata" will be given. Both operas will be sung in Central Park's Sheep Meadow.

Johncamp Realty Inc. said that it had acquired 2.4 million shares, or 73.4 percent, of the Prudent Real Estate Trust as a result of its recent tender offer.
Yields rose on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91-day and the 182-day maturities.

Warm dry weather swept the Middle West Farm Belt late in the weekend, shriveling prices of grain and soybean futures. As farmers rushed to complete their spring plantings, long delayed by uncommonly cold and wet weather this season, overseas reports indicated improved sowing conditions in the Soviet Union and in China as well.
Speeding over a small rise near the Sheep Meadow, Francisco Ortiz rolled down the southbound roadway in Central Park the other morning on fire-engine-red roller skates.
WASHINGTON, May 7, (UPI) --The Senate voted today to require a health warning label on all bottles of hard liquor. The warning would be similar to the one on cigarette packages.

WASHINGTON, May 7--The House unexpectedly rejected today, 195 to 175, a bill to renew the Treasury's lapsed authority to cover brief shortfalls of cash by borrowing directly from Federal Reserve banks.

LOS ANGELES, May 7--On Thursday, Fred Astaire will be 80 years old. Although he will still "occasionally get up and move around with some music I hear on television," he has not really danced for almost eight years.

ROME, May 7 (UPI)--A three-alarm fire caused extensive damage to the Rome Opera House today. Officials said it started when a backdrop curtain fell on a light reflector. There was a minor fire in the building yesterday.

MIDDLETOWN, Pa., May 7--A technician from the Three Mile Island nuclear plant told visiting Congressmen today that control room personnel and Federal inspectors knew that the plant's fuel core was seriously damaged two days before the damage was formally reported and the seriousness of the accident made public.

WASHINGTON, May 7--President Carter told a group of nuclear power opponents today that shutting down all the nation's nuclear generating plants was "out of the question." But he said his Administration was trying "to minimize the requirement" for nuclear power through the use of alternative energy sources and strict conservation.

While the world has been watching the Rhodesian elections, the United Nations plan for the independence of South-West, Africa (Namibia) has fallen into stalemate. Now it seems likely that there, too, an "independent" government without international approval may soon come into existence.

The Pennwalt Corporation said yesterday that it had sold enough stock in Mexico to increase Mexican ownership of the company's chemical operations there to the required 51, percent. In making the announcement, Edwin E. Tuttle, Pennwalt chairman, called the Mexicanization of the chemical facilities there complete. He also said the stock sale would add about 20 percent a share to 1979 earnings.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 6 (UPI)-- George Mayes, a three-year letterman and an East Coast Athletic Conference all-star for two seasons at middle guard, was named captain of the 1979 Army football team today.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 7 (UPI)--Butch Wynegar had three hits, including his fifth homer of the season, and Rob Wilfong singled home two runs to cap a four-run fourth inning tonight as the Minnesota Twins defeated the Toronto Blue Jays, 6-1.

Saying that the city's "overall credit outlook remains highly uncertain," Moody's Investor Services yesterday left unchanged the "highly speculative" B rating it had given New York City bonds in May 1977.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)--Patricia Albjerg Graham is resigning as director of the National Institute of Education of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare to return to a teaching post at Harvard University's Graduate School of Education.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI)--United Airlines announced today the cancellation of all scheduled flights through May 19 because of the five-week-old strike by mechanics and other ground crew workers.

SURF music never seemed very substantial as a rock-and-roll subgenre; it was all frothy vocal harmonies and bleachedout Chuck Berry guitar riffs. But its influence has endured, and a now a second generation of performers is coming along to shore up the continuing efforts of the music's originators.
Remember the squeaking door on "Inner Sanctum"? Or when Lux presented Hollywood? Or Howard Duff as Sam Spade, private eye? All three were popular radio dramas of yesteryear.
ALBANY, May 7--The State Senate voted today to repeal a controversial law that forces animal shelters to yield dogs and cats to scientific research institutions for experimentation.
A SUCCESSFUL money manager in Philadelphia has also had personal success in the stock market in a way that would appall many professionals.
WASHINGTON, May 7--A probably-harmful aspect of the anti-virus substance Interferon has been discov ered, linking it to some serious diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis.

CHARLIE and Josephine were so devoted that they had been inseparable for nearly 10 years. Then one midwinter day, in a senseless act of violence so typical of our times, Charlie was fatally shot in a melee with the police.
CONSTRAINED by television's tight budgets, Irwin Allen, the Jovian producer of "The Poseidon Adventure," "The Towering Inferno" and other big-screen cataclysms, proves to be merely mortal.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, May 7 (AP)--Australia's Immigration Minister, Michael J.R. MacKellar, said today that Australia would accept 12,000 Indochinese refugees in the next 12 months, including 7,500 Vietnamese from Malaysian camps.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 7 (Reuters)--Rhodesia's black-dominated Parliament met for the first time today, with the end of 90 years of white supremacy symbolized by the sight of Bishop Abel T. Muzorewa, who will become the new Prime Minister, seated at the center of the front bench.
Milton Ager, who composed hundreds of popular songs and contributed scores to Broadway shows and motion pictures, died Sunday in Centinela Hospital in Inglewood, a suburb of Los Angeles.

THE phenomenon might have been plucked from a Noel Cow ard lyric. Stars do it. Housewives do it. Even ladies leading gray soap-opera lives do it. The fashion of the older woman's having an affair with a younger man is upon the land.

CHICAGO, May 7--The National Basketball Association owners delayed today an attempt by the New Orleans Jazz to become the Utah Saints. Instead, the 22 owners gave their eightmember advisory and finance committee 21 days to investigate the issues.

Coast Guard tugboats began to haul incinerated garbage by barge yesterday from Manhattan transfer terminals to the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island as negotiations in the 37-day-old tug strike continued.

Bennington College will mark its 50th anniversary with a "Pioneers' Weekend" on Saturday and Sunday at which participants in the college's historical summer dance school of the 1930's will reunite for two days of panels and performance, with films and photograph exhibits.

BOSTON, May 7--With spring in the air outside Boston Garden and spring in their steps inside the arena, the Boston Bruins sought to stave off elimination in the Stanley Cup semifinals with a furious, hour's practice today.
