CINCINNATI, May 7 (UPI)--Paul Blair, the veteran American League outfielder, was signed as a free agent today by the Cincinnati Reds. The 35year-old right-handed hitter was to join the Reds in Chicago tomorrow.

The Coca-Cola Company, the world's largest soft-drink producer, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Wilmington, Del., that its profits had risen 13.4 percent in the first quarter on a 16.7 percent sales gain.
FOR its last concert of the season in Carnegie Hall Sunday after noon, the American Symphony Orchestra offered a solid, traditional program with one minor exception.

HONG KONG, May 5--Because Mao Zedong once said that "knowledge belongs to the people," Chinese authors have not been allowed to earn royalties. As part of the modernization program, the Government is now considering a copyright law, a delegation of American publishers was told in Peking.
DES MOINES, May 7--Tran Vinh Kiet, slender and earnest, spoke slowly and with some amazement, in the English he had polished working with Americans in Saigon, about the wondrous ways of Iowa.

FOR a year and a half, Bruce Beasley, a California sculptor, ran a low-grade fever and broke out in shakes and sweats every time he climbed the stairs. A doctor finally traced his illness to the arsenic compound Mr. Beasley was using to color his aluminum sculptures, but it was another year and a half before he regained his health.

In a financing affected by opposition to nuclear power, the North Carolina Municipal Power Agency is borrowing $150 million this week at a cost that is estimated to be one-quarter of 1 percentage point higher than it would otherwise have been.
Eight new judges have been nominated by Mayor Koch, six for the Criminal Court and two for the Family Court.

ROME, May 7--Bishop Hilarion Capucci, a Greek Catholic of the Melkite rite known for his militant Palestinian stance, was received by Pope John Paul II today and appointed inspector of Melkite communities in Western Europe. His last post had been that of inspector of Melkite communities in Latin America.
Despite library cuts totaling more than $1.2 million in his budget for the 1980 fiscal year, Mayor Koch pledged yesterday to reopen the New York Public Library on Thursdays at a cost of $350,000.

Imposing its most severe penalty ever on an exchange specialist, the New York Stock Exchange yesterday suspended Irwin Schloss,the president of the broker-dealer firm of Marcus Schloss Company, from any dealings on the exchange for one year.

WASHINGTON, May 7--The New York State and New York City plan to save $450 million worth of troubled housing projects has been thrown into jeopardy by a new bill in Congress designed to curtail the ability of state and local governments to finance and construct middle-income housing.
ALGIERS, May 3--Overshadowed by other conflicts on the African Continent, the Western Sahara war appears to be entering a phase that could be decisive for Morocco, Algeria and Mauritania.

LOS ANGELES, May 7--The floundering Dodgers, who had been held scoreless for 21 innings and beaten in six of their seven previous starts, found the New York Mets just in time tonight.

Plans to build a $27 million rolling mill to produce aluminum sheet and foil has been announced by the Jim Walter Corporation of Tampa, Fla. It will be completed in 1981 at a site somewhere in the Southeast, the company said.

WASHINGTON, May 7--Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance met twice today with Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin of the Soviet Union in an effort to conclude negotiations this week for a treaty limiting each side's offensive strategic arms.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI)-- American energy consumption was up 2 percent in 1978, the smallest increase in three years, the Energy Department said today.

TWO schools of thought, one new and one old, have come into basic conflict over a biological question that has long puzzled scientists: Why are similar species of birds, mammals, fishes and insects found in areas separated by thousands of miles, by vast mountain ranges and sometimes even by oceans?

The negative inferences that can be derived from the fact that an opponent has not bid are quite common, but are sometimes overlooked by experts in the heat of battle. WASHINGTON, May 7--A veteran polygraph examiner told the Senate ethics committee today that Daniel Minchew, a former aide to Senator Herman E. Talmadge, had told the truth when he asserted that he had given the Senator campaign and office funds that had been laundered through a secret bank account.

CORDOBA, Argentina (AP)--An Argentine Air Force helicopter crashed near the city of San Francisco, 300 miles northwest of Buenos Aires, last night, killing 10 of the 16 people aboard, the authorities reported.
MIAMI, May 7--A Miami judge ruled today that radar is an inexact and often unreliable instrument of law enforcement.

Although he has never won an Oscar, and he makes sure everybody knows it, Bob Hope was honored last night for his film career by the Film Society of Lincoln Center. A crowd of 2,700 trouped to Avery Fisher Hall to thank him for the memories.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., May 7 (AP)-- John Randolph, head coach at Army since 1976, was hired today as track coach at the University of Florida.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 7--Containers of radioactive chemicals were found today in the loft of a waste-disposal company warehouse where potentially explosive and potentially lethal nitroglycerin and bacteriological wastes were uncovered last week.

ALBANY, May 9--After hours of debate, the Assembly today passed a bill that would ban smoking in virtually all public places except in certain designated areas. The action, by a vote of 79 to 58, marked the first time either house of the Legislature had approved such a ban.

LOS ANGELES, May 7--Alberto Juantorena had a wonderful time on his first trip to the United States. The weather was warm and sunny, he went sightseeing and ate well, saw the Dodgers play, smiled a lot and socialized.
Skaggs Companies announced that it had acquired 2.4 million shares of the American Stores Company under its recent tender offer.
The Rangers, one victory from moving into the Stanley Cup final, are in trouble.
Heavy selling hit the stock market yesterday amid continued fears of rising interest rates.
PHILADELPHIA, May 7 (AP)--The Department of Justice announced today that it had filed a civil complaint seeking more than $149,000 from former Representative Joshua Eilberg.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7--"There's apathy out there so thick," said Albert V. Gaudiosi, who was a candidate for Mayor here when he made the remark, "that you could cut it with a knife." Last week, Mr. Gaudiosi removed himself from the race for the Democratic nomination, which will be decided by the voters in a primary May 15.

MOSCOW, May 7 (Reuters)--A West German newspaper correspondent said today that he was assaulted and robbed of about $900 after entering a taxi outside central Moscow's Intourist Hotel at midnight on Friday.

BALTIMORE, May 7 (UPI)--Jeff Newman belted his third home run of the season, and the Oakland A's pulled off a triple play to back the seven-hit pitching of Rick Langford tonight and snap the Baltimore Orioles' six-game winning streak with a 5-3 triumph.

EAST BERLIN, May 6--East Germany appears to have started a campaign of repression against its leading internal critics that is described by a writer now facing possible criminal charges as "a revival of Stalinism."

AMID all the plastic geegaws and tinny gimcracks, the oil paint ings on black velvet, and the gaudy baseball caps adorned with product names, Saks Fifth Avenue, understated and chic, made its debut as an exhibitor at the 41st annual Premium Show.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI)--Two men constantly seen around President Carter are leaving soon for other assignments. Lieut. Comdr. Paul Reason, the President's naval aide, will become the No. 2 officer aboard the Mississippi, a nuclear-powered ship with a crew of 600.

LEWISTON, N.Y.--A concrete water silo, 165 feet high and filled with 1,757 tons of uranium and and radium-rich wastes left over from the Manhattan Project-- the development of the atomic bomb in World War II--is leaking small amounts of radiation and worrying some citizens of this suburb of Niagara Falls.

ALTHOUGH it was probably a coincidence, the Collegiate Chorale's performance of the Brahms German Requiem in Carnegie Hall Sunday night fell one day before the composer's 146th birthday. Whether by design or not, it was a suitable way to mark the occasion because the Requiem is one of Brahms's most popular and moving works.
The heads of two companies competing for the city's bus-shelter franchise agreed yesterday that damage to as many as 27 shelters in Manhattan early Sunday was the work of organized vandals.

Columbia Pictures Industries reported yesterday a 26.7 percent drop in net income for the March quarter to $11.8 million, or $1.22 a share, from $16.1 million, or $1.75 a share, in the comparable quarter last year, when "Close Encounters of the Third Kind" enhanced results. Revenues of $184.5 were up 13.5 percent from $162.5 million.

HOUSTON, May 7 (UPI)--William R. Roesch, president of the United States Steel Corporation, told stockholders today that the company must generate greatly improved profitability to be able to streamline its operations and successfully compete in contemporary markets.

Interest rates on home mortgages continued to rise yesterday in the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation's weekly purchase of conventional housing loans. The volume of mortgages offered for sale declined for the fourth week in a row.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 7--The first elections for student delegates in Chilean universities under the present military regime have given candidates opposed to the authorities a clear victory.
DETROIT, May 7 (AP)--The Detroit Tigers rallied for two runs in the eighth inning on run-scoring singles by Jason Thompson and Lance Parrish to gain a 5-4 victory tonight over the Chicago White Sox.
Gould Inc., rebuffed on its $298 million offer to buy the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation, bounced back yesterday with an offer of $315 million.

ST. PAUL, May 7 (AP)--Representative Richard M. Nolan announced today that he would lead a nationwide effort to draft Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts as the Democratic Party's 1980 Presidential candidate because President Carter had "abandoned" the party.

NEW DELHI, May 7--Allegations in a book by Daniel Patrick Moynihan that the Central Intelligence Agency contrib uted money to an Indian political party, in one instance making the payment directly to Indira Gandhi, brought demands for an investigation during an angry four-hour parliamentary debate today.

William Ross Proctor, a former senior partner in the brokerage concern of Abbott, Proctor Paine, died Friday in the Hunterdon Medical Center in Flemington, N.J., after a brief illness. He was 85 years old and lived in Pittstown, N.J., and Eldred, N.Y.

SAN DIEGO, May 7 (AP)--Bake McBride drove in four runs to lead the Philadelphia Phillies to an 11-6 triumph over the San Diego Padres tonight. McBride had a run-scoring single in the Phillies' three-run fourth inning and a bases-loaded triple in the seventh.

"Sweeney Todd," the new Stephen Sondheim-Harold Prince musical, has been nominated for nine of this year's Antoinette Perry (Tony) Awards, leading all other musical candidates. Bernard Pomerance's "The Elephant Man" placed first among straight plays with seven nominations.

OVER the years, there have been private efforts to assist children with learning disorders, but now New York City has begun its own wide-scale attempt. The Board of Education's program, which will cost $7 million, is designed to help such youngsters without the stigma of separation from normal classwork.

OTTAWA, May 7 (Reuters)--A court today jailed Jean-Claude Parrot, head of Canada's postal union, for three months for defying a back-to-work order rushed through Parliament to end a postal strike last October. In addition he was put on 18 months' probation.
CINCINNATI, May 7 (AP)--The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed suit today against the Procter Gamble Company, charging sex discrimination in employment practices.
Dr. Joseph P. Mahoney, an obstetrician and gynecologist at North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, L.I., died of cancer there yesterday. He was 58 years old and lived in Douglaston, Queens.

The Boeing Company reported yesterday that net income more than doubled in the first quarter to $108.1 million, or $1.69 a share, from $45.2 million, or 71 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1978.

ATLANTA, May 7 (AP)--Bill Robinson's tie-breaking home run in the sixth inning helped the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 4-2 triumph over the Atlanta Braves tonight. WASHINGTON, May 8--The Federal Communications Commission moved closer today to easing program requirements on the radio broadcasting industry in large and small communities.

WASHINGTON, May 8--Senator Gary Hart, chairman of a Senate nuclear regulatory subcommittee, today called for a five-year deadline for the Administration and the nuclear industry to come up with an acceptable plan for nuclear waste dis posal.

Although no announcement was made, John E. Stoddard, executive vice president and chief financial officer of Blyth Eastman Dillon Company, has resigned, effective June 30. TEHERAN, Iran, Wednesday, May 9 (UPI)--Two multimillionaires, including a Jew sentenced to death partly for his connections with Israel, were executed along with five other people today by Islamic firing squads.

Thirteen hundred workers were laid off yesterday by the Seatrain Shipbuilding Corporation at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard. The company said it was discontinuing the construction of new vessels there because of what it called the Federal Government's "lack of a cohesive maritime policy" and an inability to compete with subsidized foreign shipbuilders.

WASHINGTON--The House Committee on Government Operations recently voted 20-19 in favor of a bill to establish a Cabinet-level Department of Education. The full Senate has already passed a similar measure, and the full House may vote on it by the end of May.
Abraham Ribicoff's retirement announcement, coming at the peak of his influence, caught Washington and Connecticut quite by surprise. He will not retire until his present Senate term ends next year.

WASHINGTON, May 8--Private and Government polygraph examiners gave conflicting testimony today to the Senate Select Committee on Ethics about whether Senator Herman E. Talmadge knew of a secret bank account through which office and campaign funds were laundered for his personal use.

WICHITA, Kan., May 8--The most severe shortage of slaughter cattle in more than 20 years has forced meatpacking plants and slaughterhouses in Kansas, Missouri, Iowa and other Middle Western states to lay off hundreds of workers and reduce sharply their operating hours.

The Minnesota Gas Company said yesterday that it had filed with the Minnesota Public Service Commission a proposed plan to refund $13 million to its customers in the form of a line of credit on current bills. The refunds represent the disallowed portion of a $16.5 million general rate rise put into effect by the utility in January 1978.

The impossible happened last night at Madison Square Garden. The improbable will have to come later. With their 2-1 victory over the Islanders, the Rangers captured a semifinal series that no one, including themselves, had dared dream when the National Hockey League playoffs started.

The Piedmont Management Company announced yesterday in Los Angeles that it had entered into an agreement to sell a wholly owned subsidiary, the Pacific Fidelity Life Insurance Company, to a unit of Life Investors Inc. of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, for $15 million. At least that's the point of view of John S. Reidy, senior broadcast analyst for Drexel Burnham Lambert. He says in a recent report that "significant progress" is being made under the present management team.

SAN SALVADOR, May 10--Chanting anti-Government slogans and carrying flowers and banners, 20,000 Salvadorans walked in the funeral procession today for 17 of the 23 persons killed when policemen and soldiers opened fire on a peaceful demonstration outside the cathedral here Tuesday.

LARGS, Scotland, May 10 (UPI)-- Fire broke out today in the cooling system of an inactive nuclear reactor about 25 miles west of Glasgow, the police said. Authorities said there was no danger of a radiation leak, since the reactor at the Hunterston B nuclear power station on the Ayrshire coast was shut down two years ago when sea water leaked into it. No one was injured.

LOS ANGELES, May 10--The Route 813 bus left the hilly Palos Verdes peninsula shortly after 7 o'clock this morning bound for downtown Los Angeles, 30 miles away. Normally, half of its seats would have been empty; today, the seats were filled and a dozen people were standing in the aisles.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI)--The Government reported today that consumer spending rose by five-tenths of 1 percent last month, half the March gain, another sign that economic growth was slowing. Stripped of the effects of inflation, the April performance would probably show no growth at all.

LOS ANGELES, May 10 (AP)--John Wayne has taken his first steps outside his hospital room since undergoing surgery in which cancerous cells were discovered in his intestines, officials said. MOSCOW, May 15 (Reuters)--Thousands of people using bulldozers, trucks, barrows and sandbags have built 24 miles of temporary dams to defend the west Siberian city of Tyumen from record floods caused by the spring thaw, the newspaper Trud reported today. HONG KONG, May 15--Secretary of Commerce Juanita M. Kreps and her team of advisers and negotiators came out of China today in a state of quiet elation over what they had accomplished. Steel production rose to 2,869 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of 2.1 percent from the previous week's 2,809 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 22--The widespread impression that guilty defendants frequently go free because of the exclusionary rule, which bars the admission of illegally seized evidence at the trial, has been rebutted by a study of the impact the rule has on Federal criminal procedures.

NAUTICAL archeology deep in the heart of Texas? Unlikely as that may sound, George F.Bass-- who was a pioneer in the field at the University of Pennsylvania, which is famed for its classical archeology program--is now teaching nautical archeology at Texas A M University. Its anthropology department offers a master's degree with a specialty in nautical archeology.

A 22-year-old man serving a sentence for burglary was indicted yesterday on charges that he set fire last summer to a Brooklyn supermarket in which six firemen, died. They fell to their deaths as a blazing roof collapsed while some of their relatives watched in horror.
If one moment from the Stanley Cup finals were to be put in a time capsule, it was the one that occurred early in the third period of Saturday night's fourth game.

I HAVE never believed that old canard about "no accounting for taste." A preponderant liking for one food or another is almost invariably traceable to childhood patterns or the "learned" taste of adulthood. What has long fascinated me, however, are the marked differences in taste at the international level.

CASTEAU, Belgium, May 22, (Reuter) --Gen. W.Y. Smith of the United States Air Force has been appointed chief of staff of Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers (Europe), effective July 1, SHAPE announced today. General Smith will succeed Gen. James Allen, who will become commander-in-chief of the United States European Command.

The members of the Democratic National Convention site-selection committee started a three-day visit to New York yesterday by breakfasting with Mayor Koch at Gracie Mansion, seeing the sights and checking some of the hotels that would welcome the delegates if the panel chose the city for the party's 1980 convention.

WASHINGTON, May 22--President Carter today endorsed fundamental changes in the rules governing the nation's financial institutions by asking Congress to phase out interest-rate ceilings on all consumer deposits.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 22--Ayatollah Sadegh Khalkhali asserted again today, in the face of contradictory remarks, that he was a leading authority of the Islamic revolutionary courts in Iran, and he reiterated a call that someone should assassinate the deposed Shah, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

SUSSEX, New Brunswick--Sometime during the last two weeks of May, World War II Grumman Avenger airplanes will again roar into the air from small airstrips throughout the Canadian province of New Brunswick.

MANY of the nation's 35 million allergy sufferers are, in a sense, lucky. They're sensitive to a substance, such as cat dander or chocolate, that they can quite easily avoid. But for nearly 15 million Americans, the source of distress is in the very air they breathe.

WASHINGTON, May 22--Democrats in the House of Representatives disagreed today with the centerpiece of President Carter's latest energy program-- his decision to remove price controls from crude oil produced in the United States.

DETROIT, May 22--Brian Doyle, a World Series hero at age 23 and a utility infielder at 24, knows that time is on his side. But he's impatient. He sits quietly on the Yankee bench yearning to play, knowing that he will be around after most of the New York superstars on the field now have opened a bar in Hackensack or joined some Wall Street brokerage house.

LAS VEGAS, May 22--Just when all signs appear favorable for the further expansion of cable, television into the major cities, the cable industry finds itself confronted with a new legislative proposal that most cable operators believe will vitiate some of the legal and regulatory victories that the industry has won during, the last year.

IN tonight's television melting pot of music, there is Barry Manilow at 9 on ABC and Jascha Heifetz at 10 on WNET. The Manilow, new, is "The 3d Barry Manilow Special." The Heifetz, old, is a rerun of an hour that was first shown on NBC in 1971.
BALTIMORE, May 22 (AP)--The Continental American Life Insurance Company, a Delaware insurer, has entered into an agreement to affiliate with the Crown Central Petroleum Corporation of Baltimore.

The Clark Center for the Performing Arts, noted for its teaching of dance techniques, will move next year from Eighth Avenue, where it has been for all of its 20 years, into its own studiotheater facility a few blocks away on Theater Row, the string of theater-related buildings on the south side of West 42d Street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues.

WASHINGTON, May 22--Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan declared today that unless President Carter acted, he would soon "find that he's governing by the sufferance of" Senator Edward M. Kennedy. But Senator Moynihan added that he had "no idea" of what Mr. Carter should do to increase his popularity.

RIOHACHA, Colombia, May 22--The Guajira State Governor's office said today that two Texans had been fined $20,000 each for illegally entering Colombia's air space. One of the men said they had borrowed enough money to square accounts and get home.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)--Many assertions frequently made in advertising for nonprescription drugs, such as that they are effective against colds, arthritis or indigestion, could be banned under a Federal recommendation made today.

Soon she and her fellow 14-year-olds were hooting with laughter. First published in 1959, it was called "On Becoming a Woman," and to them it read like a relic of another civilization.

BONN, May 22--The Federal Republic of Germany will be 30 years old tomorrow. Like some people of that age, the West German economy is slowing down, showing signs of fat around its waistline and finding it something of a strain to get back in shape.

MORE variety in meat cuts and sizes, new packaging methods for both poultry and fish and a definite trend toward boneless cuts of beef and pork will be changing the look of supermarket meat counters in the coming years. Consumers in search of flavorful beef bones for stocks or the family dog will indeed be left out, although those looking for greater selection, convenience and longer shelf life will soon have it their way.

WHAT with skyrocketing prices and some well-publicized new wine fraud charges, the news from Burgundy has not been good recently for American wine enthusiasts. Sichel, on the Burgundy market.

LONDON, May 22--The British Government said today that its goal was legal independence for Rhodesia, with "the widest possible international recognition." But at the same time, London confirmed that it was sending a senior diplomat to Rhodesia to maintain close contact with the new Government there, although it is regarded by many countries as illegally elected.

ALBANY, May 22--Fearing widespread closings of gasoline stations during the upcoming Memorial Day weekend, New York State today gave dealers emergency permission to meter gas by the half-gallon. The change is designed to let more of them charge more than $1 a gallon and thus encourage them to stay open.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)--The House, approved legislation today offering homeowners loans of up too $55,000 at 3 percent interest for victims of disasters like the floods that ravaged Mississippi last month.

Florida sold $125 million of highgrade tax-exempt bonds yesterday that carried the highest yields for such securities in the current upswing in interest rates, and investors, reacting to more signs of a slowdown in the economy, moved swiftly to buy them.

BONN, May 22 (Reuters)--The governing Social Democratic Party named a woman today as its candidate for President of West Germany but she appeared to have little chance of winning tomorrow's election.

ALBANY, May 22--Formal agreement was reached today on legislation to alter the so-called Rockefeller Drug Law. The accord, reached by key members of both houses of the Legislature, would soften sentences for first offenders and stiffen them for subsequent offenders.

KISMET, Fire Island, May 22-- Long a bastion of liberalism and anything-goes, Fire Island is about to lose one of its freedoms: nude sun bathing. TOKYO, May 22 (AP)--The Toyota Motor Company has exported 10 million vehicles since July 1936, officials said today. Toyota's exports reached one million in 1969 and five million in May 1975, they said.

Eliot H. Weisman, the 41-year-old former president of the bankrupt Westchester Premier Theater in Tarrytown, N.Y., was convicted with two other men in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday of racketeering, stock and bankruptcy fraud and obstructing justice.
Horseplayers clustered in front of closed-circuit television screens at Belmont Park yesterday began shouting when the No. 7 horse in the first race sprinted away to a big early lead.

AS the culmination of its Women's Project, under the direction of Julia Miles, the American Place Theater is presenting a festival of three plays by women from 20 that were given staged readings earlier this season. The first of the series, Lavonne Mueller's "Warriors From a Long Childhood," is playing through Sunday in the theater's basement space. Although Miss Mueller's drama has crucial shortcomings, it is a striking debut.

CLEVELAND, May 21--The chairman of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) Said today that he saw no reason to change his company's decision not to build a California-to-Texas pipeline to carry surplus Alaskan oil, a decision he said he planned to make final within about a month.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 22 (AP)--Mrs. Luisa Walker, the mother of Roberto Clemente, the late baseball star, died at her home last night. She was 91 years old. Mr. Clemente, who excelled with the Pittsburgh Pirates, died in an air crash on Dec. 31, 1972, as he was ferrying food and clothing to earthquake victims in Nicaragua.
George G. Bashian, an importer of Oriental rugs, died Monday at his home in Manhasset, L.I., after a long illness. He was 73 years old.
The City Council's Finance Committee will try to reduce Mayor Koch's 1980 budget by $203 million in "one-shot" revenues that may never materialize, the committee's chairman said yesterday.

STARKE, Fla., May 22--Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall tonight delayed for 36 hours the execution order that was to have placed the condemned murderer John A. Spenkelink in Flordia's electric chair early tomorrow morning. Willie Jasper Darden, the death row inmate whose execution was to have followed Mr. Spenkelink's, also received a reprieve, his from a Federal district judge.

HONG KONG, May 22--China and the Soviet Union appear to be moving cautiously toward new talks to try to improve their strained relations, but analysts here doubt that the negotiations will lead to a major breakthrough.

Western Electric International, the manufacturing subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, has won a $25 million contract to supply an electronic telephone switching system for the Taiwanese capital city of Taipei. The system, developed by Bell Laboratories, the research arm of A.T. T., will be ready for service by mid-1981.

R.H. Macy Company reported a 47.2 percent jump in profits yesterday for its third fiscal quarter on a 12.2 percent sales gain. Directors responded with an increase in the quarterly dividend to 46 cents from 41 cents. It is payable July 2 on 10.3 million outstanding shares to holders of record June 8.

WASHINGTON, May 22--The United States Steel Corporation, in what was described as "the largest environmental control agreement in the history of the steel industry," agreed today to spend $400 million over the next three and a half years to clean up air and water pollution.

WASHINGTON, May 22--With his voice choking, his lawyers grimacing and his former boss smiling, Daniel Minchew tried to explain today to the Senate Select Committee on Ethics why he had become entangled in a scheme that allegedly funneled campaign funds and Senate ex pense money to his and Senator Herman E. WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)--A legislator is questioning the legality of paying $10,540 a year in Federal job training funds to a prison inmate serving a life term for murder and armed robbery.

FOR the financial markets the good news, to rewrite Herbert Hoover, is that recession is just around the corner. The markets are counting on recession to bring lower interest rates and a lower rate of inflation. Consumers, having tried to keep borrowing and buying ahead of soaring prices, are starting to give up. The spring rebound at retail counters has been disappointing.

A world steel shortage beginning in the mid-1980's, portending sharply higher prices for steel, was predicted here yesterday by steel executives attending the annual meeting of the American Iron and Steel Institute, a trade group.

PARIS, May 22--The Ambassador of the Central African Empire said today that Amnesty International, the human rights organization, was correct last week in accusing his country of having murdered students. He announced that he had resigned and formed an opposition group.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 22 (UPI)-- Race fans headed for "Gasoline Alley" at Indianapolis were advised today to make their pit stops for fuel before they get close to the site of the Memorial Day weekend racing classic.

SYRACUSE, May 22--The director of the Oklahoma City Zoo, a New Jersey canary breeder and four other persons have been charged by Federal officials here with complicity in an international conspiracy to smuggle exotic birds into the United States.
PARIS, May 22--Georges Garin, one of France's foremost cooks and a pioneer of the so-called nouvelle cuisine, died in Toulon last week, it was learned here today. He was 66 years old.
AMERICA'S magazine publishers, no strangers to crisis situations, are facing still another one, a really big one. The already tight paper situation is on the verge of getting terrible.

Col. Arthur D. Simons, the Green Beret commander who led an abortive raid on a prisoner of war camp deep in North Vietman in 1970 and helped free two American engineers imprisoned in Iran earlier this year, died Monday at Baylor Medical Center in Dallas.

The City Council voted yesterday to create a Department of Juvenile Justice. The work of the new agency, sought by Mayor Koch to consolidate programs for young people accused of crimes, is now handled by several city agencies.

Stephen C. Vladeck, a labor and civil liberties lawyer who was chairman of Group Health Inc. from 1967 until last summer, when he became general counsel, died Monday night at his home on Central Park West. He was 59 years old and had been ill for several months.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May. 22-- Oleg A. Troyanovsky, the Soviet Union's chief delegate to the United Nations, is undergoing tests for a stomach ailment at New York Hospital but said today that he expected to be home by the weekend.

Philip Johnson, the 72-year-old architect whose recent skyscraper designs for New York, Pittsburgh and other cities have been among the most controversial new buildings of the decade, has won the first Pritzker Architecture Prize, a new $100,000 award established by the Hyatt Foundation.

Moses Malone of the Houston Rockets has been named the National Basketball Association's most-valuable player in balloting by the league's 223 players. The 24-year-old center received 112 votes.

SEOUL, South Korea, May 22--The South Korean Government is hastening its plan to use tankers to store crude oil.

Gold prices hit record highs yesterday for the fifth time in six days as investors switched to the precious metal from foreign currencies amid fears of high prices and low supplies of oil.

Joseph Ratner, a philosopher, writer and teacher, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in New York City. He was 78 years old.

But how quickly they had to move toward that goal was left to the Department of Transportation. Secretary Brock Adams decided to increase mileage requirements rapidly in the early 1980'S, and then ease on to 27.5 by 1985.

BONN, May 22--A Government-appointed commission, winding up a fouryear investigation of the dominant role of banks in the West German economy, called today for retaining the country's banking system while acknowledging certain potentialities for abuse.

WASHINGTON, May 22--Two Democratic Senators, Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Howard M. Metzenbaum of Ohio, said today that they would introduce legislation to prohibit the country's 16 largest crude oil producing companies from acquiring any other company, in the energy field or elsewhere, with assets of $100 million or more.
That staid and often aloof institution, the City Bar Association, has gone Madison Avenue with a campaign to "blow the whistle on crime."

AKRON, Ohio, May 22 (AP)--The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company today reported earnings of $32.6 million, or 57 cents a share, on sales of $1.35 billion for the quarter ended April 30, in contrast to a loss of $44.4 million, including a $73 million after-tax writeoff for plant shutdowns at home and abroad, on sales of $1.23 billion, in the comparable 1978 period.

COLUMBUS, Ohio--When you come back to your native state, old friends ask in wonder and even in exasperation what's going on in Washington. They seem particularly curious about Jimmy Carter. He puzzles them. They sense his personal integrity...

HARRISBURG, Pa., May 22 (UPI)--Two New York City bankers told Pennsylvania's Public Utility Commission today that the regulatory risk represented by the commission makes banks unwilling to lend utilities associated with Three Mile Island the funds they need.
SAN JUAN, P.R., May 22--Puerto Rico's most famous cultural asttraction, the Casals Festival, has been canceled this year as a result of a dispute between the organizers and local musicians.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 22--Twelve state senators dubbed the "Killer Bees" returned to the Texas Senate chamber today after a five-day absence, contending that the Presidential primary legislation they sought to block was "dead."

LINCOLN, Neb., May 22(UPI)--The Nebraska Legislature today passed and sent to Gov. Charles Thone a bill to curb the issuance of warrants to search newsrooms. The bill would allow such warrants to be issued only when there was probable cause to believe that a news person or organization had committed or was committing a crime.

WESTPORT, Wash., May 22 (AP)--A camper truck carrying a party of eight on a beach outing was struck by a wave and overturned, fatally crushing three persons, the authorities said today. The other occupants of the camper, including two children, were reported in good condition in a hospital. One of the dead was identified as James Dereus, 42 years old, of Ames, Iowa. The others were not immediately identified.
THE New York Stock Exchange, which has been criticized for the markets it has made in some stocks, has opened the door to new competition, and its "private club" image is crumbling to a degree.

WASHINGTON, May 22--A Mississippi television broadcaster asked a House subcommittee today to maintain regulatory control over his industry, a position sharply opposed by most other broadcast executives.

LOS ANGELES, May 22--California's popular amusement and tourism spots, early victims of tight gasoline supplies, are trying to hold onto business by luring the "one-tank travelers"--people who live within close proximity.
Johan Cruyff, the brilliant striker from the Netherlands, signed a multiyear contract last night with the Los Angeles Aztecs of the North American Soccer League.

CENTRAL ISLIP, L.I., May 22 (AP)-- Two young boys were critically burned and three other persons, including a Central Islip fireman, were injured in a house fire last night, the Suffolk County police reported.

WASHINGTON, May 22--Orders for durable goods took their steepest plunge in 11 years last month, down 8.7 percent from March, giving the strongest evidence to date that an economic slowdown may have begun.

LONDON, May 22--The chief prosecution witness startled everyone at the Jeremy Thorpe murder conspiracy trial the other day by alleging that he and Mr. Thorpe had plotted to murder not only the male model who is a central figure in the case, but also an otherwise unidentified man named "Mr. Hetherington."
The team that Casey Stengel used to call "my amazing Mets" hasn't been amazing for a long time.

The Franklin Mint Corporation, a mail order private mint and collectibles producer, said that next month it would start minting and selling gold bullion coins and would open two or three test retail stores to sell jewelry and home furnishings.

WASHINGTON, May 22--A new Congressional study says that while a largescale nuclear war would be a catastrophe for the United States and the Soviet Union the two nations could probably recover from a limited nuclear conflict in which each side sought to destroy the other's military forces.

GENEVA, May 22--The Divine Light of Swami Omkarananda, as the sect leader terms his power, failed him today and a Swiss court sentenced the 49-year old Indian to 14 years in prison on charges ranging from breach of the peace to attempted murder.

TOKYO, May 22 (AP)--Du Ziduan, Deputy Minister of Light Industry, has urged priority steps to increase the output of sewing machines, bicycles, wines and liquor, the New China News Agency reported today. The agency said the minister had stressed that development of light industry would expand employment and foreign trade.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 22--Mayor Dianne Feinstein invoked a mutual aid pact and put policemen from San Francisco and neighboring towns on alert tonight in case of more violence by residents protesting the manslaughter verdict in the slayings last November of Mayor George Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk.

Every year, at the beginning of the barbecue season, the question arises as to which is preferable-- charcoal, charcoal briquettes, gas-fired stones, such as lava stones, or electric grills.

HARRISON, N.Y., May 22 (AP)--The police are looking for a thief who has been nicknamed the "bathroom burglar" because of his way of breaking into houses. The police noted that in two burglaries last weekend the invader got into homes by climbing through bathroom windows. He took an undetermined amount of jewelry, including a ring valued at about $60,000, the police said.

N.R. Kleinfield, a business and financial reporter for The New York Times, has tied for first place with two reporters from The Chicago Tribune in the large-dailies category of the 1979 Gerald Loeb Awards for distinguished business and financial journalism.

The New York City Department of Health released the names of 19 food establishments Monday that it said had violated the Health Code. The department also named five restaurants that had corrected earlier violations and two that had been closed for failing to do so.

LAS VEGAS, May 22--The creation of a 24-hour-a-day national news network exclusively for cable television and the presentation of a series of Broadway and Off Broadway productions for pay cable highlighted a number of program announcements at the National Cable Television Association Convention here.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 23 (AP)-- Cincinnati's Mike LaCoss pitched a three-hitter and the Reds smacked three homers tonight to beat the San Francisco Giants, 5-0.

TUESDAY night at Carnegie Hall, George Crumb's grandly ambitious "Star-Child" was performed by the Philadelphia Orchestra, somewhat changed from the original version heard in its premiere by the New York Philharmonic two seasons ago.

Tenneco Inc. announced yesterday that it had found natural gas in the Baltimore Canyon off New Jersey at a well not far from where Texaco Inc. discovered gas last August. The new find, which follows the withdrawal of several companies from the area in recent months, rekindled hope that this offshore site might some day supply fuel for the Northeast.

LONDON BOWLER-hatted gentlemen with furled umbrellas conferred earnestly about their aphids. It rained, turning the Thames-side Royal Hospital grounds into a four-acre mud puddle. Exhibitors worked feverishly to remove the last blades of grass before the Queen arrived. And it was flower power as usual as the Chelsea Flower Show opened here Tuesday, bringing a fragrant breath of springtime to this icy May.

MANILA, May 23 (Reuters)--The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, which has spent two and a half weeks here trying to devise a way of closing the gap between the wealthy and developing nations, appeared to be stalled today. Third-world countries were said to be split over energy problems, and the rich nations were divided over the issue of protectionism. The meeting is scheduled to end next week.

PETER ALLEN has been around for awhile. He was known as a youthful performer from Australia, as Liza Minnelli's husband and ex-husband, and most significantly as the finest composer and performer to emerge from the cabaret scene in New York in the early-mid 1970's.

TORONTO, May 23 (AP)--Wayne Garland pitched a four-hitter for his first complete game since 1977 and Gary Alexander cracked a two-run homer in the eighth as the Cleveland Indians rallied to beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 4-3, tonight.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 24--Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini castigated his secular critics today, telling his followers they should "struggle with them even worse than you did with the Shah."

WASHINGTON, May 24--Nuclear safety experts in the Government knew that Babcock Wilcox reactors had an important engineering flaw more than a year before that flaw played a critical part in the March 28 accident at Three Mile Island, according to a report obtained by the House Interior Committee.

VARNA, Bulgaria, May 24 (AP)-- Blagoi Blagoev of Bulgaria set a world record in the snatch event in the lightheavyweight category today in the European weight-lifting championships. KINGS ISLAND, Ohio, June 8--Jerilyn Britz, a 36-year-old former Minneapolis schoolteacher, did not collapse today in the manner some surprise first-round leaders do in major golf toumaments.

BOISE, Idaho, June 8 (AP)--A few Nez Perch Indians dipped their fishing lines into the Rapid River in a symbolic gesture today, but state officials reported no problems enforcing a ban on widespread Indian harvesting of the spring chinook salmon run.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)--Nearly 113 million acres of land in the West have been proposed for elimination from further consideration as possible wilderness areas, Cecil D. Andrus, the Secretary of the Interior, said today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 8--They were all demonstrably and unarguably still young, even if a few prematurely graying heads here and there in the crowd did raise a vision of impending middle age.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 8--Homeowners in the metropolitan area who depend on oil for heating have begun to get increases of almost 60 percent in their monthly budget-plan bills for the fuel they use.

The Lighthouse Music School cast will present a new rock opera by Samuel Barab, "Little Stories From Tomorrow's Paper," which was written especially for the blind and the visually impaired and will be performed by the school's opera workshop.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 8--Ed Figueroa had the right idea. When he was asked about pitching in this game last Tuesday, he decided he was not going to. He had not pitched since May 19, and he had not been told when he would pitch again. He prefers three days of rest and now he had 19.

MAPUTO, Mozambique, June 8--Robert Mugabe, co-leader of the guerrilla forces fighting the Zimbabwe Rhodesian Government, said yesterday that any lifting of economic sanctions against the country by the United States and Britain could prolong the war,

Paul Stewart Slade, a globe-trotting photojournalist whose pictures of world leaders and fast-breaking news events appeared for more than 25 years in American and European magazines, died of a heart attack Thursday in his home at 625 Main Street on Roosevelt Island. He was 47 years old.

SALISBURY, Zimbabwe Rhodesia, June 8--Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa said today that President Carter's decision to maintain economic sanctions against this country's black-led Government was an appeasement of militant African states and of black voters in the United States.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 8 (AP)--Northwest Airlines has gone to Federal court in an effort to get its fleet of grounded DC10's back into the air. The airline said in papers filed in Washington late yesterday that it was losing $900,000 each day that its fleet of 22 DC-10's was idle.

"Does anyone want to share a ride into Manhattan?" Sally Banes called down the line outside the Eastern Air Lines shuttle terminal at La Guardia Airport the other day, where arriving passengers were waiting their turn to climb--generally alone--into taxicabs.

Peter Donald, the actor, dialectician and toastmaster who was perhaps best known as the storyteller on the radio and television program "Can You Top This?" died of cancer of the throat and stomach on April 30 at Broward Memorial Medical Center in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., after an illness of more than a year. He was 60 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., June 8 (AP) --A series of explosions triggered by gasoline vapor backed up in sewer lines ripped through several homes in east Independence today, forcing several hundred residents to evacuate temporarily, the police said.
NOWY TARG, Poland, June 8--Pope John Paul II, celebrating mass for a vast crowd of southwestern Polish highlanders, urged them today to set a Christian example even if doing so meant risking danger.
The Iranian Government has taken control of the nation's private banks, citing what Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan called "undesirable and unprofitable conditions" in the banking industry.
DORADO, Kan., June 8 (AP)--The Walnut River flooded a two-mile section of El Dorado today, forcing the evacuation of 500 residents and causing an estimated $2 million to $3 million in damages.

WASHINGTON, June 8--With Secretary of Defense Harold Brown sitting on one side and Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance on the other, President Carter leaned back in his chair Tuesday night in the White House Cabinet Room and said: "I feel confident with this decision.".

AEROSOL-type cans of spray paint are ideal for many small finishing jobs around the house. They are widely used for such chores as painting small pieces of furniture, cabinets, railings, toys, appliances and other odd-shaped or hard-to-paint small objects because they save time and eliminate brushcleaning problems.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)--The House passed a bill today that authorizes up to $14 million in appropriations for the Civil Rights Commission in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The vote was 279 to 0. The measure will now go to a conference committee, where differences between Senate and House versions will be worked out.
